headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Conference Call for the quarter ended December 31, 2010. My name is Christina, and I'll be your conference operator today's conference. Please note that the financial results to be discussed in
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Conference Call for the quarter ended December 31, 2010. My name is Christina, and I'll be your conference operator today's conference. 
Please note that the financial results to be discussed in this conference call are preliminary. Statements made in this conference call regarding Franklin Resources Inc. which are not historical facts are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by the forward-looking statements. These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission including in the risk factors and MD&A section of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K filing. [Operator Instructions] Now I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Greg Johnson. Mr. Johnson, you may begin.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for taking the time out to join us on this call. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; and I'm joined by Ken Lewis, our CFO. Hopefully everyone had a chance to listen to the commentary we made available this morning, bu
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for taking the time out to join us on this call. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; and I'm joined by Ken Lewis, our CFO. Hopefully everyone had a chance to listen to the commentary we made available this morning, but just to quickly recap, it was another strong quarter driven by strong equity markets, as well as the depth and breadth of our global presence. 
AUM reached an all-time high of $671 billion, and we saw the benefits of diversification as flow trends to equity and Hybrid products improved while fixed income flow remains strong. We were able to recapture almost half of the muni fund outflows that we experienced during the quarter, the exchanges into other Franklin Templeton funds. 
Operating income was $659 million, again, we end the year the high on a high note, but while part of the increase was due to some nonrecurring items in seasonality, it that was largely driven by the growth of assets. I'd like to now open it up to your questions.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Bill Katz from Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Bill Katz from Citigroup.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just around capital management, you mentioned on your prerecorded call that this quarter might be a bit more indicative relative to last rolling five quarters, if you will, if we look at the payout ratio and the special dividend about a year ago. I guess,
componenttext: Just around capital management, you mentioned on your prerecorded call that this quarter might be a bit more indicative relative to last rolling five quarters, if you will, if we look at the payout ratio and the special dividend about a year ago. I guess, strategic question I have -- I know we keep asking this on these conference calls, but given your very robust balance sheet and the fact that you can continue build cash and try to understand strategically given where rates are and given where you are with the franchise as diverse as it is and recurring asset is, why you continue to husband so much capital? And just sort of what your thoughts are? Is there something that you're worried about strategically in the business or looking at similar transaction maybe why not one or more step up, if you will, in terms of the dividend payout or buyback?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Ken. I'll take a stable at that. I think there's a couple of way to look at this question. First, if you look at our balance sheet, keep in mind that a significant part of the balance sheet, we have to reinvest in the business. And by reinvesting
componenttext: This is Ken. I'll take a stable at that. I think there's a couple of way to look at this question. First, if you look at our balance sheet, keep in mind that a significant part of the balance sheet, we have to reinvest in the business. And by reinvesting in the business, we are talking about seeding new products and co-investing and also keeping money on reserve for restricted purposes. I would say that almost 2/3 of the balance sheet is for reinvesting in the business and earmarked for those purposes. And the remainder, as you know, a part of it is offshore and part of it is in the United States. So that's kind of give you the perspective how to use the balance sheet regarding the philosophy and strategy. I think that remains unchanged, if you look at our history. This quarter's payout ratio is kind of indicative of our long-term history, and I think that's proved to be very beneficial to shareholders over the last four years. I mean is that over the last four years, we generated over $1 billion of cash, kept stable, and we reduced the shareholder accounts significantly by about 12%, I think over the last four years. So we continue to be cognizant of returning and providing value to shareholders. And the other two comments I'd make is the market is do turn, so it's good to have a strong balance sheet. We saw that through the financial crisis, but not only from a financial point of view but from also from a client point of view. We found it to be the fact that we have a strong balance sheet to be one of the factors that we were able to retain and attract clients during that period.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just around margins and, again, relative to your commentary that this particular quarter may have been a bit strong. If you would adjust for the number of one-time asset called out in the prior quarter call and taking into consideration in your guidance f
componenttext: Just around margins and, again, relative to your commentary that this particular quarter may have been a bit strong. If you would adjust for the number of one-time asset called out in the prior quarter call and taking into consideration in your guidance for this upcoming quarter, notwithstanding sort of the time issue, but your margin is running generally above average for the industry. To the extent that the volumes continue to grow, whether it be market or new business, would you let the margin run at this point in time, or do you have any other step function of investors that are beyond your guidance?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: We've said this before too, looking at the short-term margin, we feel it's not the best approach to running the business. So I guess, in that sense, if the markets took off faster than our planned spending, you would see some expansion in the margin. Havi
componenttext: We've said this before too, looking at the short-term margin, we feel it's not the best approach to running the business. So I guess, in that sense, if the markets took off faster than our planned spending, you would see some expansion in the margin. Having said that, I have in my prerecorded comments mentioned that we do think spending will increase, not a function of the margin itself but a function of our strategic plans. I can say most of the business units are under budget, so far in this fiscal year, so that's why I thought it was prudent to put some guidance out there on the spending levels.

componenttext: The quarterly numbers you gave for the first quarter their previous step function beyond that as we get into calendar second quarter of '11?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, kind of just given the shift away from fixed income products more broadly these days. Can you just talk about some of the reasons why you think flows into the Global Bond Fund will continue to hold up whether its kind of the funds geographic divers
componenttext: First, kind of just given the shift away from fixed income products more broadly these days. Can you just talk about some of the reasons why you think flows into the Global Bond Fund will continue to hold up whether its kind of the funds geographic diversification, its performance, maybe rising demand on the institutional side? Any color there would be helpful.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's a little bit of all of the above. We tend to categorize global bonds and look at them like their typical U.S. fixed income fund, but they are different. I kind of put it in the alternatives category in a sense. It's a new category for retail.
componenttext: I think it's a little bit of all of the above. We tend to categorize global bonds and look at them like their typical U.S. fixed income fund, but they are different. I kind of put it in the alternatives category in a sense. It's a new category for retail. We talked about on our prior call about -- it had very small percentage coming from basically nothing to now, being a part of a lot of retail portfolio. So it's a nice way to diversify. I mean the records, and you look at the last decade, how well they've done. And obviously, the currency's played a big part in that. And also I think just around the globe, the consensus of people worrying about their own currencies and a nice way to diversify your purchasing power. It really is a new asset class for the retail investor. Now with that said, I mean anytime rates back up, you're going to have some pressure from rising rates further value portfolio, but it's not your typical fixed income fund as far as rate sensitivity. And our fund has a very low duration relative to other ones anyways. So it's really more about how well you manage the currencies versus how much interest rates are going to affect that. As long as you do that well, I think you'll continue to see very strong flows?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just second, I know you made the investment in Teleco last quarter. And I guess, maybe you're looking at setting up a hedge fund capability in Asia. But more broadly, how are you thinking about continuing to build out your alternatives capabilities in ter
componenttext: Just second, I know you made the investment in Teleco last quarter. And I guess, maybe you're looking at setting up a hedge fund capability in Asia. But more broadly, how are you thinking about continuing to build out your alternatives capabilities in terms of growing it organically versus acquisitions. And then what sorts of products or strategies are you more focused on?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think as we stated before, it is a priority for the company. We recognize both on the institutional side, as well as retail, a growing appetite. We think its a natural extension of what we do. We're a little bit hesitant about just going out and purchas
componenttext: I think as we stated before, it is a priority for the company. We recognize both on the institutional side, as well as retail, a growing appetite. We think its a natural extension of what we do. We're a little bit hesitant about just going out and purchasing large hedge funds or alternative managers just because we think it's hard to have a consistent repeatable process where you can put different players in to that like you can with a retail mutual fund process. So I think we're going to continue to be open to look at everything. Situation like Appelago is really more of a startup-type for us to dip our toes into the managed future derivatives, hedge fund replication and then build that into our solutions area. The solutions area is another area whether it's outcome-oriented or targeted-type retirement plan that will continue to build capabilities and have, as mentioned before, tactical asset location fund, hard asset funds, funds that we think and do well on a rising rate environment and funds that can utilize investments even outside of our own group but the majority of them will be within our own group. So we'll continue to build that but we're going to do it thoughtfully. And we got our goal that said to be x size in a certain period. We just want to make sure it fits within our organization.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Roger Freeman from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Roger Freeman from Barclays Capital.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: There was some commentary in the prepared remarks or the press release about the strategic process projects recently approved increasing spending around that and obviously you talked a little bit about them. Two things, one is, we're also looking at your
componenttext: There was some commentary in the prepared remarks or the press release about the strategic process projects recently approved increasing spending around that and obviously you talked a little bit about them. Two things, one is, we're also looking at your proxy. I think you laid out some margin, minimum margin requirements to get the full payout again. It seems fairly low. I think it was a little over 30%. Is that kind of going back to -- is that indicative of where spending could go that those margins could get down to those levels? And can you talk about what some of those projects are?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Ken. I guess, I want to start by re-emphasizing how can we run the business. I mean it's very much an assessment of the market environment, assessment of strengths and where we want to focus on the next three to five years. Of course, we back that
componenttext: This is Ken. I guess, I want to start by re-emphasizing how can we run the business. I mean it's very much an assessment of the market environment, assessment of strengths and where we want to focus on the next three to five years. Of course, we back that down to an annual process. And so much of the revenue is driven by the market that it's just -- we think the best way to run the business is focused on short-term margins. And so we're going to strategic projects -- my comments were directed specifically to technology projects. And I guess, the question is, you're trying to get an order of magnitude of what spending is on IT and others. I don't think that it's your magnitude that would take the margin down to that 32% level in the short term. We're not thinking about that. It's just enhancing our systems, improving our customer service, functions and expanding globally, more in line with the spending progress you've seen in 2010, I'd say.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: You're core Domestic Equities business, you've been running these vision campaign. You think you're positioned well to get market share improvements as flows come back in equities. You've given us some stats in the past about the number of advisers that s
componenttext: You're core Domestic Equities business, you've been running these vision campaign. You think you're positioned well to get market share improvements as flows come back in equities. You've given us some stats in the past about the number of advisers that sold Franklin. Can you update us on this past quarter over the past 12 months, what that spending is and what the mix is there? Is that equities predominantly?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think for us, looking at the 20-20 vision campaign and our focused on U.S. equities, we feel like we continue to make very good progress the are. And two of our funds, the Franklin Rising Dividend Fund and the Franklin Growth Fund have really taken
componenttext: Yes, I think for us, looking at the 20-20 vision campaign and our focused on U.S. equities, we feel like we continue to make very good progress the are. And two of our funds, the Franklin Rising Dividend Fund and the Franklin Growth Fund have really taken off as fat as sales and then continue to grow in terms of market share in nonproprietary channel. We've also been very successful getting them on DCIO platforms, and that is going to be very important in all market to keep generating consistent sales. And that's an area where I would say, historically, we've been underrated on an all U.S. equity side, but we do have some funds that are doing very well and are getting a whole new audience. I don't have all the numbers in front of me, but if you look at Franklin Equity Group as a whole, we talk about top two quartiles, but if you look at the first quartile overall performance, it's 77% in the three-year, 73% five-year and close to 80% in 10-year of those assets and about 70% in the one-year in the first quartile. So you really have accident long-term performance in that a group at the right time with the marketing campaign, and we are seeing significant market share improvement there, as well as significant net inflows in to those funds.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Michael Carrier from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question comes from Michael Carrier from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: You gave one stat this quarter just on the muni side in terms of money leaving muni funds and you guys being able to capture up to 50% of that. I guess, if you look over time, when you've had these shifts, whether it's in or out of equities, maybe interna
componenttext: You gave one stat this quarter just on the muni side in terms of money leaving muni funds and you guys being able to capture up to 50% of that. I guess, if you look over time, when you've had these shifts, whether it's in or out of equities, maybe international or domestic or vice versa or past cycles with fixed income in equities. Do you have any other, I guess, longer-term stats across cycles that you can get? Because I think that's one of the concerns and everyone thinks that guys have the good distribution particularly in the advisory channels. So those are just stats I think is what the positive expectation could be, and if you just have any more any more details, it would be helpful as we can kind of get our hands around that?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's hard. I think every market will be different as far as what's working and what's not. I think just looking at the diversification, we have by asset class and by geography, I think is really unparalleled in the industry. I look at the muni wor
componenttext: I think it's hard. I think every market will be different as far as what's working and what's not. I think just looking at the diversification, we have by asset class and by geography, I think is really unparalleled in the industry. I look at the muni world and, of course, we felt like this noise was coming. We talked a lot about it internally, try to get people ready. But the muni market is a retail-driven market. It tends to be a lot more volatile because of that. And when you have the headline risk and some of the -- I think this confusion around the possibility of state bankruptcies and things that you get an oversold market. But I think the good news about munis is, I think like most fixed income markets, the yields can get attracted to new buyers and you do a crossover buyers coming in and when those fields get above treasuries, and I think some of the better information gets out about the possibility of state bankruptcies that, that should settle down and I think the market will come back. And already, in the last week or two, you've seen the market settling down a bit and hopefully that's trend. But like everyone, we know as these budget slides happen in the political arena, you're going to have a lot of volatility in the year or two ahead. But as far as how much you can keep and how much is working, I think it's too hard to generalize base on past trends.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just on the Equity business, both in the domestic side and international, you had flows on both those buckets. Any detour or any color on the products that are gaining traction. And then you just mentioned on your recorded call that you have a pi
componenttext: And then just on the Equity business, both in the domestic side and international, you had flows on both those buckets. Any detour or any color on the products that are gaining traction. And then you just mentioned on your recorded call that you have a pickup in some redemptions even though you had record sales, so do you have any color on that as well?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the offshore, the Asian Growth Fund continues to be very popular at $2.3 billion in net inflows in the quarter versus about $1 billion last quarter. Our China fun as well, offshore was a top seller, and Global Discovery had good inflows. Our
componenttext: Well, I think the offshore, the Asian Growth Fund continues to be very popular at $2.3 billion in net inflows in the quarter versus about $1 billion last quarter. Our China fun as well, offshore was a top seller, and Global Discovery had good inflows. Our Eastern European hot fund had good inflows. So, yes, I think the strength outside of the U.S. obviously, is more in the global funds and more of the global sector funds. And then in the U.S., the two funds that I mentioned, the big sellers with the rising dividend and the growth fund for U.S. funds.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jeff Hobson from Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jeff Hobson from Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll start with the second part. The U.K., for us, a nice kind of fit where we get a group of long-term record, and we can immediately try to leverage that through our sales relationships. And even we're optimistic that we can take that group and introduc
componenttext: I'll start with the second part. The U.K., for us, a nice kind of fit where we get a group of long-term record, and we can immediately try to leverage that through our sales relationships. And even we're optimistic that we can take that group and introduce them to large distributors that we had, global relationships with fairly quickly. And I think the other marketed we mentioned would be Australia, which is one that we've looked at some opportunities there and will probably continue to do so, just with the superannuation and the importance of having local Australian equity management there. Outside of that, I don't think there's any major markets. You can look at Japan as one, but probably not high on our list. We do have the domestic equity capabilities there now. The question around munis, are we proactive, the answer is, no. As far as going out and trying to retain, that's probably a normal number for most fixed income funds where they would move somewhere else if somebody had a short-term concern on the market. And I think it goes to the strength the broker dealers sold funds and where they pay a commission and going to the fund family and if you have a well-diversified fund family, you will retain a lot of those assets because those people are in it to buy munis. That's what they want. But there maybe a period where they want to shift out a timeframe and having a strong fund family that allows you to do that, and also having a payday commission, we're not just going to jump out and move into something else because that wouldn't be appropriate. So I think the broker-dealer side, you do end up retaining more than you would on the direct side.

componenttext: I think it's really any of the shorter-duration bond fund. We saw a pickup in the floating rate fund, which rates are going to go up. Obviously, that's a good place to go in the short term. And money funds as well's.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

componenttext: On the Global Bond Fund, it is predominantly a retail product to date. Can you give us a sense of the current breakdown there of the mix within that fund generally, and was the appetite is on the institutional side for that product today with maybe regards to RFP or sales cycle for instance?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: It is predominantly retail. I don't have the exact percentage, but it's the dominant 90% plus of the assets. And again, as I stated, the institutional side is more of global lag. It's not a specific sovereign debt category for the institutional marketplac
componenttext: It is predominantly retail. I don't have the exact percentage, but it's the dominant 90% plus of the assets. And again, as I stated, the institutional side is more of global lag. It's not a specific sovereign debt category for the institutional marketplace, and that's an area where in the last year or two, three, we continue to build good momentum and still have a very good pipeline. I put write up there with our top-selling category and much of that continues to be because the strength overall of that team and the success of the Global Bond Fund that we're able to leverage in the global lag, as well as the emerging markets there.

componenttext: The answer is yes to both. So before we issued the 8-K showing the changes historically. Hopefully that could help update all the models. And the Q should be out very soon.

componenttext: I think we continue to see some modest increase in headcounts going forward. Like I said, most of the business units are under budget, so I'd expect them to pickup. It's just a little background on the change in headcount this quarter. I think there were 60 to 65 with the net change. Most of that was in portfolio and portfolio support functions, sales and technology, and about a third of that where low-cost jurisdiction. So I would expect the capacity headcount to be in those areas and in that geography. So I would expect a little bit of increase there going forward.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's my view is that I think have to take into account the demographics of the aging population and how that shifts. And I think the -- probably the equity selloff probably accelerated that shift a little bit. I think the other part of this is, if
componenttext: I think it's my view is that I think have to take into account the demographics of the aging population and how that shifts. And I think the -- probably the equity selloff probably accelerated that shift a little bit. I think the other part of this is, if you look at the marketplace today, and we look at our -- we're successful in U.S. equity side and funds like the rising dividend funds or Hybrid Franklin income fund or Franklin Growth fund, they tend to be a little bit viewed more conservatively, managed less volatile versus your traditional growth momentum fund. I think part of it is the advisor, gravitating towards that instead of what used to be able a momentum are even large-cap growth. I just think there is some shifts there that it's just very powerful when people are getting older and that you don't want to take the risk that they're taking before and that's not true in every country, but I think that's the case I would make in the States. And you also have an incredible run up of equities during that period. And I just think it's going to take time and you're probably not going to get back to those kind of flows.

componenttext: And in the muni funds, I think in your presentation shows the one-year Lipper rankings, which fallen off considerably now that everybody faced the pressure of muni funds. Is yours just a function of a higher California muni exposure?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The California funds doing I think the second quartile for the one year to the end of the year. It's really duration. Our muni funds are run for current income, as well as total returns and so any time when interest rates are backing up, we will underperf
componenttext: The California funds doing I think the second quartile for the one year to the end of the year. It's really duration. Our muni funds are run for current income, as well as total returns and so any time when interest rates are backing up, we will underperform in the short run. It's as simple as that. We think people buying munis for the higher yield along with the stability of principle, that's how we manage the fund. So again depending on what raids were doing, we generally will underperform and that's been the key driver, not the quality of the portfolio. It's been really the duration.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Conference Call for the quarter ended December 31, 2010. My name is Christine, and I will be your conference operator for today's conference. Please note that the financial results to be discuss
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Conference Call for the quarter ended December 31, 2010. My name is Christine, and I will be your conference operator for today's conference. 
Please note that the financial results to be discussed in this conference call are preliminary. Statements made in this conference call regarding Franklin Resources, Inc., which are not historical facts are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by the forward-looking statements. These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the Risk Factors and MD&A section of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K filing. [Operator Instructions] 
Now I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Greg Johnson. Mr. Johnson, you may begin.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for taking time out to join us on this call. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; and I'm joined by Ken Lewis, our CFO. Hopefully everyone had a chance to listen to the commentary we made available this morning,
componenttext:
Well, thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for taking time out to join us on this call. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; and I'm joined by Ken Lewis, our CFO. Hopefully everyone had a chance to listen to the commentary we made available this morning, but just to quickly recap, it was another strong quarter driven by strong equity markets, as well as the depth and breadth of our global presence. 
AUM reached an all-time high of $671 billion, and we saw the benefits of diversification as flow trends to equity and Hybrid products improved, while fixed income flow remains strong. We were able to recapture almost half of the muni [municipal] fund outflows that we experienced during the quarter, the exchanges into other Franklin Templeton funds. Operating income was $659 million, began the year on a high note, but while part of the increase was due to some non-recurring items in seasonality, it that was largely driven by the growth of assets. 
I'd like to now open it up for your questions.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Bill Katz from Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Bill Katz from Citigroup.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: First question is just around capital management. You mentioned on your pre-recorded call that this quarter might be a bit more indicative relative to the last rolling five quarters, if you will, if you look at the payout ratio and I get that with the spe
componenttext: First question is just around capital management. You mentioned on your pre-recorded call that this quarter might be a bit more indicative relative to the last rolling five quarters, if you will, if you look at the payout ratio and I get that with the special dividend about a year ago. I guess, the strategic question I have is I know we keep asking on these conference calls, but given your very robust balance sheet and the fact that you can continue to sort of build cash and was trying to understand strategically given where rates are and given where you are with the franchise as diverse as it is and as recurring as it is, why you continue to husband so much capital? And just sort of what your thoughts are here. Is there something that you're worried about strategically in the business or looking at May from December [ph] transaction maybe why not be a little more, maybe stepped up, if you will, in terms of either dividend payout or buyback?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Ken. I'll take a stab at that. I think there's a couple of ways to look at this question. First, if you look at our balance sheet, keep in mind that a significant part of the balance sheet we have to reinvest in the business. And by reinvesting in
componenttext: This is Ken. I'll take a stab at that. I think there's a couple of ways to look at this question. First, if you look at our balance sheet, keep in mind that a significant part of the balance sheet we have to reinvest in the business. And by reinvesting in the business, we're talking about seeding new products and co-investing and also keeping money on reserve for restricted purposes. So I would say that almost 2/3 of the balance sheet is for reinvesting of the business and earmarked for those purposes. And the remainder, as you know, part of it is offshore and part of it is in the United States. So that's kind of give you the perspective from how we use the balance sheet regarding the philosophy and strategy. I think that remains unchanged, if you look at our history this quarter's payout ratio is kind of indicative of our long-term history, and I think that's proved to be very beneficial to shareholders over the last four years. I made this comment last quarter, but I'll just reiterate it. Over the last four years, we generated over $1 billion of cash, kept debt stable, and we've reduced the shareholder accounts significantly by about 12%, I think over the last four years. So we continued to be cognizant of returning and providing value to shareholders. And the other two comments I'd make is the markets do turn, so it's good to have a strong balance sheet. We saw that through the financial crisis and not only from a financial point of view but also from a client point of view. We found that to be -- the fact that we have a strong balance sheet to be one of the factors that we were able to retain and attract clients during that period.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just around margins and, again, relative to your commentary that this particular quarter may have been a bit strong. If you adjust for the number of one timers you called out in the period quarter call and take into consideration your guidance for this up
componenttext: Just around margins and, again, relative to your commentary that this particular quarter may have been a bit strong. If you adjust for the number of one timers you called out in the period quarter call and take into consideration your guidance for this upcoming quarter, notwithstanding some of the day count issue, but your margins are generally running above average for the industry. To the extent that the volumes would continue to grow, whether it'd be market or new business, would you let the margin run at this point in time? Or do you need another step function of investment spending beyond your guidance?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we've said this before too. Looking at the short-term margin, we feel it's not the best approach to running the business. And so I guess, in that sense, if the markets took off faster than our planned spending, you would see some expansion in the ma
componenttext: Well, we've said this before too. Looking at the short-term margin, we feel it's not the best approach to running the business. And so I guess, in that sense, if the markets took off faster than our planned spending, you would see some expansion in the margin. Having said that, I have in my pre-recorded comments mentioned that we do think the spending will increase, not a function of the margin itself, but a function of our strategic plans. And I can say that most of the business units are under budget, so far in this fiscal year, so that's why I thought it was prudent to put some guidance out there on the spending levels.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the quarterly numbers you gave for the first quarter there could be a step function beyond that as we get into the calendar second quarter of '11?
componenttext: Well, the quarterly numbers you gave for the first quarter there could be a step function beyond that as we get into the calendar second quarter of '11?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just think -- I would say my guidance was for the next few quarters.
componenttext: I just think -- I would say my guidance was for the next few quarters.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, kind of just given the shift away from fixed income products more broadly these days. Can you just talk about maybe some other reasons why you think flows into the Global Bond Fund will continue to hold up whether its kind of the funds geographic d
componenttext: First, kind of just given the shift away from fixed income products more broadly these days. Can you just talk about maybe some other reasons why you think flows into the Global Bond Fund will continue to hold up whether its kind of the funds geographic diversification, its performance, maybe rising demand on the institutional side? Any color there would be helpful.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's probably a little bit of all the above. I mean, we tend to categorize global bonds and look at them like your typical U.S. fixed income fund, but they are different. And I kind of put them in the alternatives category in a sense. I mean
componenttext: Well, I think it's probably a little bit of all the above. I mean, we tend to categorize global bonds and look at them like your typical U.S. fixed income fund, but they are different. And I kind of put them in the alternatives category in a sense. I mean, it's a new category for retail. We talked about it on prior calls about -- it had very small percentage coming from basically nothing to now being a part of a lot of that retail portfolio. So it's a nice way to diversify. I mean, the records and you look at the last decade, how well they've done. And obviously, the currencies play a big part in that. And also I think just around the globe, the consensus of people worrying about their own currencies and a nice way to diversify your purchasing power. It really is a new asset class for the retail investor. Now with that said, I mean any time rates back up, you're going to have some pressure from rising rates and just the value of the portfolio, but it's just not your typical fixed income fund as far as rate sensitivity, and our funds has a very low duration relative to other ones anyway. So it's really more about how well you manage the currencies versus how much interest rates are going to affect that. As long as you do that well, I think you'll continue to see very strong flows.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just second, I know you made the investment in Pelagos last quarter. And I guess, maybe you're looking at setting up a hedge fund capabilities in Asia. But more broadly, how are you thinking about continuing to build out your alternatives capabil
componenttext: And then just second, I know you made the investment in Pelagos last quarter. And I guess, maybe you're looking at setting up a hedge fund capabilities in Asia. But more broadly, how are you thinking about continuing to build out your alternatives capabilities in terms of growing it organically versus acquisitions? And then what sorts of products or strategies are you more focused on?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as we've stated before, I mean it is a priority for the company. We recognize both on the institutional side, as well as retail, a growing appetite. We think it's a natural extension of what we do. We're a little bit hesitant about just goin
componenttext: Well, I think as we've stated before, I mean it is a priority for the company. We recognize both on the institutional side, as well as retail, a growing appetite. We think it's a natural extension of what we do. We're a little bit hesitant about just going out and purchasing large hedge funds or alternative managers just because we think it's hard to have a consistent repeatable process where you can put different players into that like you can with a retail mutual fund process. So I think we're going to continue to be open to look at everything. Situation like the Pelagos is really more of the startup type for us to dip our toes into the managed future derivatives, hedge fund replication and then build that into our solutions area. The solutions area is another area whether it's outcome-oriented or targeted-type retirement plans that we will continue to build capabilities and have. As I've mentioned before, tactical asset allocation fund, hard asset funds, funds that we think can do well in a rising rate environment and funds that can utilize investments even outside of our own group, but the majority of them will be within our own group. So we'll continue to build that, but we're going to do it thoughtfully. And we've got no goal that says we have to be X size in a certain period. We just want to make sure that it fits within our organization.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Roger Freeman from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Roger Freeman from Barclays Capital.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess, could you -- there was some commentary I think I came over the prepared remarks or the press release about strategic projects recently approved, increasing spending around that and obviously, you just talked a little bit about it. I guess, two th
componenttext: I guess, could you -- there was some commentary I think I came over the prepared remarks or the press release about strategic projects recently approved, increasing spending around that and obviously, you just talked a little bit about it. I guess, two things there. One is, we're also looking at your proxy. I think you laid out some minimum margin requirements to get sort of full payout against those and they seem fairly low. I think it was a little over 30%. Is that kind of going back to -- I think Bill's question. Is that indicative of where spending could go that those margins could get down to those levels? And can you talk about what some of those projects are?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Ken. Yes, I guess, I want to start by re-emphasizing how we run the business. I mean, it's very much an assessment of the market environment, assessment of our strengths and where we want to focus on the next three to five years. Of course,
componenttext: Sure. This is Ken. Yes, I guess, I want to start by re-emphasizing how we run the business. I mean, it's very much an assessment of the market environment, assessment of our strengths and where we want to focus on the next three to five years. Of course, we've backed that down into an annual process. And so much of the revenue is driven by the market that it's just -- we think not the best way to run the business to focus on short-term margins. And so we're going the strategic projects -- my comments were directed specifically to technology projects. And I guess, the question is, you're trying to get an order of magnitude of what spending is on IT and others. I don't think that it's the order of magnitude that would take the margin down to that 32% level in the short term. We're not thinking about that. It's just enhancing our systems, improving our customer service, functions and expanding globally, more in line with the spending progress you've seen in 2010, I'd say.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your core Domestic Equities business, you've been running this vision campaign. I know you think you're positioned well to get market share improvements as flows come back in equities. You've given us some stats [statistics] in the past about the number o
componenttext: Your core Domestic Equities business, you've been running this vision campaign. I know you think you're positioned well to get market share improvements as flows come back in equities. You've given us some stats [statistics] in the past about the number of advisors that sold Franklin bonds for the first time. And can you kind of update us on maybe this past quarter, maybe over the past 12 months, what that spending and what the mix has been? I mean, is that equities predominantly?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think for us -- looking at the 20-20 vision campaign and our focused on U.S. equities, we feel like we continue to make very good progress there. And two of our funds, the Franklin Rising Dividends Fund and the Franklin Growth Fund have really take
componenttext: Yes, I think for us -- looking at the 20-20 vision campaign and our focused on U.S. equities, we feel like we continue to make very good progress there. And two of our funds, the Franklin Rising Dividends Fund and the Franklin Growth Fund have really taken off as far as sales and continued to grow in terms of market share in non-proprietary channel. We've also been very successful in getting them on DCIO platforms, and that is going to be very important in all markets to kind of keep generating consistent sales. And that's an area where I would say, historically we've been under weighted on the U.S. equity side, but we do have some funds that are doing very well and are getting a whole new audience. I don't have all of the numbers in front of me, but if you look at the Franklin Equity Group as a whole, we talk about top two quartiles. But if you look at the first quartile overall performance, it's 77% in the three year, 73% in the five year and close to 80% in the 10 year of those assets and about 70% in the one year in the first quartile. So you really have excellent long-term performance with that group at the right time with the marketing campaign, and we are seeing significant market share improvements there, as well as significant net inflows into those funds.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Michael Carrier from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question comes from Michael Carrier from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: You gave one stat this quarter just on the muni side in terms of money leaving muni funds and you guys being able to capture roughly 50% of that. I guess, if you look over time, when you've had these shifts, whether it's in and out of equities, maybe inte
componenttext: You gave one stat this quarter just on the muni side in terms of money leaving muni funds and you guys being able to capture roughly 50% of that. I guess, if you look over time, when you've had these shifts, whether it's in and out of equities, maybe international or domestic or vice versa or past cycles with fixed income in equities. Do you have any other I guess like longer-term stats across cycles that you could give? Because I think that's one of the concerns and everyone thinks that you guys have the good distribution, particularly in the advisory channels. So those are just stats I think is what the positive expectation could be, and if you just had any more details, it would be helpful as we can kind of get our hands around that?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's hard. I mean, I think every market's a little bit different as far as what's working and what's not. And I think just looking at the diversification, we have by asset class and by geography, I think is really unparalleled in the industr
componenttext: Well, I think it's hard. I mean, I think every market's a little bit different as far as what's working and what's not. And I think just looking at the diversification, we have by asset class and by geography, I think is really unparalleled in the industry. I look at the muni world and, of course, we felt like this noise was coming. I mean we talked a lot about it internally, try to get people ready, but the muni market is a retail-driven market. It tends to be a lot more volatile because of that. And when you have the headline risk and some of the -- I think this confusion around the possibility of state bankruptcies and things that you get an oversold market. But I think the good news about munis is, I think they -- like most fixed income markets, the yields can get attracted to new buyers and you do have crossover buyers coming in and when those yields get above treasuries, and I think some of the better information gets out about the possibility of state bankruptcies that, that issue will settle down and I think the market will come back. And already, in the last week or two, you've seen the market settling down a bit and hopefully that's a trend. But like everyone, we know as these budget slides happen in the political arena, you're going to have a lot of volatility in the year or two ahead. But as far as how much you can keep and how much is working, I mean, I think too hard to generalize base on past trends.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just in the Equity business, both on the domestic side and international. You had flows in both those buckets. I guess, any detour or any color on the products that are gaining traction. And then you just mentioned on the recorded call that you h
componenttext: And then just in the Equity business, both on the domestic side and international. You had flows in both those buckets. I guess, any detour or any color on the products that are gaining traction. And then you just mentioned on the recorded call that you had a pickup in some redemptions, even though you had record sales, so do you have any color on that as well?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the offshore, the Asia Growth Fund continues to be very popular. We had $2.3 billion in net inflows in the quarter versus about $1 billion last quarter. Our China Fund as well, offshore was a top seller, and Global Discovery had good inflows
componenttext: Well, I think the offshore, the Asia Growth Fund continues to be very popular. We had $2.3 billion in net inflows in the quarter versus about $1 billion last quarter. Our China Fund as well, offshore was a top seller, and Global Discovery had good inflows. Our Eastern European hot fund had good inflows. So yes, I think the strength outside of the U.S. obviously is more in the global funds and more of the global sector funds. And in the U.S., the two funds that I mentioned, the big sellers were the rising dividend and the growth fund that are for U.S. funds.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Jeff Hopson from Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: The next question comes from Jeff Hopson from Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Back on the muni exchanges, is that something you're doing proactively to try to retain those, or is that just a natural consequence of having better brand awareness with the financial advisors? And then secondarily, I know that the U.K. had been somethin
componenttext: Back on the muni exchanges, is that something you're doing proactively to try to retain those, or is that just a natural consequence of having better brand awareness with the financial advisors? And then secondarily, I know that the U.K. had been something that you want to fill over time. As we think strategically around the globe going forward, where could be potential areas that you feel like you need to be in either where you're not in or you need to be bigger in those particular markets.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll start with the second part. The U.K. for us, a nice kind of fit where we get a group with long-term record and we can immediately try to leverage that through our sales relationships. And even we're optimistic that we can take that group and introduc
componenttext: I'll start with the second part. The U.K. for us, a nice kind of fit where we get a group with long-term record and we can immediately try to leverage that through our sales relationships. And even we're optimistic that we can take that group and introduce them to some large distributors that we have global relationships with fairly quickly. Now I think the other market that we mentioned would be Australia, which is one that we've looked at some opportunities there and will probably continue to do so, just with the superannuation and the importance of having local Australian equity management there. Outside of that, I don't think there's any major markets. I mean you could look at Japan as one, but probably not high in our list. We do have a domestic equity capability there now. The question around munis, are we proactive? The answer is, no. As far as going out and trying to retain, that's probably a normal number for most fixed income funds where they would move somewhere else if somebody had a short-term concern on the market. And I think it goes to the strength the broker-dealers sold funds and where they pay a commission and go into the fund family. And if you have a well-diversified fund family, you will retain a lot of those assets because those people are in it to buy munis. That's what they want. But there maybe a period where they want to shift out for a time frame and having a strong fund family allows you to do that, and also having payday commission, they're not going to just jump out and move into something else because that wouldn't be appropriate. So I think the broker-dealer side, you do end up retaining more than you would on the direct side.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

componenttext: And then on the Global Bond Fund, it is predominantly I think been a retail product to date. And can you give us a sense of the current breakdown there of the mix within that fund generally, and what the appetite is on the institutional side for that product today, maybe with regards to RFP or kind of sales cycle where it sits?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: It is predominantly retail. I don't have the exact percentage, but it's the dominant 90% plus of the assets. And again, as I stated, I think the institutional side is more a global lag. It's not a specific sovereign debt category for the institutional mar
componenttext: It is predominantly retail. I don't have the exact percentage, but it's the dominant 90% plus of the assets. And again, as I stated, I think the institutional side is more a global lag. It's not a specific sovereign debt category for the institutional marketplace, and that's an area where in the last year, two, three, we continue to build good momentum and still have a very good pipeline. I'd put that write-up there with our top-selling category and much of that continues to be because of the strength overall of that team and the success on the Global Bond Fund that we're able to leverage in the global lag, as well as emerging markets debt.

componenttext: The answer is yes to both. So before we put the earnings release out we issued the 8-K showing the changes historically, hopefully that could help update all the models. And certainly, in the Q, we're going to break out the expense line item to show which component of the expense is more or less sales-based, which component is more related to assets under management, and then we'll show the amortization at the first commission. And the Q should be out very soon.

componenttext: Well, I think we're working on it. We want to make sure that, that's part of the reason we came in with a 20% stake and want to understand exactly how derivatives fit into a 40-act [ph] type retail product. And so we'll take our time there and try to figure out where it fits. So I would imagine something in the next 12 months, we would expect but there really is no direct timetable to introduce those capabilities in our funds right now.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

componenttext: Just headcount rose a bit in the quarter, how do see that over the next year?

componenttext: I think it will continue to see some modest increase in headcounts going forward. Like I said, most of the business units are under budget, so I'd expect the hiring to pickup. Maybe a little background on the change in headcount this quarter. I think there were 60 to 65 with the net change. Most of that was in portfolio and portfolio support functions, sales and technology, and about a third of that were in low-cost jurisdiction. So I would expect the capacity headcount to be in those areas and in that geography. So I would expect a little bit of increase going forward.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Given that predominate U.S. retail franchise, curious on what your thoughts are or aspirations are for making a bigger push? I know some people are concerned that higher rates bring changes in allocations. I actually think higher rates is a lot of institu
componenttext: Given that predominate U.S. retail franchise, curious on what your thoughts are or aspirations are for making a bigger push? I know some people are concerned that higher rates bring changes in allocations. I actually think higher rates is a lot of institutions around the world would love to invest at a higher yield. So just curious on your thoughts on growing the institutional fixed income footprint in the U.S. over time.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Now that's been a big push of ours, and I think we continue to build out the capabilities there and we have a very strong team and I would agree. And I think that fixed income tends to rebound a lot faster in bear markets than equities do because of that
componenttext: Now that's been a big push of ours, and I think we continue to build out the capabilities there and we have a very strong team and I would agree. And I think that fixed income tends to rebound a lot faster in bear markets than equities do because of that current yield. And you're right, you do attract new buyers that come in and all of a sudden say, hey I can get X percent on a muni or on a government and that will attract a new buyer. And once rates settle down, that's true, you will come back a little bit faster.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And what does it take -- in other words, it feels like a lot of the infrastructure is there. Clearly you have great management skills. Can you do side-by-side? Can the same managers manage the funds? And is it more of the marketing effort to get into the
componenttext: And what does it take -- in other words, it feels like a lot of the infrastructure is there. Clearly you have great management skills. Can you do side-by-side? Can the same managers manage the funds? And is it more of the marketing effort to get into the consultants and that just is a longer sales process?

componenttext: Well, I think the answer is yes to both. You can do side-by-side. That's what we do, and we have been building very good relationships with the consultants and continue to see very significant separate accounts come in, in the last quarter or two of our largest separate accounts for global lag, so it's working.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

componenttext: The next question comes from Bill Katz from Citigroup.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greg, you mentioned toward the end of the pre-recorded call that you would expect to shift back to equities, but flows maybe a little bit more drawn out and maybe less than prior cycles. Maybe you could expand on that a little bit. It seems to be a little
componenttext: Greg, you mentioned toward the end of the pre-recorded call that you would expect to shift back to equities, but flows maybe a little bit more drawn out and maybe less than prior cycles. Maybe you could expand on that a little bit. It seems to be a little bit more conservative than what some of your peers have been saying over the last couple of days. So is that your view? Is that your view on top of your relationship with the distributors in getting feedback that way? Maybe just a little more qualitative discussion around that will be helpful.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's my view that I think you have to take into account the demographics of an aging population and how that shifts. And I think the -- probably the Subir [ph] equity sell off probably accelerated that shift a little bit. I think the other p
componenttext: Well, I think it's my view that I think you have to take into account the demographics of an aging population and how that shifts. And I think the -- probably the Subir [ph] equity sell off probably accelerated that shift a little bit. I think the other part of it is, if you look at the marketplace today and we look at our -- we're successful in the U.S. equity side and funds like the rising dividend fund or a Hybrid Franklin income fund or a Franklin Growth Fund, that tend to be a little bit viewed more conservatively, managed less volatile versus your traditional growth momentum fund. I think part of it is the advisor gravitating towards that instead of what used to be a momentum or even a large-cap growth. So I just think there's some shifts there that it's just very powerful when people are getting older and they're not going to want to take the risk that they're taking before and that's not true in every country, but I think that's the case I would make in the States. And you also had an incredible runoff of equities during that period. And I just think it's going to take time and you're probably not going to get back to those kind of flows.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Marc Irizarry from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question comes from Marc Irizarry from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greg, when I look at the net flow trends and equity just on their phase and obviously U.S. equity fund flows picking up and then looks like some deceleration in global. Is there anything from a tactical perspective that you're seeing from the retail chann
componenttext: Greg, when I look at the net flow trends and equity just on their phase and obviously U.S. equity fund flows picking up and then looks like some deceleration in global. Is there anything from a tactical perspective that you're seeing from the retail channel across the globe that suggest that maybe there's a little bit of more demand for U.S. over global at this point in time from obviously tactical perspective?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I mean I don't think we're seeing that. I think for us, our performance has been better on some of the U.S. funds in the near term. And if you look at our big global funds, they have a bias value, value has underperformed growth here for the last coup
componenttext: No, I mean I don't think we're seeing that. I think for us, our performance has been better on some of the U.S. funds in the near term. And if you look at our big global funds, they have a bias value, value has underperformed growth here for the last couple of years. And Mutual Series is more defensive in nature and has higher cash levels in Templeton, it has always been under weighted material through the last few years. So I think that hurt the shorter-term performance for some of our core global funds. And as you would expect, we're not doing as well there as we would like to be.

componenttext: Well, I think it just depends on people's individual view. headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just looking on the returns in that fund. First, I think in October, a pretty significantly underperformed the Barclays Global Ag Index, but then it dramatically outperformed in November and December. I'm just curious if there's any sort of shift in curre
componenttext: Just looking on the returns in that fund. componenttext: Well, I think there's always shift. I don't think there's was a dramatic shift. And I think we always talk about short-term underperformance because we expect it in that fund in any given time when how quickly the euro can move on some headlines and that's going to affect. Hopefully, we get the longer-term trends right, and that's what we've done. But there's always going to be periods where we have short-term underperformance with that kind of fund.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then in the muni funds, I think in your presentation you showed the one-year Lipper rankings, which fallen off considerably and obviously everybody has faced the pressures of muni fund investing. Is yours just a function of a higher California muni ex
componenttext: And then in the muni funds, I think in your presentation you showed the one-year Lipper rankings, which fallen off considerably and obviously everybody has faced the pressures of muni fund investing. Is yours just a function of a higher California muni exposure?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, actually -- I mean, the California funds are doing -- I think it was second quartile for the one year through the end of the year. It's really duration. I mean our muni funds are run for current income, as well as total return. And so any time when in
componenttext: No, actually -- I mean, the California funds are doing -- I think it was second quartile for the one year through the end of the year. It's really duration. I mean our muni funds are run for current income, as well as total return. And so any time when interest rates are backing up, we will underperform in the short run. I mean it's as simple as that. We think people buying munis for the higher yield, along with the stability of principle, that's how we manage the funds. So again, depending on what rates are doing, we generally will underperform and that's been the key driver, not the quality of the portfolio. It's been really the duration.
