headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Conference Call for the quarter ended December 31, 2010. My name is Christine, and I will be your conference operator for today's conference. Please note that the financial results to be discuss
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Conference Call for the quarter ended December 31, 2010. My name is Christine, and I will be your conference operator for today's conference. 
Please note that the financial results to be discussed in this conference call are preliminary. Statements made in this conference call regarding Franklin Resources, Inc., which are not historical facts are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by the forward-looking statements. These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the Risk Factors and MD&A section of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K filing. [Operator Instructions] 
Now I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Greg Johnson. Mr. Johnson, you may begin.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for taking time out to join us on this call. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; and I'm joined by Ken Lewis, our CFO. Hopefully everyone had a chance to listen to the commentary we made available this morning,
componenttext:
Well, thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for taking time out to join us on this call. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; and I'm joined by Ken Lewis, our CFO. Hopefully everyone had a chance to listen to the commentary we made available this morning, but just to quickly recap, it was another strong quarter driven by strong equity markets, as well as the depth and breadth of our global presence. 
AUM reached an all-time high of $671 billion, and we saw the benefits of diversification as flow trends to equity and Hybrid products improved, while fixed income flows remained strong. We were able to recapture almost half of the muni [municipal] fund outflows that we experienced during the quarter, via exchanges into other Franklin Templeton funds. Operating income was $659 million, began the year on a high note, but while part of the increase was due to some non-recurring items in seasonality, it was largely driven by the growth of assets. 
I'd like to now open it up for your questions.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Bill Katz from Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Bill Katz from Citigroup.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: First question is just around capital management. You mentioned on your pre-recorded call that this quarter might be a bit more indicative relative to the last rolling five quarters, if you will, if you look at the payout ratio and I get that with the spe
componenttext: First question is just around capital management. You mentioned on your pre-recorded call that this quarter might be a bit more indicative relative to the last rolling five quarters, if you will, if you look at the payout ratio and I get that with the special dividend about a year ago. I guess, the strategic question I have is I know we keep asking on these conference calls, but given your very robust balance sheet and the fact that you can continue to sort of build cash, I’m just trying to understand strategically given where rates are and given where you are with the franchise as diverse as it is and as recurring as it is, why you continue to husband so much capital? And just sort of what your thoughts are here. Is there something that you're worried about strategically in the business or looking at maybe from a seminal transaction, maybe wind up dealing more, maybe stepped up, if you will, in terms of either dividend payout or buyback?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Ken. I'll take a stab at that. I think there's a couple of ways to look at this question. First, if you look at our balance sheet, keep in mind that a significant part of the balance sheet we have to reinvest in the business. And by reinvesting in
componenttext: This is Ken. I'll take a stab at that. I think there's a couple of ways to look at this question. First, if you look at our balance sheet, keep in mind that a significant part of the balance sheet we have to reinvest in the business. And by reinvesting in the business, we're talking about seeding new products and co-investing and also keeping money on reserve for restricted purposes. So I would say that almost 2/3 of the balance sheet is for reinvesting in the business and earmarked for those purposes. And the remainder, as you know, part of it is offshore and part of it is in the United States. So that's kind of give you the perspective from how we use the balance sheet. Regarding the philosophy and the strategy, I think that remains unchanged. If you look at our history, this quarter's payout ratio is kind of indicative of our long-term history, and I think that's proved to be very beneficial to shareholders over the last four years. I made this comment last quarter, but I'll just reiterate it. Over the last four years, we’ve generated over $1 billion of cash, kept debt stable, and we've reduced the shareholder accounts significantly by about 12%, I think over the last four years. So we continue to be cognizant of returning and providing value to shareholders. And the other two comments I'd make is the markets do turn, so it's good to have a strong balance sheet. We saw that through the financial crisis and not only from a financial point of view but also from a client point of view. We found that to be -- the fact that we have a strong balance sheet to be one of the factors that we were able to retain and attract clients during that period.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just around margins and, again, relative to your commentary that this particular quarter may have been a bit strong. If you adjust for the number of one timers you called out in the pre-recorded call and take into consideration your guidance for this upco
componenttext: Just around margins and, again, relative to your commentary that this particular quarter may have been a bit strong. If you adjust for the number of one timers you called out in the pre-recorded call and take into consideration your guidance for this upcoming quarter, notwithstanding some of the day count issue, but your margins are generally running above average for the industry. To the extent that the volumes would continue to grow, whether it be market or new business, would you let the margin run at this point in time? Or do you need another step function of investment spending beyond your guidance?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we've said this before too. Looking at the short-term margin, we feel it's not the best approach to running the business. And so I guess, in that sense, if the markets took off faster than our planned spending, you would see some expansion in the ma
componenttext: Well, we've said this before too. Looking at the short-term margin, we feel it's not the best approach to running the business. And so I guess, in that sense, if the markets took off faster than our planned spending, you would see some expansion in the margin. Having said that, I have in my pre-recorded comments mentioned that we do think the spending will increase, not a function of the margin itself, but a function of our strategic plans. And I can say that most of the business units are under budget, so far in this fiscal year, so that's why I thought it was prudent to put some guidance out there on the spending levels.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: So the quarterly number you gave for the first quarter there could be a step function beyond that as we get into the calendar second quarter of '11?
componenttext: So the quarterly number you gave for the first quarter there could be a step function beyond that as we get into the calendar second quarter of '11?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just think -- I would say my guidance was for the next few quarters.
componenttext: I just think -- I would say my guidance was for the next few quarters.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, kind of just given the shift away from fixed income products more broadly these days. Can you just talk about maybe some of the reasons why you think flows into the Global Bond Fund will continue to hold up whether it’s kind of the Fund’s geogr
componenttext: First, kind of just given the shift away from fixed income products more broadly these days. Can you just talk about maybe some of the reasons why you think flows into the Global Bond Fund will continue to hold up whether it’s kind of the Fund’s geographic diversification, its performance, maybe rising demand on the institutional side? Any color there would be helpful.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's probably a little bit of all the above. I mean, we tend to categorize global bonds and look at them like your typical U.S. fixed income fund, but they are different. And I kind of put them in the alternatives category in a sense. I mean
componenttext: Well, I think it's probably a little bit of all the above. I mean, we tend to categorize global bonds and look at them like your typical U.S. fixed income fund, but they are different. And I kind of put them in the alternatives category in a sense. I mean, it's a new category for retail. We talked about it on prior calls about -- it has very small percentage coming from basically nothing to now being a part of a lot of retail portfolio. So it's a nice way to diversify. I mean, the records and you look at the last decade, how well they've done. And obviously, the currencies play a big part in that. And also I think just around the globe, the consensus of people worrying about their own currencies and a nice way to diversify your purchasing power. It really is a new asset class for the retail investor. Now with that said, I mean any time rates back up, you're going to have some pressure from rising rates and just the value of the portfolio, but it's just not your typical fixed income fund as far as rate sensitivity, and our fund has a fairly low duration relative to other ones anyway. So it's really more about how well you manage the currencies versus how much interest rates are going to affect that. And as long as you do that well, I think you'll continue to see very strong flows.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just second, I know you made the investment in Pelagos last quarter. And I guess, maybe you're looking at setting up hedge fund capabilities in Asia. But more broadly, how are you thinking about continuing to build out alternatives, capabilities
componenttext: And then just second, I know you made the investment in Pelagos last quarter. And I guess, maybe you're looking at setting up hedge fund capabilities in Asia. But more broadly, how are you thinking about continuing to build out alternatives, capabilities in terms of growing it organically versus acquisitions? And then what sorts of products or strategies are you more focused on?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as we've stated before, I mean it is a priority for the company. We recognize both on the institutional side, as well as retail, a growing appetite. We think it's a natural extension of what we do. We're a little bit hesitant about just goin
componenttext: Well, I think as we've stated before, I mean it is a priority for the company. We recognize both on the institutional side, as well as retail, a growing appetite. We think it's a natural extension of what we do. We're a little bit hesitant about just going out and purchasing large hedge funds or alternative managers just because we think it's hard to have a consistent repeatable process where you can put different players into that like you can with a retail mutual fund process. So I think we're going to continue to be open to look at everything. A situation like a Pelagos is really more of a startup type for us to dip our toes into the managed future derivatives, hedge fund replication and then build that into our solutions area. The solutions area is another area whether it's outcome-oriented or targeted-type retirement plans that we will continue to build capabilities and have, as I've mentioned before, tactical asset allocation fund, hard asset funds, funds that we think can do well in a rising rate environment and funds that can utilize investments even outside of our own group, but the majority of them will be within our own group. So we'll continue to build that, but we're going to do it thoughtfully. And we've got no goal that says we have to be X size in a certain period. We just want to make sure that it fits within our organization.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Roger Freeman from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Roger Freeman from Barclays Capital.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess, could you -- there was some commentary, I think, it came over the prepared remarks or the press release about strategic projects recently approved, increasing spending around that and obviously, you just talked a little bit about it. I guess, two
componenttext: I guess, could you -- there was some commentary, I think, it came over the prepared remarks or the press release about strategic projects recently approved, increasing spending around that and obviously, you just talked a little bit about it. I guess, two things there. One is, we're also looking at your proxy. I think you laid out some minimum margin requirements to get sort of full payout against those and they seem fairly low. I think it was a little over 30%. Is that kind of going back to -- I think Bill's question. Is that indicative of where spending could go that those margins could get down to those levels? And can you talk about what some of those projects are?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Ken. Yes, I guess, I want to start by re-emphasizing how we run the business. I mean, it's very much an assessment of the market environment, assessment of our strengths and where we want to focus on the next three to five years. Of course,
componenttext: Sure. This is Ken. Yes, I guess, I want to start by re-emphasizing how we run the business. I mean, it's very much an assessment of the market environment, assessment of our strengths and where we want to focus on the next three to five years. Of course, we've backed that down into an annual process. And so much of the revenue is driven by the market that it's just, we think, not the best way to run the business to focus on short-term margins. And so regarding the strategic projects, my comments were directed specifically to technology projects. And I guess, the question is, you're trying to get an order of magnitude of what spending is on IT and others. I don't think that it's the order of magnitude that would take the margin down to that 32% level in the short term. We're not thinking about that. It's just enhancing our systems, improving our customer service functions and expanding globally, more in line with the spending progress you've seen in 2010, I'd say.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your core Domestic Equities business, you've been running this vision campaign. You think you're positioned well to get market share improvements as flows come back into equities. You've given us some stats in the past about the number of advisors that so
componenttext: Your core Domestic Equities business, you've been running this vision campaign. You think you're positioned well to get market share improvements as flows come back into equities. You've given us some stats in the past about the number of advisors that sold Franklin funds for the first time. Can you kind of update us on maybe this past quarter, maybe over the past 12 months, what that spending and what the mix has been? I mean, is that equities predominantly?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think for us -- looking at the 20-20 vision campaign and our focus on U.S. equities, we feel like we continue to make very good progress there. And two of our funds, the Franklin Rising Dividend Fund and the Franklin Growth Fund, have really taken
componenttext: Yes, I think for us -- looking at the 20-20 vision campaign and our focus on U.S. equities, we feel like we continue to make very good progress there. And two of our funds, the Franklin Rising Dividend Fund and the Franklin Growth Fund, have really taken off as far as sales and continue to grow in terms of market share in non-proprietary channel. We've also been very successful in getting them on DCIO platforms, and that is going to be very important in all markets to kind of keep generating consistent sales. And that's an area where I would say, historically we've been under weighted on the U.S. equity side, but we do have some funds that are doing very well and are getting a whole new audience. I don't have all of the numbers in front of me, but if you look at the Franklin Equity Group as a whole, we talk about top two quartiles. But if you look at the first quartile overall performance, it's 77% in the three year, 73% in the five year and close to 80% in the 10 year of those assets and about 70% in the one year in the first quartile. So you really have excellent long-term performance with that group at the right time with the marketing campaign, and we are seeing significant market share improvements there, as well as significant net inflows into those funds.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Michael Carrier from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question comes from Michael Carrier from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: You gave one stat this quarter just on the muni side in terms of money leaving muni funds and you guys being able to capture roughly 50% of that. I guess, if you look over time, when you've had these shifts, whether it's in and out of equities, maybe inte
componenttext: You gave one stat this quarter just on the muni side in terms of money leaving muni funds and you guys being able to capture roughly 50% of that. I guess, if you look over time, when you've had these shifts, whether it's in and out of equities, maybe international or domestic or vice versa or past cycles with fixed income in equities. Do you have any other I guess like longer-term stats across cycles that you could give? Because I think that's one of the concerns and everyone thinks that you guys have the good distribution, particularly in the advisory channels. So those types of stats I think is what the positive expectation could be, and if you just had any more details, it would be helpful so we can kind of get our hands around that.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's hard. I mean, I think every market's a little bit different as far as what's working and what's not. And I think just looking at the diversification we have by asset class and by geography, I think is really unparalleled in the industry
componenttext: Well, I think it's hard. I mean, I think every market's a little bit different as far as what's working and what's not. And I think just looking at the diversification we have by asset class and by geography, I think is really unparalleled in the industry. I look at the muni world and, of course, we felt like this noise was coming. I mean we talked a lot about it internally, tried to get people ready, but the muni market is a retail-driven market. It tends to be a lot more volatile because of that. And when you have the headline risk and some of the -- I think just confusion around the possibility of state bankruptcies and things, that you get an oversold market. But I think the good news about munis is, I think they -- like most fixed income markets, the yields can get attractive to new buyers and you do have crossover buyers coming in and when those yields get above treasuries, and I think some of the better information gets out about the possibility of state bankruptcies that, that issue will settle down and I think the market will come back. And already, in the last week or two, you've seen the market settling down a bit and hopefully that's a trend. But like everyone, we know these budget fights happen in the political arena, you're going to have a lot of volatility in the year or two ahead. But as far as how much you can keep and how much is working, I mean, it’s just, I think, too hard to generalize based on past trends.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just in the Equity business, both on the domestic side and international. You had flows in both those buckets. I guess, any detour or any color on the products that are gaining traction. And then you just mentioned on the recorded call that you h
componenttext: And then just in the Equity business, both on the domestic side and international. You had flows in both those buckets. I guess, any detour or any color on the products that are gaining traction. And then you just mentioned on the recorded call that you had a pickup in some redemptions, even though you had record sales, so do you have any color on that as well?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the offshore, the Asia Growth Fund continues to be very popular. We had $2.3 billion in net inflows in the quarter versus about $1 billion last quarter. Our China Fund as well, offshore was a top seller, and Global Discovery had good inflows
componenttext: Well, I think the offshore, the Asia Growth Fund continues to be very popular. We had $2.3 billion in net inflows in the quarter versus about $1 billion last quarter. Our China Fund as well, offshore was a top seller, and Global Discovery had good inflows. Our Eastern European hot fund had good inflows. So yes, I think the strength outside of the U.S. obviously is more in the global funds and more of the global sector funds. And in the U.S., the two funds that I mentioned, the big sellers were the Rising Dividend and the Growth Fund for U.S. funds.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Jeff Hopson from Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: The next question comes from Jeff Hopson from Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Back on the muni exchanges, is that something you're doing proactively to try to retain those, or is that just a natural consequence of having better brand awareness with the financial advisors? And then secondarily, I know that the U.K. had been somethin
componenttext: Back on the muni exchanges, is that something you're doing proactively to try to retain those, or is that just a natural consequence of having better brand awareness with the financial advisors? And then secondarily, I know that the U.K. had been something that you wanted to fill over time. As we think strategically around the globe going forward, where could be potential areas that you feel like you need to be in either where you're not in or you need to be bigger in those particular markets?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll start with the second part. The U.K. is just a, for us, a nice kind of fit where we get a group with long-term record and we can immediately try to leverage that through our sales relationships. And even we're optimistic that we can take that group a
componenttext: I'll start with the second part. The U.K. is just a, for us, a nice kind of fit where we get a group with long-term record and we can immediately try to leverage that through our sales relationships. And even we're optimistic that we can take that group and introduce them to some large distributors that we have global relationships with fairly quickly. Now I think the other market that we mentioned would be Australia, which is one that we've looked at some opportunities there and will probably continue to do so, just with the superannuation and the importance of having local Australian equity management there. Outside that, I don't think there's any major markets. I mean you could look at Japan as one, but probably not high in our list. We do have a domestic equity capability there now. The question around munis, and are we proactive? The answer is, no. As far as going out and trying to retain, that's probably a normal number for most fixed income funds where they would move somewhere else if somebody had a short-term concern on the market. And I think it goes to the strength of broker-dealers’ sold funds and where they pay a commission and go into the fund family. And if you have a well-diversified fund family, you will retain a lot of those assets because those people are in it to buy munis. That's what they want. But there may be a period where they want to shift out for a time frame and having a strong fund family allows you to do that, and also having paid a commission, they're not going to just jump out and move into something else because that wouldn't be appropriate. So I think the broker-dealer side, you do end up retaining more than you would on the direct side.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

componenttext: Well, I think it's really any of the shorter duration bond funds. We saw a pickup in the floating rate fund, which if somebody thought rates are going to go up, obviously that's a good place to go in the short term, and money funds as well.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then on the Global Bond Fund, it has predominantly I think been a retail product to date. And can you give us a sense of the current breakdown there of the mix within that fund generally, and what the appetite is on the institutional side for that pro
componenttext: And then on the Global Bond Fund, it has predominantly I think been a retail product to date. And can you give us a sense of the current breakdown there of the mix within that fund generally, and what the appetite is on the institutional side for that product today, maybe with regards to RFP or kind of sales cycle, where it fits?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: It is predominantly retail. I don't have the exact percentage, but it's the dominant 90% plus of the assets. And again, as I stated, I think the institutional side is more a global lag. It's not a specific sovereign debt category for the institutional mar
componenttext: It is predominantly retail. I don't have the exact percentage, but it's the dominant 90% plus of the assets. And again, as I stated, I think the institutional side is more a global lag. It's not a specific sovereign debt category for the institutional marketplace, and that's an area where in the last year, two, three, we continue to build good momentum and still have a very good pipeline. I'd put that right up there with our top-selling category and much of that continues to be because of the strength overall of that team and the success on the Global Bond Fund that we're able to leverage into global lag, as well as emerging markets debt.

componenttext: In terms of the new disclosure, you've collapsed some line items and made things a little bit more opaque. Any chance we can get disclosure on what the underwriting and distribution expense would be under the old reporting structure? Or any chance that will be available in the Qs?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The answer is yes to both. So before we put the earnings release out we issued the 8-K showing the changes historically. Hopefully that could help update all the models. And certainly, in the Q, we're going to break out the expense line item to show which
componenttext: The answer is yes to both. So before we put the earnings release out we issued the 8-K showing the changes historically. Hopefully that could help update all the models. And certainly, in the Q, we're going to break out the expense line item to show which component of the expense is more or less sales-based, which component is more related to assets under management, and then we'll show the amortization of the first commissions. And the Q should be out very soon.

componenttext: Well, I think we're working on it. We want to make sure that, that's part of the reason we came in with a 20% stake and want to understand exactly how derivatives fit into a 40-act [ph] type retail product. And so we'll take our time there and try to figure out where it fits. So I would imagine something in the next 12 months, we would expect but there really is no direct timetable to introduce those capabilities in our funds right now.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you’ll continue to see some modest increase in headcounts going forward. Like I said, most of the business units are under budget, so I'd expect the hiring to pick up. Maybe a little background on the change in headcount this quarter. I think th
componenttext: I think you’ll continue to see some modest increase in headcounts going forward. Like I said, most of the business units are under budget, so I'd expect the hiring to pick up. Maybe a little background on the change in headcount this quarter. I think there were 60 to 65 with the net change. Most of that was in portfolio and portfolio support functions, sales and technology, and about a third of that were in low-cost jurisdictions. So I would expect the capacity headcount to be in those areas and in that geography. So I would expect a little bit of increase in headcount going forward.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Given that predominately dominant U.S. retail franchise, curious on what your thoughts are or aspirations are for making a bigger push. I know some people are concerned that higher rates bring changes in allocations. I actually think higher rates, there
componenttext: Given that predominately dominant U.S. retail franchise, curious on what your thoughts are or aspirations are for making a bigger push. I know some people are concerned that higher rates bring changes in allocations. I actually think higher rates, there’s a lot of institutions around the world that would love to invest at a higher yield. So just curious on your thoughts on growing the institutional fixed income footprint in the U.S. over time.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, that's been a big push of ours, and I think we continue to build out the capabilities there and we have a very strong team and I would agree. And I think that fixed income tends to rebound a lot faster in bear markets than equities do because of tha
componenttext: Well, that's been a big push of ours, and I think we continue to build out the capabilities there and we have a very strong team and I would agree. And I think that fixed income tends to rebound a lot faster in bear markets than equities do because of that current yield. And you're right, you do attract new buyers that come in and all of a sudden say, hey I can get X percent on a muni or on a government and that will attract a new buyer. And once rates settle down, that's true, you will come back a little bit faster.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And what does it take -- in other words, it feels like a lot of the infrastructure is there. Clearly you have great management skills. Can you do side-by-side? Can the same managers manage the funds? And is it more of the marketing effort to get into the
componenttext: And what does it take -- in other words, it feels like a lot of the infrastructure is there. Clearly you have great management skills. Can you do side-by-side? Can the same managers manage the funds? And is it more of the marketing effort to get into the consultants and that just is a longer sales process?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the answer is yes to both. You can do side-by-side. That's what we do, and we have been building very good relationships with the consultants and continue to see very significant separate accounts come in, in the last quarter or two of our l
componenttext: Well, I think the answer is yes to both. You can do side-by-side. That's what we do, and we have been building very good relationships with the consultants and continue to see very significant separate accounts come in, in the last quarter or two of our largest separate accounts for global lag, so it's working.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greg, you mentioned toward the end of the pre-recorded call that you would expect to shift back to equities, but flows may be a little bit more drawn out and may be less than prior cycles. Maybe you could expand on that a little bit. It seems to be a litt
componenttext: Greg, you mentioned toward the end of the pre-recorded call that you would expect to shift back to equities, but flows may be a little bit more drawn out and may be less than prior cycles. Maybe you could expand on that a little bit. It seems to be a little bit more conservative than what some of your peers have been saying over the last couple of days. So is that your view? Is that your view on top of your relationship with the distributors in getting feedback that way? Maybe just a little more qualitative discussion around that will be helpful.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's my view that I think you have to take into account the demographics of an aging population and how that shifts. And I think the -- probably the severe equity sell-off probably accelerated that shift a little bit. I think the other part
componenttext: Well, I think it's my view that I think you have to take into account the demographics of an aging population and how that shifts. And I think the -- probably the severe equity sell-off probably accelerated that shift a little bit. I think the other part of it is, if you look at the marketplace today and we look at our – where we're successful in the U.S. equity side and funds like the Rising Dividend Fund or a Hybrid Franklin Income Fund or a Franklin Growth Fund, that tend to be a little bit viewed more conservatively managed, less volatile versus your traditional growth momentum fund. I think part of it is the advisor gravitating towards that instead of what used to be a momentum or even a large-cap growth. So I just think there's some shifts there that it's just very powerful when people are getting older and they're not going to want to take the risk that they were taking before and that's not true in every country, but I think that's the case I would make in the States. And you also had an incredible run-up of equities during that period. And I just think it's going to take time and you're probably not going to get back to those kind of flows.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greg, when I look at the net flow trends and equity just on their face and obviously U.S. equity fund flows picking up and then looks like some deceleration in global. Is there anything from a tactical perspective that you're seeing from the retail channe
componenttext: Greg, when I look at the net flow trends and equity just on their face and obviously U.S. equity fund flows picking up and then looks like some deceleration in global. Is there anything from a tactical perspective that you're seeing from the retail channel across the globe that suggests that maybe there's a little bit of more demand for U.S. over global at this point in time from at least a tactical perspective?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I mean I don't think we're seeing that. I think for us, our performance has been better on some of the U.S. funds in the near term. And if you look at our big global funds, they have a value bias value. Value has underperformed growth here for the las
componenttext: No, I mean I don't think we're seeing that. I think for us, our performance has been better on some of the U.S. funds in the near term. And if you look at our big global funds, they have a value bias value. Value has underperformed growth here for the last couple of years. And Mutual Series is more defensive in nature and has higher cash levels, and Templeton has been under weighted material through the last few years. So I think that’s hurt the shorter-term performance for some of our core global funds. And as you would expect, we're not doing as well there as we would like to be.

componenttext: Just in terms of the Global Bond Fund and sort of a macro comment around sort of relative yields globally. componenttext: Well, I think it just depends on people's individual view. I'm just curious if there was any sort of shift in currency exposure mix within fixed income asset classes broadly, geographies, anything?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's always shifts. I don't think there was a dramatic shift. And I think we talk about short-term underperformance because we expect it in that fund in any given time when how quickly the euro can move on some headlines and that's going
componenttext: Well, I think there's always shifts. I don't think there was a dramatic shift. And I think we talk about short-term underperformance because we expect it in that fund in any given time when how quickly the euro can move on some headlines and that's going to affect. Hopefully, we get the longer-term trends right, and that's what we've done. But there's always going to be periods where we have short-term underperformance with that kind of fund.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then in the muni funds, I think in your presentation you showed the one-year Lipper rankings, which had fallen off considerably and obviously everybody’s faced the pressures of muni fund investing. Is yours just a function of a higher California mun
componenttext: And then in the muni funds, I think in your presentation you showed the one-year Lipper rankings, which had fallen off considerably and obviously everybody’s faced the pressures of muni fund investing. Is yours just a function of a higher California muni exposure?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, actually -- I mean, the California funds are doing -- I think it was second quartile for the one year through the end of the year. It's really duration. I mean our muni funds are run for current income, as well as total return. And so at any time when
componenttext: No, actually -- I mean, the California funds are doing -- I think it was second quartile for the one year through the end of the year. It's really duration. I mean our muni funds are run for current income, as well as total return. And so at any time when interest rates are backing up, we will underperform in the short run. I mean it's as simple as that. We think people buy munis for the higher yield, along with the stability of principal, that's how we manage the funds. So again, depending on what rates are doing, we generally will underperform and that's been the key driver, not the quality of the portfolio. It's been really the duration.

componenttext: No, no change really, we're still wait and see attitude on there.

componenttext: And I think it would be our intention to -- like we did last time, we were able to bring back those dollars where they're more flexible here as far as buying X stock and paying dividends. It will be our intention to bring most of it back.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon and welcome to Franklin Resources Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call for the Quarter Ended March 31, 2011. My name is Christine and I will be your conference operator today. Please note that the financial results to be discussed in thi
componenttext: Good afternoon and welcome to Franklin Resources Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call for the Quarter Ended March 31, 2011. My name is Christine and I will be your conference operator today. Please note that the financial results to be discussed in this conference call are preliminary. Statements made in this conference call regarding Franklin Resources Inc., which are not historical facts are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the risk factors and MD&A section of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K filing. [Operator Instructions] Now, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Greg Johnson, Chief Executive Officer. You may begin.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for taking time to join us for this call. Joining me is Ken Lewis, our CFO. This morning we reported a strong quarter of operating results, sales we're an all-time high and long-term net new flows impr
componenttext: Thank you and good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for taking time to join us for this call. Joining me is Ken Lewis, our CFO. This morning we reported a strong quarter of operating results, sales we're an all-time high and long-term net new flows improved to $9 billion due to the continued strength of global bonds and the pickup of U.S. equity and Hybrid flows. We did experience some lumpy institutional redemptions during the quarter, the flow trends improved in March. That trend has continued in April and we continue to see that we're well-positioned to benefit from increased investor demand for equities and Hybrid fund. Now I'd like to open it up to your questions.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

componenttext: I guess, just to start with the flows, looking at domestic equities, $2.4 billion, net. componenttext: There really is. There's not anything lumpy to call out. I think for us, we talked about some of the efforts around DCIO platform that it was a record sales month for us there and the equity funds, especially in the U.S. few of them had record quarters as well.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

componenttext: And I guess, the follow-up, just around expenses. componenttext: Sure. I guess, just as a follow-up on the previous question too. There's also strong flows in our seek out products linear category as part of the come through symptoms.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: U.S. opportunities top selling one there. That's for equity front. Yes, it's true that in a particularly the IT, the occupancy expense came in a little under. What we were thinking is going to be that we continue to spend innovating, it should take a litt
componenttext: U.S. opportunities top selling one there. That's for equity front. Yes, it's true that in a particularly the IT, the occupancy expense came in a little under. What we were thinking is going to be that we continue to spend innovating, it should take a little bit longer for that spend to be reflected in the income statement. I guess, two reasons. One, there is a lot of projects at we're working on or capitalized. So you have to wait till its completed and then come through in depreciation expense. And two, there have been a lot of efficiencies realized in this fiscal year particularly given some strategic decisions on the technology side, for example, bringing the data center helps them. What kind of recognizing some of those fadings, sooner than we thought, so that's been maybe keeping the expense line static instead of increasing what we talked. The message is the same. I think you probably to see some, not very dramatic, but you you'll see some incremental uptick in those lines going forward.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: The next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, maybe to just of kind follow up on the domestic equity flows, can you give us some color around maybe some of the drivers behind this step up whether its performance, rising risk appetites more broadly, maybe it's related to your recent marketing e
componenttext: First, maybe to just of kind follow up on the domestic equity flows, can you give us some color around maybe some of the drivers behind this step up whether its performance, rising risk appetites more broadly, maybe it's related to your recent marketing efforts?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the answer is probably a little bit all of the above. We have felt that the performance has been very strong especially on the Franklin equity side. Franklin Growth Fund has been a long time. We just spent, for the last six months, pushing hard on
componenttext: I think the answer is probably a little bit all of the above. We have felt that the performance has been very strong especially on the Franklin equity side. Franklin Growth Fund has been a long time. We just spent, for the last six months, pushing hard on those bonds. And I think obviously the timing is right. And then I think more importantly for the longer-term trend is all of the new platforms that we've introduced those funds to in the last six months and the defining contribution tends to be a steadier place to go and that's probably where the battles won and lost as far as equity funds go. So our metric was getting them on as many platforms over the last year when equities were at a favor. Now, when you're see things come back, they were doing very well. The Franklin growth fund, the raising dividends fund, the offshore the Franklin U.S. opportunities fund, all had record quarters for that last quarter.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And in terms of margins, is it fair to say maybe margins have had peaked at least in the near term just you continue to ramp up some investment spending or do you still feel like there's some leverage in the model just assuming as its continued to trend h
componenttext: And in terms of margins, is it fair to say maybe margins have had peaked at least in the near term just you continue to ramp up some investment spending or do you still feel like there's some leverage in the model just assuming as its continued to trend higher and maybe the mix improves a little bit?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think there's some leverage in the model. Obviously, leverage puts -- time and time again, leverage is the big driver. Even the short quarter this month caused a little bit the margin compression. But we're going to continue to spend -- it's not we were
componenttext: I think there's some leverage in the model. Obviously, leverage puts -- time and time again, leverage is the big driver. Even the short quarter this month caused a little bit the margin compression. But we're going to continue to spend -- it's not we were doing it pretty thoughtfully and I think there's room for extension.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jeff Hopson from Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jeff Hopson from Stifel.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Any additional details on the $4.7 million as far as why that left. Do you know if it want to are passive? And then in terms of international equity retail, I guess, on the c-cap side, any change in kind of the products that you're selling there in the As
componenttext: Any additional details on the $4.7 million as far as why that left. Do you know if it want to are passive? And then in terms of international equity retail, I guess, on the c-cap side, any change in kind of the products that you're selling there in the Asia Pacific growth was a big seller in the previous quarter but any changes there?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think first of all the large redemption and the more performance related, and it really depends on how you view performance. If you look at Templeton and with the early value by S. If you look at them, it's all international equity funds, they were unde
componenttext: I think first of all the large redemption and the more performance related, and it really depends on how you view performance. If you look at Templeton and with the early value by S. If you look at them, it's all international equity funds, they were under performing. Now that's turned around dramatically since that decision was made by those sovereign wealth funds to switch over. I'm not sure where the money went or whether passive or they're active, but it was performance related to the Templeton lag. Now that's really over the last three months it turned around dramatically. You could see most of the Templeton funds now are in the top first or second quartile, including the three-year number that moved quickly. And at that same time, we were winning global equity mandates at the same time when that redemption was made. So I don't think you can draw any conclusion that happened. These funds tend to move moneys around a little bit quicker than fair average. When you have to do a downturn and short-term performance, you're vulnerable. As far as the global equity flows go outside of the U.S., you're right, the big driver has been Asian growth. And that trailed off during the quarter, and I think the reason there is really the backup and rates in the January effect on emerging markets and overall. Those markets underperformed the overall MSCI during the quarter, and again those tend to be more short-term performance related. Now I would think that would, they would be coming back now.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Bill Katz from Citigroup.
componenttext: The next question comes from Bill Katz from Citigroup.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

componenttext: Just wanted to give a little more detail behind the new vision, 2020 vision campaign. Can you talk a little bit about when you rolled it out, where you rolled it out geographically and is there any more opportunity to penetrate other distribution channels with any of the regions, et cetera. And quantitative feedback beyond the 80,000 certificates you guys sent out so far.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're onto the next phase of that campaign. And it was really designed just to give advisers tools to deal with, the move towards fixed income and how much pressure there was to redeem equities and whether it was our fund or somebody else's,
componenttext: Well, I think we're onto the next phase of that campaign. And it was really designed just to give advisers tools to deal with, the move towards fixed income and how much pressure there was to redeem equities and whether it was our fund or somebody else's, we just want to create more value in relationship by having those tools out there and try to come in and follow up with the Franklin fund. Right now, the push in marketing is global, is a new core. And it doesn't mean we're forgetting about U.S. but all the tests and surveys that we've done in trends indicate that there'll be more moving to Global Equities. People are still underway and we wanted to change the thinking. Because again, I think that's advantageous to us with our overall mix to have Global Equities represent a larger base than individual investors' portfolio.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are there any question, are they any opportunities to sort of broaden out that marketing campaign that could add another way of growth on top of what you're doing right now?
componenttext: Are there any question, are they any opportunities to sort of broaden out that marketing campaign that could add another way of growth on top of what you're doing right now?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, hopefully. As I said before, I think the equity push is something that -- we're getting to a new audience. We still think there's a lot of opportunity on the retirement side to get into more plans and as long as performance stays solid there, there
componenttext: Well, hopefully. As I said before, I think the equity push is something that -- we're getting to a new audience. We still think there's a lot of opportunity on the retirement side to get into more plans and as long as performance stays solid there, there is no reason why we can't expand into new markets. And the bigger question is how much global equity expand. And again, you could talk about this looking at each country, because each country has its own biased to their home investing. Some higher than others, and we're really approaching it on a regional and country-by-country basis. So we are rolling it out across the globe.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And so my follow-up question is come back to Martin through a different way. I think your tax rate is a little bit lower to what people are anticipating. I think that's the mix shift that's underway. I think I asked this question I apologize in advise. Wh
componenttext: And so my follow-up question is come back to Martin through a different way. I think your tax rate is a little bit lower to what people are anticipating. I think that's the mix shift that's underway. I think I asked this question I apologize in advise. When you think about the profitability by geography, don't want to ask question but is non-U.S. business at this point in time, I know you have some but it's not U.S. innately more positive or equal in terms of the profit contribution?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Non-U.S., U.S. are approximately even. If you put over the layers, the none-U.S. there are pockets that are more profitable than the synergy U.S. products but there are also pockets that are not. And maybe they're not because we just may be getting starte
componenttext: Non-U.S., U.S. are approximately even. If you put over the layers, the none-U.S. there are pockets that are more profitable than the synergy U.S. products but there are also pockets that are not. And maybe they're not because we just may be getting started in there or the products may be small. So they blend out to the point I can make a statement that non-U. S., U.S. is about the same profitability today. Just maybe if I can touch on the tax rate and the mix question, sure, part of it was due to the assets that are managed out of low-texture like Singapore, Hong Kong and the Bahamas. But also some of it was portfolio related. You can see on that slide we did that new chart that shows you we had some gains, a lot of those gains were outside the U.S. so that changes the earnings mix too.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

componenttext: The next question comes from Michael Carrier from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

componenttext: Just given the longer redemption in this quarter than in the last quarter, I think was in Hybrid. Can you give us any color just on the institutional pipeline and maybe do you have some of the out but what's coming in and where is the interest?

componenttextpreview: Well, I think the pipeline looks good. We don't really don't talk about trend there, put up any numbers where you'd do guess work, if any lumpy things are coming in or not or going out. I think the feeling is the trends that are again, we talked about the
componenttext: Well, I think the pipeline looks good. We don't really don't talk about trend there, put up any numbers where you'd do guess work, if any lumpy things are coming in or not or going out. I think the feeling is the trends that are again, we talked about the quarters around global equities and whether it's lower duration, emerging market bonds are all very much in place and are very active and healthy pipeline for us. So hopefully we'll see some good numbers coming in there next quarter.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then on the retail side, it looks like you've definitely seen a pickup in the domestic equity side and the Hybrid. And then just in terms of interest levels, I guess it makes sense. You haven't seen the pick up on the international equity but it looks
componenttext: And then on the retail side, it looks like you've definitely seen a pickup in the domestic equity side and the Hybrid. And then just in terms of interest levels, I guess it makes sense. You haven't seen the pick up on the international equity but it looks like there's a focus on the marketing new campaign and then I guess, any update on the Muni side in terms of any increased interest from the advisers, or from the retail client?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think munis said will continue to be difficult. I think they're under pressure everyday in the headlines and you certainly have some strategic buyers that come into the market but just overall retail buyer that is the dominant player in that marke
componenttext: Well, I think munis said will continue to be difficult. I think they're under pressure everyday in the headlines and you certainly have some strategic buyers that come into the market but just overall retail buyer that is the dominant player in that marketplace. It's going to react what they read about what read about in headlines. And I think the bigger part was the they concern that rates are going up and taxes are staying down and not going up quickly. And I think those two on a less liquid market had a pretty dramatic impact, coupled with the headlines, it's hard to separate out what effect the most. But the bottom line is, we don't see that turning around quickly. It's better performance has been better. It was positive overall for munis. So that's positive and whether it settles down, and I think it should but we still run that risk of headlines everyday and budgets being battle and that's just going to put headwinds into muni flows. International equity, the issue, the core strength of our franchise around Franklin, around the Templeton side has a little bit larger cap value bias and less energy immaterial waiting. It was relative performance, not good news today as the dollars' been weak, they don't hedge anything. The move in the last quarter into Europe and other places where they've been overweighted that's hurt performance has helped performance here and helped it dramatically. So that's turned around quickly. It's hard to sell for your third and fourth quartile but now that we're back in the first and second, hopefully we can see some turn around there quickly on the retail side. And mutuals been steady and positive and mutual European and mutual discovery continue to be steady as far as inflows go. And again hopefully that will continue

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ken Worthington from JP Morgan.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ken Worthington from JP Morgan.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the something global bond and the international bond franchise, I know you've talked about no capacity issues there. Are you getting any sense of either owner fatigue or buyer fatigue. At some performance remains really good but net sales peaked last y
componenttext: On the something global bond and the international bond franchise, I know you've talked about no capacity issues there. Are you getting any sense of either owner fatigue or buyer fatigue. At some performance remains really good but net sales peaked last year in kind of the March and June quarters and the gross redemption seems to be creeping higher. Just any sense of fatigue and do you think sales number kind of stabilize here or do you think they continue to decline from very strong levels?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think, as we said, even at the height that it's very hard to maintain those kind of flow numbers, and you have the natural the funds growing and aging and you're going to have redemption that weren't in there before, just based on the average life of an
componenttext: I think, as we said, even at the height that it's very hard to maintain those kind of flow numbers, and you have the natural the funds growing and aging and you're going to have redemption that weren't in there before, just based on the average life of an investment. So that puts pressure on the overall net number. But I'd looked at the story to me is the strength of the global total return fund and how quickly it has grown in $2.5 billion of net inflows under that fund the last quarter. So while you could argue maybe the global bond has slowed a little bit but you can certainly say the global bond will return has become very meaningful and that's even a bigger market than the global bond. Because it's not only have sovereign debt but has corporate bonds in there. And that's had excellent performance and we'll continue to see strong interest there. I think, again, any country that's concerned about their currency whether it's U.S. or the Euro are going to be very interested in global bonds and that's certainly getting more headlines I would argue today than ever. I'm still pretty optimistic on flows there.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

componenttext: And then as a follow-up, can you give us a little more information on the SICAV products. What are the asset levels that you have in those funds at this point. And if you can, what were the SICAV sales for the quarter?

componenttext: Maybe just a start a follow-up on the 2020 campaign question. When I look at equity funds that you flag for emphasis in the campaign Templeton growth is a standout year-to-date but most of the others are lagging this year, and I'm just wondering if that kind of short-term performance, part from their long-term records, but does that kind of short-term performance influence the sales or should we assume that particularly in DC it's really more important to get on the menu. And then it's demand for that particular asset class.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that's exactly right. I think that's why it's so important to get on those platforms, to get the steadier flows and not be vulnerable to short-term swings, which are more discretionary on buying the latest invest as far as the 1, 3 and 5. So you'r
componenttext: I think that's exactly right. I think that's why it's so important to get on those platforms, to get the steadier flows and not be vulnerable to short-term swings, which are more discretionary on buying the latest invest as far as the 1, 3 and 5. So you're right, there's some slight under performance in the near term for a couple of those funds. It's probably will have I think some effect. So again that's why it's so important for us to get on the retirement platforms where you are less vulnerable and it's more of that 3 and 5-year numbers than it is the 6 months and 1 year.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I just had a modeling question, which is -- I just wanted to clarify something you mentioned during a pre-recorded commentary, you were talking about the drivers for distribution revenues and expenses and it seemed like the biggest driver f
componenttext: Okay. And then I just had a modeling question, which is -- I just wanted to clarify something you mentioned during a pre-recorded commentary, you were talking about the drivers for distribution revenues and expenses and it seemed like the biggest driver for both has changed in asset. But the impact seems to be really different for revenues compared to expenses. It had a bigger impact on expenses and so they rose faster. I'm just wondering if that's something specific for the quarter or in modeling ahead, should we assume that assets go up X percent and it should have a similar impact?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

componenttext: I think maybe one of the things to focus on is the mix of international and U.S. in that equation. Because on the expense side, you're going to have expenses, distribution expenses related to both the international products as well as the U.S. products. But on the revenue side, it's essentially are mostly just the U.S. products.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow-up, obviously, there's a tremendous secular story on the international, both equity and debt. Can you guys put any color on just how much this sustained dollar weakness is maybe enhancing that. And is that a rich pocket, is that what
componenttext: Just wanted to follow-up, obviously, there's a tremendous secular story on the international, both equity and debt. Can you guys put any color on just how much this sustained dollar weakness is maybe enhancing that. And is that a rich pocket, is that what a reverse at all, just a little bit? Or is it really just a driver in this secular trend with better growth dynamics?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's no question we're getting the benefit of the weak dollar and the trend towards investing more offshore. The question there, what happens when it goes the other way? And we've had it go the other way, and that will hurt performance an
componenttext: Well, I think there's no question we're getting the benefit of the weak dollar and the trend towards investing more offshore. The question there, what happens when it goes the other way? And we've had it go the other way, and that will hurt performance and some fronts and help others depending on hedging strategies. And our global bond fund, it doesn't necessarily invest against the dollar all the time so basically like it's going too far again. They have the flexibility to move the other way too. So for us, obviously, probably everything held equal, it's a net-net benefit. Not sure what you can do as an entity to hedge yourself against that should it go the other way. But we've been through periods like that before and it's just needs certain funds will be out of favor.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just to follow up. I just read a couple of pieces talking about how internationally there's some new potential law changes that will provide more disclosure around commissions and things of that nature, I think in Taiwan, maybe in the U.K. How ar
componenttext: And then just to follow up. I just read a couple of pieces talking about how internationally there's some new potential law changes that will provide more disclosure around commissions and things of that nature, I think in Taiwan, maybe in the U.K. How are you guys thinking through that. And will that have any impact on how you sell stuff on is it sort of just more a procedural and not really a change that you're guys are going to sell products.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think I would've just dismiss those kinds of issues. I think they just depends shapes and form and you can have drastic moves like it was done in the India market where they did away with it. And sales charge and whether or not that changes over time I
componenttext: I think I would've just dismiss those kinds of issues. I think they just depends shapes and form and you can have drastic moves like it was done in the India market where they did away with it. And sales charge and whether or not that changes over time I think time will tell. So I think you have to work with the regulators and hopefully come up with some form of disclosure and transparency that works for everyone. But I don't think there's anything in those two markets that immediately we would be a cause for concern for us right now.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

componenttext: The next question comes from Marc Irizarry from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greg, when you think about building the global to local business outside the U.S., I know the markets pretty it is idiosyncratic but can you talk about where you're seeing the best share gains locally and where you're not sort of gaining momentum. What ar
componenttext: Greg, when you think about building the global to local business outside the U.S., I know the markets pretty it is idiosyncratic but can you talk about where you're seeing the best share gains locally and where you're not sort of gaining momentum. What are some of the impediments to gaining share there and then a follow.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it's generally, it will come down to your relative performance and just like in any market, what's selling. I think for us in the local asset management side, we picked up good share in India and a lot of that's been around just developing fixed inc
componenttext: Well, it's generally, it will come down to your relative performance and just like in any market, what's selling. I think for us in the local asset management side, we picked up good share in India and a lot of that's been around just developing fixed income funds, have done well in that market. Korea on the other one has been a tough market and even though the equity markets been up, equity flows in general there have not been very strong. So it's been more institutional for us than retail. But really, that's the two that probably standout in my mind as far as one or the other. And a lot of the other one, whether it's China with the JV, it still create potential profitable  but probably a longer-term venture and one that you don't own more than 50%.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And when you think about your strong capital position that you're in and the decent amount of cash overseas. How do you think about making acquisitions to sort of bolster your market position in some of those local markets?
componenttext: And when you think about your strong capital position that you're in and the decent amount of cash overseas. How do you think about making acquisitions to sort of bolster your market position in some of those local markets?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the fact that we do have a lot of cash overseas and the fact that that's where we're growing it's a bias towards -- I think we're going to do an acquisition, all things being equal, to give us the bias internationally.
componenttext: I think the fact that we do have a lot of cash overseas and the fact that that's where we're growing it's a bias towards -- I think we're going to do an acquisition, all things being equal, to give us the bias internationally.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the other point is we are in more of these markets than most firms that are looking to get into them. So for us, require firm and combine it there's a strategic premium built in the multiples for people that are trying to get in. China, India mark
componenttext: I think the other point is we are in more of these markets than most firms that are looking to get into them. So for us, require firm and combine it there's a strategic premium built in the multiples for people that are trying to get in. China, India marks that we've been in for a while. So that kind of precludes us from paying them. And that's how we think about it as well. Unless it was really an entirely new type of fund management that we didn't have enough market, then you could rationalize doing it. But you you're not going to have a lot of opportunities to grow scale and put these two together and make it accretive with some of the points of entry and what people are paying to get in. So I think that's a little bit of a constraint in a lot of markets where we've seen some deals done.

componenttextpreview: You guys have a pretty good track record of launching new products. You got international equities and obviously the level bonds. Just wondering, on a go-forward basis where you think organically, if you were looking at new product suites, where they migh
componenttext: You guys have a pretty good track record of launching new products. You got international equities and obviously the level bonds. Just wondering, on a go-forward basis where you think organically, if you were looking at new product suites, where they might reside?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Really, I would say the area with the greatest opportunity to be around taxable asset allocation, real asset-type funds, funds that will be a little bit more defensive in a rising rate environment. So that's really where we built our solutions capability.
componenttext: Really, I would say the area with the greatest opportunity to be around taxable asset allocation, real asset-type funds, funds that will be a little bit more defensive in a rising rate environment. So that's really where we built our solutions capability. It made a lot of hires in the last couple of years and that's why we're going to see 4 or 5 new funds over the next year or so.

componenttext: No. I said there was nothing that stood out as being lumpy. I said that we don't comment on lumpy post-March 31 as far as our comments go. And Hybrid is obviously been very attractive. componenttext: Apologies if you covered this already. But I think in the pre-recorded commentary you talked about how investment gains have been up lately because you're reallocating capital investments and rebalancing corporate investment. I'm just wondering if you can give a little color on what changes you're making and why. Whether those gains and losses will stay elevated for a few more quarters?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I think they're were unusually higher in the last couple of quarters. Because the way they characterize. I'm not -- it's kind of a realtime decision that you process and it's hard to predict going forward but the changes we made were just in the corpo
componenttext: No, I think they're were unusually higher in the last couple of quarters. Because the way they characterize. I'm not -- it's kind of a realtime decision that you process and it's hard to predict going forward but the changes we made were just in the corporate side, more of a conservative approach I guess, in terms of shorter duration. And then on the product side, I think we talked about this before. We have a good discipline of after we make investment, on monitoring our investment in the SICAV and then recycling it, for a lack of a better word, to new products. So that does crystallize gains from time to time.
