headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome, to Franklin Resources Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call for the Quarter Ended March 31, 2011. My name is Christine, and I will be your conference operator for today. Please note that the financial results to be discuss
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome, to Franklin Resources Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call for the Quarter Ended March 31, 2011. My name is Christine, and I will be your conference operator for today. 
Please note that the financial results to be discussed in this conference call are preliminary. Statements made in this conference call regarding Franklin Resources Inc., which are not historical facts are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the risk factors and MD&A section of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K filing. [Operator Instructions] Now I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Greg Johnson, Chief Executive Officer. You may begin.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for taking time to join us for this call. Joining me is Ken Lewis, our CFO. This morning we reported a strong quarter of operating results, sales we're at an all-time high and long-term net new flow
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for taking time to join us for this call. Joining me is Ken Lewis, our CFO. 
This morning we reported a strong quarter of operating results, sales we're at an all-time high and long-term net new flows improved to $9 billion, due to the continued strength of Global bonds and a pickup in U.S. Equity and Hybrid flows. We did experience some lumpy institutional redemptions during the quarter, but flow trends improved in March. That trend has continued in April, and we continue to see that we're well positioned to benefit from increased investor demand for equities and Hybrid fund. Now I'd like to open it up for your questions.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Roger Freeman from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Roger Freeman from Barclays Capital.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess, just to start with the flows, looking at domestic equities, $2.4 billion net. I mean, how are -- is there any lumpy institutional inflows, mandates that funded in the quarter there? Because obviously, it's a very strong number. And looking at sor
componenttext: I guess, just to start with the flows, looking at domestic equities, $2.4 billion net. I mean, how are -- is there any lumpy institutional inflows, mandates that funded in the quarter there? Because obviously, it's a very strong number. And looking at sort of the same fund, datas on the mutual fund side, it would suggest it was a -- that you got a smaller number. So I was wondering if there's anything lumpy in there, if that really is representative of the broad-based market share gains?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: There really is -- there's not anything lumpy to call out. I mean, I think for us, we talked about some of the efforts around the DCIO platform that it was a record sales month for us there. And the equity funds, especially in the U.S., a few of them had
componenttext: There really is -- there's not anything lumpy to call out. I mean, I think for us, we talked about some of the efforts around the DCIO platform that it was a record sales month for us there. And the equity funds, especially in the U.S., a few of them had record quarters as well.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's great. And I guess, the follow-up, just around expenses. They came in below what we were looking for sort of based on some of the commentary about -- in 4 years what's it going to look like, and I sense others as well. I mean, can you talk a
componenttext: Okay. That's great. And I guess, the follow-up, just around expenses. They came in below what we were looking for sort of based on some of the commentary about -- in 4 years what's it going to look like, and I sense others as well. I mean, can you talk a little bit about how some of that progression pans out over the year vis-à-vis some of the projects you're spending on?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. I guess, just as a follow-up on the previous question too. There's also strong flows in our SICAV products in the U.K. category it probably doesn't come through in some funds. So the U.S. opportunities fund was our top selling one there for equity f
componenttext: Sure. I guess, just as a follow-up on the previous question too. There's also strong flows in our SICAV products in the U.K. category it probably doesn't come through in some funds. So the U.S. opportunities fund was our top selling one there for equity funds.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's true that -- particularly the IT and the occupancy expense came in a little under where we're thinking it's going to be, but we continue to spend innovating it, it should be taking a little bit longer for that spend to be reflected in the income
componenttext: Yes, it's true that -- particularly the IT and the occupancy expense came in a little under where we're thinking it's going to be, but we continue to spend innovating it, it should be taking a little bit longer for that spend to be reflected in the income statement for, I guess, two reasons. One, is a lot of the projects that we're working on are capitalized, so you have to wait until its completed. And then it will come through in depreciation expense. And two, there have been a lot of efficiencies realized in this fiscal year, particularly due to some strategic decisions we've made on the technology side. For example, bringing these data centers in house. Where kind of recognizing some of those savings earlier than we thought. So that's been, maybe, keeping the expense line static instead of increasing what we thought. But the message is the same. I think, over the long term, you'll see some, well, not very dramatic, but you you'll see some incremental uptick in those lines going forward.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, maybe to just of kind follow-up on the domestic equity flows, can you give us some color around maybe some of the drivers behind this step-up whether its performance, rising risk appetites more broadly, or maybe it's related to your recent marketin
componenttext: First, maybe to just of kind follow-up on the domestic equity flows, can you give us some color around maybe some of the drivers behind this step-up whether its performance, rising risk appetites more broadly, or maybe it's related to your recent marketing efforts?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the answer is probably a little bit all of the above. I mean, we have felt that the performance has been very strong especially on the Franklin equity side. Franklin Growth Fund has been around a long time. We've just spent, for the last six month
componenttext: I think the answer is probably a little bit all of the above. I mean, we have felt that the performance has been very strong especially on the Franklin equity side. Franklin Growth Fund has been around a long time. We've just spent, for the last six months, pushing hard on those bonds. And I think obviously the timing is right. And then I think more importantly for the longer-term trend is all of the new platforms that we've introduced those funds to in the last six months and the defining contribution tends to be a steadier place to go and that's probably where the battles won and lost as far as equity funds go. So our metric was getting them on as many platforms over the last year when equities were at a favor. And now when you're see things come back, they're doing very well. And the Franklin Growth fund, the Raising Dividends fund, and then offshore the Franklin U.S. Opportunities fund, all had record quarters for the last quarter.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of margins, is it fair to say maybe margins have peaked, at least in the near term, just as you continue to ramp up some investment spending? Or do you still feel like there's some leverage in the model just assuming assets continu
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of margins, is it fair to say maybe margins have peaked, at least in the near term, just as you continue to ramp up some investment spending? Or do you still feel like there's some leverage in the model just assuming assets continue to trend higher and maybe the mix improves a little bit?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think, there's some leverage in the model. Obviously, revenue -- time and time again, revenue is the big driver. Even the short quarter this month caused a little bit of the margin compression. But we're going to continue to spend, but it's not -- we we
componenttext: I think, there's some leverage in the model. Obviously, revenue -- time and time again, revenue is the big driver. Even the short quarter this month caused a little bit of the margin compression. But we're going to continue to spend, but it's not -- we were doing it pretty thoughtfully and I think there's room for extension.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jeff Hopson from Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jeff Hopson from Stifel.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Any additional details on the $4.7 billion as far as why that left. Do you know if it went to passive? And then in terms of international equity retail, I guess, on the SICAV side, any change in kind of the products that you're selling there. I know Asia-
componenttext: Any additional details on the $4.7 billion as far as why that left. Do you know if it went to passive? And then in terms of international equity retail, I guess, on the SICAV side, any change in kind of the products that you're selling there. I know Asia-Pacific growth was a big seller in the previous quarter, but any changes there?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think, first of all, the large redemptions and the -- or more performance-related, and it really depends on how you view performance. And if you look at Templeton and with the early value by us. If you look at them, it's all international equity funds,
componenttext: I think, first of all, the large redemptions and the -- or more performance-related, and it really depends on how you view performance. And if you look at Templeton and with the early value by us. If you look at them, it's all international equity funds, they were under performing. Now that's turned around dramatically since that decision was made by those sovereign wealth funds to switch over. I'm not sure where the moneys went going passive or they're active, but it was performance-related to the Templeton lag. Now that's really over the last three months it turned around dramatically. And you could see most of the Templeton funds now are in the top first or second quartile, including the three-year number that moved quickly. And at that same time, we were winning global equity mandates, at the same time that, that redemption was made. So I don't think you can draw any conclusion. That happens. And these funds tend to move moneys around a little bit quicker than, say, your average. So when you have downturns and short-term performance, you're vulnerable. As far as the global equity flows go outside of the U.S., you're right, the big driver has been Asian growth. And that trailed off during the quarter. And I think the reason there is really the backup in rates and the January effect on emerging markets. And overall, those markets underperformed the overall MSCI during the quarter. And again, those tend to be more short-term performance-related, and I would think that, that would be coming back now.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Bill Katz from Citigroup.
componenttext: The next question comes from Bill Katz from Citigroup.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to get a little more detail behind the new vision, 2020 Vision campaign. Could you talk a little bit about when you rolled it out? Where you rolled it out geographically? And is there any more opportunity to penetrate other distribution channe
componenttext: Just wanted to get a little more detail behind the new vision, 2020 Vision campaign. Could you talk a little bit about when you rolled it out? Where you rolled it out geographically? And is there any more opportunity to penetrate other distribution channels with any other regions, et cetera? And more quantitative feedback beyond the 80,000 fulfillment certificates you sent out so far.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're on to the next phase of that campaign. And it was really designed just to give advisers tools to deal with, the move towards fixed income and how much pressure there was to redeem equities and whether it was our fund or somebody else's
componenttext: Well, I think we're on to the next phase of that campaign. And it was really designed just to give advisers tools to deal with, the move towards fixed income and how much pressure there was to redeem equities and whether it was our fund or somebody else's. We just wanted to create more value in the relationship by having those tools out there and then try to come in and follow up with the Franklin fund. Right now, the push in marketing is global, is a new core. And it doesn't mean we're forgetting about U.S. but all the tests and surveys that we've done in trends indicate that there'll be more moving to Global Equities. People are still under-weighted and we wanted to change the thinking. Because again, I think that's advantageous to us with our overall mix to have Global Equities represent a larger base of individual investors' portfolio.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are there any questions, are there any opportunities to sort of broaden out that marketing campaign that could add another way of growth on top of what you're doing right now?
componenttext: Are there any questions, are there any opportunities to sort of broaden out that marketing campaign that could add another way of growth on top of what you're doing right now?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, hopefully. I mean, that's -- as I said before, I think the equity push is something that -- we're getting to a new audience. We still think there's a lot of opportunity on the retirement side to get into more plans and as long as performance stays s
componenttext: Well, hopefully. I mean, that's -- as I said before, I think the equity push is something that -- we're getting to a new audience. We still think there's a lot of opportunity on the retirement side to get into more plans and as long as performance stays solid there, there is no reason why we can't expand the new markets. And the bigger question is how much can global equity expand. And again, you could talk about this looking at each country, because each country has its own biased to their home investing. Some higher than others and we're really approaching it on a regional and country-by-country basis. So we are rolling it out across the globe.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And so my follow-up question is, sort of come back to mark it in from a different way. I think your tax rate is a little below to what people are anticipating. I think, that's the mix shift that's underway. I think I asked this question every call, so I a
componenttext: And so my follow-up question is, sort of come back to mark it in from a different way. I think your tax rate is a little below to what people are anticipating. I think, that's the mix shift that's underway. I think I asked this question every call, so I apologize in advance, but when you think about the profitability by geography, I don't want to ask a leading question here, but is non-U.S. business at this point in time, I know you have some of it in the Bahamas, what have you, but it's not U.S. innately more positive or equal in terms of the profit contribution?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Non-U.S., U.S. are approximately even. If you put away the layers, in the non-U.S, there are pockets that are more profitable than the standard U.S. products, but there are also pockets that are not. And maybe they're not because we just may be getting st
componenttext: Non-U.S., U.S. are approximately even. If you put away the layers, in the non-U.S, there are pockets that are more profitable than the standard U.S. products, but there are also pockets that are not. And maybe they're not because we just may be getting started in area or the products may be small. So they blend out to a point where I can make a statement that non-U. S., U.S. is about the same profitability today. Just maybe, I can touch on the tax rate and the mix question. Sure, part of it was due to the assets that are managed out of low-texture switchings like Singapore, Hong Kong and the Bahamas. But also some of them was portfolio-related. So you can see on that slide we did that new chart that showed you that we had some gains, a lot of those gains were outside the U.S. So that changes the earnings mix, too.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

componenttext: The next question comes from Michael Carrier from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just given the longer redemption this quarter and than, in the last quarter, I think it was in Hybrid. Can you give us any color, just on the institutional pipeline and maybe you have some of these in the out, but what's coming in and where is the interes
componenttext: Just given the longer redemption this quarter and than, in the last quarter, I think it was in Hybrid. Can you give us any color, just on the institutional pipeline and maybe you have some of these in the out, but what's coming in and where is the interest?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the pipeline looks good. I mean we really don't about or try to put out any numbers for you to be able to guess if any lumpy things are coming in or not or going out. I think the feeling is the trends, that again, we talked about the quarter
componenttext: Well, I think the pipeline looks good. I mean we really don't about or try to put out any numbers for you to be able to guess if any lumpy things are coming in or not or going out. I think the feeling is the trends, that again, we talked about the quarters around global equities and whether it's lower duration, emerging market bonds are all very much in place and have a very active and healthy pipeline for us. So hopefully we'll see some good numbers coming in there next quarter.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the retail side, it looks like you've definitely seen a pickup on the domestic equity side and the Hybrid. And then just in terms of interest levels, I guess, it makes sense, you haven't seen the pick up on the international equity but i
componenttext: Okay. And then on the retail side, it looks like you've definitely seen a pickup on the domestic equity side and the Hybrid. And then just in terms of interest levels, I guess, it makes sense, you haven't seen the pick up on the international equity but it looks like there's a focus on the marketing new campaign. And then, I guess, just any update on the muni side just in terms of any increased interest from the advisers or from the retail client.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, muni as we've said, will continue to be difficult. I mean, I think they're under pressure everyday in the headlines and you certainly have some strategic buyers that come into the market with just the overall retail buyer that is a dominant
componenttext: Well, I think, muni as we've said, will continue to be difficult. I mean, I think they're under pressure everyday in the headlines and you certainly have some strategic buyers that come into the market with just the overall retail buyer that is a dominant player in that marketplace is going to react to what they read about in headlines. And I think the bigger part was the concern that rates are going up and taxes are staying down and not going up quickly. And I think those two on a less liquid market had a pretty dramatic impact, coupled with the headlines, and it's hard to separate out what affects it the most. But the bottom line is, we don't see that turning around quickly. It's better -- performance has been better. It was positive for the quarter overall for munis. So that's positive and whether it settles down, I think it should, but you still run that risk of headlines everyday and budgets being battle, and that's just going to put headwinds into muni flows. International equity, I mean, the issue, the core strength of our franchise around Franklin -- around the Templeton side has with its larger cap value bias and less energy in material waiting. It's hurt relative performance. Now the good news today, is the dollar has been weak, they don't hedge anything. The move in the last quarter into Europe and other places where they've been overweighted that's hurt performance, that's helped performance here and helped it dramatically. So that's turned around quickly. It's hard to sell when you're third and fourth quartile. But now that we're back in the first and second, hopefully we can see some turn around there quickly on the retail side. And mutuals has been steady and positive. And mutuals European and Mutual Discovery continue to be steady as far as inflows go. And again, hopefully that will continue

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ken Worthington from JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ken Worthington from JPMorgan.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the Templeton Global bond and the International bond franchise, I know you've talked about there being no capacity issues there. Are you getting any sense of either owner fatigue or buyer fatigue if fund performance remains really good but the net sale
componenttext: On the Templeton Global bond and the International bond franchise, I know you've talked about there being no capacity issues there. Are you getting any sense of either owner fatigue or buyer fatigue if fund performance remains really good but the net sales peaked last year in kind of the March and June quarters and the gross redemption seems to be creeping higher. Just any sense of fatigue and do you think sales number kind of stabilize here or do you think they continue to decline from very strong levels?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, as we said, even at the height that it's very hard to maintain those kind of flow numbers, and you have the natural -- the funds growing and aging and you're going to have redemption that weren't there before, just based on the average life
componenttext: Well, I think, as we said, even at the height that it's very hard to maintain those kind of flow numbers, and you have the natural -- the funds growing and aging and you're going to have redemption that weren't there before, just based on the average life of an investment. So that puts pressure on the overall net number. But I'd looked at -- the story to me is the strength of the Global Total Return fund and how quickly that's grown in $2.5 billion of net inflows into that fund the last quarter. So while you could argue maybe the Global bond has slowed a little bit, but you can certainly say the Global Total Return has become very meaningful, and that's even a bigger market than the Global Bond because it's not only has sovereign debt but has Corporate bonds in there. And that's had excellent performance, and we're continuing to see strong interest there. And I think, again, any country that's concerned about their currency whether it's U.S. or the euro are going to be very interested in Global bonds and that's certainly getting more headlines. I would argue today than ever. So I still am pretty optimistic on flows there.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great, And then as a follow-up, can you give us a little more information on the SICAV products. What are the asset levels you have in those funds at this point. And if you can, what were the SICAV sales for the quarter?
componenttext: Great, And then as a follow-up, can you give us a little more information on the SICAV products. What are the asset levels you have in those funds at this point. And if you can, what were the SICAV sales for the quarter?

componenttextpreview: I don't have the actual breakdown of the sales, it's about $130 billion in assets in the SICAV funds.
componenttext: I don't have the actual breakdown of the sales, it's about $130 billion in assets in the SICAV funds.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from Cynthia Mayer from Bank of America.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Maybe just to start, a follow-up on the 2020 campaign question. When I look at the equity funds that you flag for emphasis in the campaign, Templeton Growth is a standout year-to-date, but most of the others are lagging this year. And I'm just wondering i
componenttext: Maybe just to start, a follow-up on the 2020 campaign question. When I look at the equity funds that you flag for emphasis in the campaign, Templeton Growth is a standout year-to-date, but most of the others are lagging this year. And I'm just wondering if that kind of short-term performance, apart from their long-term records, but does that kind of short-term performance influence the sales or should we assume that, particularly in DC, it's really more important to get on the menu. And then it's demand for that particular asset class.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that's exactly right. I think that's why it's so important to get on those platforms, to get the steadier flows and not be vulnerable to short-term swings, where it's more discretionary on buying the latest invest as far as the 1, 3 and 5. So you'
componenttext: I think that's exactly right. I think that's why it's so important to get on those platforms, to get the steadier flows and not be vulnerable to short-term swings, where it's more discretionary on buying the latest invest as far as the 1, 3 and 5. So you're right, I mean there's some slight under performance in the near term for a couple of those funds. And probably it will have, I think, some effect. But again, that's why it's so important for us to get on the retirement platforms where you are less vulnerable and it's more of the 3- and 5-year numbers than it is the 6 months and 1 year.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I just had a modeling question, which is -- I just wanted to clarify something you mentioned on your pre-recorded commentary, you were talking about the drivers for distribution revenues and expenses and it seemed like you were saying that
componenttext: Okay. And then I just had a modeling question, which is -- I just wanted to clarify something you mentioned on your pre-recorded commentary, you were talking about the drivers for distribution revenues and expenses and it seemed like you were saying that the biggest driver for both has changed in asset. But the impact seemed to be really different for revenues and for expenses. It had a bigger impact on expenses and so they rose faster. So I'm just wondering if that was something specific for the quarter? Or in modeling ahead, should we assume that assets go up x percent and it should have a similar impact?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think maybe one of the things to focus on is the mix of international and U.S. in that equation. Because on the expense side, you're going to have expenses, distribution expenses related to both the international products as well as the U.S. products. B
componenttext: I think maybe one of the things to focus on is the mix of international and U.S. in that equation. Because on the expense side, you're going to have expenses, distribution expenses related to both the international products as well as the U.S. products. But on the revenue side, it's essentially or mostly just the U.S. products.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

componenttext: The next question comes from Dan Fannon from Jefferies & Company.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

componenttext: I guess, to start off from a capital management perspective, should we view this as kind of a normal quarter for buybacks based on kind of where you're thinking cash flow is going to come in or your cash is sitting today. And then, I guess, an update on what you're potentially thinking about from acquisitions.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right, I guess, If you look at this quarter, it's roughly in line with basically the prior 4 and 5 quarters. And I think that's a good average. And then depending on market conditions, we'll be opportunistic and flex that one way or the other. In terms of
componenttext: Right, I guess, If you look at this quarter, it's roughly in line with basically the prior 4 and 5 quarters. And I think that's a good average. And then depending on market conditions, we'll be opportunistic and flex that one way or the other. In terms of acquisitions, we continue to look. We continue to get presented opportunities around the world and we continue to work. So when it make sense, we'll do something.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I mean, is there any specific product or focus? I mean, you've talked about potentially alternatives and a little bit more of a focus in terms of what you would add to your product suite. Has anything else there changed?
componenttext: I mean, is there any specific product or focus? I mean, you've talked about potentially alternatives and a little bit more of a focus in terms of what you would add to your product suite. Has anything else there changed?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. That hasn't changed. That's probably the focus.
componenttext: No. That hasn't changed. That's probably the focus.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Douglas Sipkin from Ticonderoga.
componenttext: The next question comes from Douglas Sipkin from Ticonderoga.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow-up, obviously, there's a tremendous secular story on the international, both equity and debt. I mean, can you guys put any color on just how much the sustained dollar weakness is maybe enhancing that. And is that a rich pocket, if th
componenttext: Just wanted to follow-up, obviously, there's a tremendous secular story on the international, both equity and debt. I mean, can you guys put any color on just how much the sustained dollar weakness is maybe enhancing that. And is that a rich pocket, if that where to reverse at all, just a little bit? Or is it really just a driver of this secular trend with better growth dynamics?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's no question, we're getting the benefit of the weak dollar and the trend towards investing more offshore. The question, what happens when it goes the other way, and we've had it go the other way, and that will hurt performance and som
componenttext: Well, I think there's no question, we're getting the benefit of the weak dollar and the trend towards investing more offshore. The question, what happens when it goes the other way, and we've had it go the other way, and that will hurt performance and some funds and help others depending on the hedging strategies in our Global Bond fund. It doesn't necessarily invest against the dollar all the time. So if they feel like it's going too far, they have the flexibility to move the other way, too. So for us, obviously, probably everything held equal, it's a net-net benefit. I'm not sure what you can do as an entity to hedge yourself against that should it go the other way. But we've been through periods like that before and it's just means certain funds will be out of favor.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just to follow up. I just read a couple of pieces talking about how internationally there's some new potential law changes that will provide more disclosure around commissions and things of that nature, I think in Taiwan, maybe in the U.K. How ar
componenttext: And then just to follow up. I just read a couple of pieces talking about how internationally there's some new potential law changes that will provide more disclosure around commissions and things of that nature, I think in Taiwan, maybe in the U.K. How are you guys thinking through that. I mean will that have any impact on how you sell stuff or is it sort of just more a procedural and not really a change to how you guys are going to sell products.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think those are wrong -- I wouldn't just dismiss those kind of issues. I think they -- it just depends what shape and form. You can have drastic moves like it was done in the India market where they did away with the run and sales charge, and whether or
componenttext: I think those are wrong -- I wouldn't just dismiss those kind of issues. I think they -- it just depends what shape and form. You can have drastic moves like it was done in the India market where they did away with the run and sales charge, and whether or not that changes over time, I think time will tell. So I think you have to work with the regulators and hopefully come up with some form of disclosure and transparency that works for everyone. But I don't think there's anything in those two markets that immediately we would be a cause for concern for us right now.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Marc Irizarry from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question comes from Marc Irizarry from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greg, when you think about building the global to local business outside the U.S., I know the markets pretty idiosyncratic but can you talk about where you're seeing the best share gains locally and where you're not sort of gaining momentum. What are some
componenttext: Greg, when you think about building the global to local business outside the U.S., I know the markets pretty idiosyncratic but can you talk about where you're seeing the best share gains locally and where you're not sort of gaining momentum. What are some of the impediments to you gaining share there? And then I'll follow.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, generally, it will come down to your relative performance. And just like in any market, what's selling. I think for us in the local asset management side, we picked that good share in India and a lot of that's been around just developing fixed incom
componenttext: Well, generally, it will come down to your relative performance. And just like in any market, what's selling. I think for us in the local asset management side, we picked that good share in India and a lot of that's been around just developing fixed income funds that have done well in that market. Korea, on the other hand, is in a tough market. And then even though the equity markets been up, equity flows in general there, have not been very strong. So it's been more institutional for us than retail. But really, that's the two that probably standout in my mind as far as one or the other. And a lot of the other one, whether it's China with the JV, I mean, still great potential and profitable, but probably a longer-term venture and one that you don't own more than 50%.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And then when you think about your strong capital position that you're in and the decent amount of cash down the south, overseas. How do you think about making acquisitions to sort of bolster your market position in some of those local markets?
componenttext: Great. And then when you think about your strong capital position that you're in and the decent amount of cash down the south, overseas. How do you think about making acquisitions to sort of bolster your market position in some of those local markets?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the fact that we do have a lot of cash overseas and the fact that that's where we're growing gives us a bias towards -- I think we're going to do an acquisition, all things being equal, to give us the bias towards doing that internationally.
componenttext: Well, I think the fact that we do have a lot of cash overseas and the fact that that's where we're growing gives us a bias towards -- I think we're going to do an acquisition, all things being equal, to give us the bias towards doing that internationally.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think the other point is we are in more of these markets than most firms that are looking to get into them. So for us, to acquire a firm and combine it, there's a strategic premium built in the multiples sort of people that are trying to get in
componenttext: Yes. And I think the other point is we are in more of these markets than most firms that are looking to get into them. So for us, to acquire a firm and combine it, there's a strategic premium built in the multiples sort of people that are trying to get in, China, India markets that we've been in for a while. So that kind of precludes us from paying that. And that's how we think about it as well. I mean unless it was really an entirely new type of fund management that we didn't have in that market, then you could rationalize doing it. But you you're not going to have a lot of opportunities to stand with a grow scale and put these two together and make it accretive with some of the points of entry and what people are paying to get in. So I think that's a little bit of a constraint in a lot of markets where we've seen some deals done.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Jonathan Casteleyn from Susquehanna.
componenttext: The next question comes from Jonathan Casteleyn from Susquehanna.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering if there's any evidence around the municipal outflows you're seeing? Are they being recaptured in other products within the complex?
componenttext: I'm just wondering if there's any evidence around the municipal outflows you're seeing? Are they being recaptured in other products within the complex?

componenttext: Really, I would say the area with the greatest opportunity to be around taxable asset allocation, real asset-type funds, funds that will be a little bit more defensive in a rising rate environment. So that's really where we built out our solutions capability. It made a lot of hires in the last couple of years and that's why we're going to see 4 or 5 new funds over the next year or so.

But I think in the pre-recorded commentary you talked about how investment gains have been up lately because you're reallocating capital investments and rebalancing corporate investment. I'm just wondering if you can give a little color on what changes you're making and why? And whether those gains and losses will stay elevated for a few more quarters?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. I think, they were unusually high in the last couple of quarters, I guess, the way to characterize it. They're not -- it's kind of a realtime decision that you can process and it's hard to predict going forward. But the changes we made were just in th
componenttext: No. I think, they were unusually high in the last couple of quarters, I guess, the way to characterize it. They're not -- it's kind of a realtime decision that you can process and it's hard to predict going forward. But the changes we made were just in the corporate side, more of a conservative approach, I guess, in terms of shorter duration. And then on the product side, I think we've talked about this before. We have a good discipline of after we make investment -- on monitoring our investment in the SICAV and then recycling it, for a lack of a better word, to new products. So that does crystallize gains from time to time.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call for the Quarter Ended March 31, 2011. My name is Christine, and I will be your conference operator for today. Please note that the financial results to be discusse
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call for the Quarter Ended March 31, 2011. My name is Christine, and I will be your conference operator for today. 
Please note that the financial results to be discussed in this conference call are preliminary. Statements made in this conference call regarding Franklin Resources Inc. which are not historical facts are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the risk factors and MD&A section of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K filing. [Operator Instructions] Now I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Greg Johnson, Chief Executive Officer. You may begin.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for taking time to join us for this call. Joining me is Ken Lewis, our CFO. This morning we reported a strong quarter of operating results, sales we're at an all-time high and long-term net new flows
componenttext:
Thank you and good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for taking time to join us for this call. Joining me is Ken Lewis, our CFO. 
This morning we reported a strong quarter of operating results, sales we're at an all-time high and long-term net new flows improved to $9 billion, due to the continued strength of Global bonds and a pickup in U.S. Equity and Hybrid flows. We did experience some lumpy institutional redemptions during the quarter, but flow trends improved in March. That trend has continued in April, and we continue to see that we're well positioned to benefit from increased investor demand for equities and Hybrid funds. Now I'd like to open it up for your questions.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Roger Freeman from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Roger Freeman from Barclays Capital.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess, just to start with the flows. Looking at domestic equities, $2.4 billion net. I mean, how are -- is there any lumpy institutional inflows, mandates that funded in the quarter there? Because obviously, it's a very strong number. And looking at sor
componenttext: I guess, just to start with the flows. Looking at domestic equities, $2.4 billion net. I mean, how are -- is there any lumpy institutional inflows, mandates that funded in the quarter there? Because obviously, it's a very strong number. And looking at sort of the same fund, data on the mutual fund side, it would suggest it was a -- that you did get some smaller numbers. So I was wondering if there's anything lumpy in there, if that really is representative of the broad-based market share gains.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: There really isn't -- there's not anything lumpy to call out. I mean, I think for us, we talked about some of the efforts around the DCIO platform that it was a record sales month for us there. And the equity funds, especially in the U.S., a few of them h
componenttext: There really isn't -- there's not anything lumpy to call out. I mean, I think for us, we talked about some of the efforts around the DCIO platform that it was a record sales month for us there. And the equity funds, especially in the U.S., a few of them had record quarters as well.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's great. And I guess, the follow-up, just around expenses. They came in below what we were looking for sort of based on some of the commentary about -- in 4 years what it was going to look like, and I sense others as well. I mean, can you talk
componenttext: Okay. That's great. And I guess, the follow-up, just around expenses. They came in below what we were looking for sort of based on some of the commentary about -- in 4 years what it was going to look like, and I sense others as well. I mean, can you talk a little bit about how some of that progression pans out over the year vis-à-vis some of the projects you're spending on?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. I guess, just as a follow-up on the previous question, too. There's also strong flows in our SICAV products in the U.K. category it probably doesn't come through in some funds. So the U.S. opportunities fund was our top selling one there for equity
componenttext: Sure. I guess, just as a follow-up on the previous question, too. There's also strong flows in our SICAV products in the U.K. category it probably doesn't come through in some funds. So the U.S. opportunities fund was our top selling one there for equity funds.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's true that -- particularly the IT and the occupancy expense came in a little under where we're thinking it was going to be, but we continued to spend in those areas, it's just taking a little bit longer for that spend to be reflected in the incom
componenttext: Yes, it's true that -- particularly the IT and the occupancy expense came in a little under where we're thinking it was going to be, but we continued to spend in those areas, it's just taking a little bit longer for that spend to be reflected in the income statement for, I guess, 2 reasons. One is a lot of the projects that we're working on are capitalized, so you have to wait until its completed and then it will come through in depreciation expense. And two, there have been a lot of efficiencies realized in this fiscal year, particularly due to some strategic decisions we've made on the technology side. For example, bringing the data center in house. We're kind of recognizing some of those savings earlier than we thought. So that's been maybe keeping the expense line static instead of increasing what we thought. But the message is the same. I think over the long term you'll see some, well, not very dramatic, but you you'll see some incremental uptick in those lines going forward.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: The next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, maybe to just of kind follow-up on the domestic equity flows, can you give us some color around maybe some of the drivers behind this step-up, whether its performance, rising risk appetites more broadly, or maybe it's related to your recent marketi
componenttext: First, maybe to just of kind follow-up on the domestic equity flows, can you give us some color around maybe some of the drivers behind this step-up, whether its performance, rising risk appetites more broadly, or maybe it's related to your recent marketing efforts?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the answer is probably a little bit all of the above. I mean, we have felt that the performance has been very strong, especially on the Franklin equity side. Franklin Growth Fund has been around a long time. We've just spent, over the last 6 month
componenttext: I think the answer is probably a little bit all of the above. I mean, we have felt that the performance has been very strong, especially on the Franklin equity side. Franklin Growth Fund has been around a long time. We've just spent, over the last 6 months, pushing hard on those funds and I think obviously the timing is right. And then I think more importantly for the longer-term trend is all of the new platforms that we've introduced those funds to in the last 6 months and the defined contribution tends to be a steadier place to go and that's probably where the battle's won and lost as far as equity funds go. So our metric was getting them on as many platforms over the last year when equities were out of favor. And now when you're see things come back, they're doing very well. And the Franklin Growth fund, the Rising Dividends fund, and then offshore the Franklin U.S. Opportunities fund all had record quarters for the last quarter.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of margins, is it fair to say maybe margins have peaked, at least in the near term, just as you continue to ramp up some investment spending? Or do you still feel like there's some leverage in the model just assuming assets continu
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of margins, is it fair to say maybe margins have peaked, at least in the near term, just as you continue to ramp up some investment spending? Or do you still feel like there's some leverage in the model just assuming assets continue to trend higher and maybe the mix improves a little bit?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think there's some leverage in the model. Obviously, revenue -- time and time again, revenue's the big driver. Even the short quarter this month caused a little bit of the margin compression. But we're going to continue to spend, but it's not -- we're d
componenttext: I think there's some leverage in the model. Obviously, revenue -- time and time again, revenue's the big driver. Even the short quarter this month caused a little bit of the margin compression. But we're going to continue to spend, but it's not -- we're doing it pretty thoughtfully and I think there's room for expansion.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jeff Hopson from Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jeff Hopson from Stifel.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Any additional details on the $4.7 billion as far as why that left? Do you know if it went to passive? And then in terms of international equity retail, I guess, on the SICAV side, any change in kind of the products that you're selling there? I know Asia-
componenttext: Any additional details on the $4.7 billion as far as why that left? Do you know if it went to passive? And then in terms of international equity retail, I guess, on the SICAV side, any change in kind of the products that you're selling there? I know Asia-Pacific growth was a big seller in the previous quarter, but any changes there?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think, first of all, the large redemptions and the -- were more performance related and it really depends on how you view performance. And if you look at Templeton and with really a value bias if you look at them relative, it's all international equity
componenttext: I think, first of all, the large redemptions and the -- were more performance related and it really depends on how you view performance. And if you look at Templeton and with really a value bias if you look at them relative, it's all international equity funds, they were under performing. Now that's turned around dramatically since that decision was made by those sovereign wealth funds to switch over. I'm not sure where the monies went going passive or they're active, but it was performance-related to the Templeton lag. Now that's really over the last 3 months it turned around dramatically. And you could see most of the Templeton funds now are in the top first or second quartile, including the 3-year number that moved quickly. And at that same time we were winning global equity mandates at the same time that, that redemption was made. So I don't think you can draw any conclusions that, that happens. These funds tend to move monies around a little bit quicker than, say, your average. So when you do have downturns and short-term performance, you're vulnerable. As far as the global equity flows go outside of the U.S., you're right, the big driver's been Asian growth and that trailed off during the quarter. And I think the reason there is really the backup in rates and the January effect on emerging markets. And overall, those markets underperformed the overall MSCI during the quarter. And again, those tend to be more short-term performance-related, and I would think that, that would be coming back now.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Bill Katz from Citigroup.
componenttext: The next question comes from Bill Katz from Citigroup.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to get a little more detail behind the new vision, 2020 Vision campaign. Could you talk a little bit about when you rolled it out? Where you rolled it out geographically? And is there any more opportunity to penetrate other distribution channe
componenttext: Just wanted to get a little more detail behind the new vision, 2020 Vision campaign. Could you talk a little bit about when you rolled it out? Where you rolled it out geographically? And is there any more opportunity to penetrate other distribution channels with any other regions, et cetera? Any more quantitative feedback beyond the 80,000 fulfillment certificates you sent out so far?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're on to the next phase of that campaign. And it was really designed just to give advisers tools to deal with the move towards fixed income and how much pressure there was to redeem equities and whether it was our fund or somebody else's.
componenttext: Well, I think we're on to the next phase of that campaign. And it was really designed just to give advisers tools to deal with the move towards fixed income and how much pressure there was to redeem equities and whether it was our fund or somebody else's. We just wanted to create more value in the relationship by having those tools out there and then try to come in and follow up with the Franklin fund. Right now, the push in marketing is global is a new core. And that doesn't mean we're forgetting about U.S., but all the tests and surveys that we've done and trends indicate that there'll be more moving to Global Equities. People are still under-weighted and we wanted to change the thinking. Because again, I think that that's advantageous to us with our overall mix to have Global Equities represent a larger base of individual investors' portfolio.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are there any -- expands the question, are there any opportunities to sort of broaden out that marketing campaign that could add another way of growth on top of what you're doing right now?
componenttext: Are there any -- expands the question, are there any opportunities to sort of broaden out that marketing campaign that could add another way of growth on top of what you're doing right now?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, hopefully. I mean, that's -- as I said before, I think the equity push is something that we're getting to a new audience. We still think there's a lot of opportunity on the retirement side to get into more plans and as long as performance stays soli
componenttext: Well, hopefully. I mean, that's -- as I said before, I think the equity push is something that we're getting to a new audience. We still think there's a lot of opportunity on the retirement side to get into more plans and as long as performance stays solid there, there's no reason why we can't expand to new markets. And the bigger question is how much can global equities expand. And again, you could talk about this looking at each country, because each country has its own bias to their home investing. Some higher than others and we're really approaching it on a regional and country-by-country basis. So we are rolling it out across the globe.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And so my follow-up question is, sort of come back to Martin's from a different way. I think your tax rate is a little bit lower than people were anticipating. I guess that's the mix shift that's underway. I think I ask this question every quarter, so I a
componenttext: And so my follow-up question is, sort of come back to Martin's from a different way. I think your tax rate is a little bit lower than people were anticipating. I guess that's the mix shift that's underway. I think I ask this question every quarter, so I apologize in advance, but when you think about the profitability by geography, I don't want to ask a leading question here, but is non-U.S. business at this point in time -- I know you run some of the money through the Bahamas, what have you, but is non-U.S. innately more positive or equal in terms of the profit contribution?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Non-U.S., U.S. are approximately even. If you pull away the layers in the non-U.S, there are pockets that are more profitable than the standard U.S. products, but there are also pockets that are not. And maybe they're not because we might just be getting
componenttext: Non-U.S., U.S. are approximately even. If you pull away the layers in the non-U.S, there are pockets that are more profitable than the standard U.S. products, but there are also pockets that are not. And maybe they're not because we might just be getting started in an area or the products may be small. So they blend out to a point where I can make the statement that non-U. S., U.S. is about the same profitability today. Just maybe I can touch on the tax rate and the mix question. Sure, part of it was due to the assets that are managed out of low-texture switches like Singapore, Hong Kong and the Bahamas. But also some of it was portfolio-related. So you can see on that slide we did that new chart that showed you that we had some gains, a lot of those gains were outside the U.S. So that changes the earnings mix, too.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

componenttext: The next question comes from Michael Carrier from Deutsche Bank.

componenttext: Just given the longer redemption this quarter than in last quarter, I think it was in Hybrid. Can you give us any color just on the institutional pipeline and maybe you have some of these on the out, but what's coming in and where is the interest?

componenttext: Well, I think the pipeline looks good. I mean we really don't talk about or try to put out any numbers where you'd be able to guess if any lumpy things are coming in or not or going out. I think the feeling is the trends and again, we talked about the quarters around global equities and whether it's lower duration, emerging market bonds are all very much in place and they're very active and healthy pipeline for us. So hopefully we'll see some good numbers coming in there next quarter.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the retail side, it looks like you're definitely seeing a pickup on the domestic equity side and the Hybrid. And then just in terms of interest levels, I guess it makes sense. I mean, you haven't seen a pickup on the international equity
componenttext: Okay. And then on the retail side, it looks like you're definitely seeing a pickup on the domestic equity side and the Hybrid. And then just in terms of interest levels, I guess it makes sense. I mean, you haven't seen a pickup on the international equity, but it looks like there's a focus on the marketing new campaign. And then, I guess, just any update on the muni side just in terms of any increased interest from the advisers or from the retail client.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think muni, as we've said, will continue to be difficult. I mean, I think they're under pressure every day in the headlines and you certainly have some strategic buyers that come into the market, but just the overall retail buyer that is a dominan
componenttext: Well, I think muni, as we've said, will continue to be difficult. I mean, I think they're under pressure every day in the headlines and you certainly have some strategic buyers that come into the market, but just the overall retail buyer that is a dominant player in that marketplace is going to react to what they read about in headlines. And I think the bigger part was the concern that rates are going up and taxes were staying down and not going up quickly. And I think those 2 on a less liquid market had a pretty dramatic impact, coupled with the headlines, and it's hard to separate out what affects it the most. But the bottom line is, we don't see that turning around quickly. It's better -- performance has been better. It was positive for the quarter overall for munis. So that's positive and whether it settles down, I think it should, but you still run that risk of headlines everyday and budgets being battle, and that's just going to put headwind into muni flows. International equity, I mean, the issue, the core strength of our franchise around Franklin -- around the Templeton side has with its larger cap value bias and less energy in material waiting has hurt relative performance. Now the good news today is the dollar's been weak, they don't hedge anything. The move in the last quarter into Europe and other places where they've been overweighted that's hurt performance has helped performance here and helped it dramatically. So that's turned around quickly. It's hard to sell when you're third and fourth quartile. But now that we're back into first and second, hopefully we can see some turn around there quickly on the retail side. And mutual's been steady and positive. And Mutual European and Mutual Discovery continue to be steady as far as inflows go. And again, hopefully that'll continue.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ken Worthington from JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ken Worthington from JPMorgan.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the Templeton Global bond and the International bond franchise, I know you've talked about there being no capacity issues there. Are you getting any sense of either owner fatigue or buyer fatigue? The fund performance remains really good, but the net s
componenttext: On the Templeton Global bond and the International bond franchise, I know you've talked about there being no capacity issues there. Are you getting any sense of either owner fatigue or buyer fatigue? The fund performance remains really good, but the net sales peaked last year in kind of the March and June quarters and gross redemption seems to be creeping higher. So any sense of fatigue? And do you think sales number kind of stabilize here or do you think they continue to decline from very strong levels?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, as we said, even at the height that it's very hard to maintain those kind of flow numbers, and you have the natural -- the funds growing and aging and you're going to have redemptions that weren't there before, just based on the average lif
componenttext: Well, I think, as we said, even at the height that it's very hard to maintain those kind of flow numbers, and you have the natural -- the funds growing and aging and you're going to have redemptions that weren't there before, just based on the average life of an investment. So that puts pressure on the overall net number. But I'd looked at -- the story to me is the strength of the Global Total Return fund and how quickly that's grown in $2.5 billion of net inflows into that fund the last quarter. So while you could argue maybe the Global bond has slowed a little bit, but you can certainly say the Global Total Return has become very meaningful, and that's even a bigger market than the Global Bond because it not only has sovereign debt, but has Corporate bonds in there. And that's had excellent performance and we're continuing to see strong interest there. And I think, again, any country that's concerned about their currency, whether it's U.S. or the euro, are going to be very interested in Global bonds and that's certainly getting more headlines I would argue today than ever. So I still am pretty optimistic on flows there.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And then as a follow-up, can you give us a little more information on the SICAV products? What are the asset levels you have in those funds at this point? And if you can, what were the SICAV sales for the quarter?
componenttext: Great. And then as a follow-up, can you give us a little more information on the SICAV products? What are the asset levels you have in those funds at this point? And if you can, what were the SICAV sales for the quarter?

componenttext: I don't have the actual breakdown of the sales. It's about $130 billion in assets in the SICAV funds.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from Cynthia Mayer from Bank of America.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Maybe just to start, a follow-up on the 2020 campaign question. When I look at the equity funds that you flag for emphasis in the campaign, Templeton Growth is a standout year-to-date, but most of the others are lagging this year. And I'm just wondering i
componenttext: Maybe just to start, a follow-up on the 2020 campaign question. When I look at the equity funds that you flag for emphasis in the campaign, Templeton Growth is a standout year-to-date, but most of the others are lagging this year. And I'm just wondering if that kind of short-term performance, apart from their long-term records, but does that kind of short-term performance influence the sales or should we assume that, particularly in DC, it's really more important to get on the menu. And then it's demand for that particular asset class.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that's exactly right. I think that's why it's so important to get on those platforms, to get the steadier flows and not be vulnerable to short-term swings where it's more discretionary on buying the latest and best as far as the 1, 3 and 5. So you
componenttext: I think that's exactly right. I think that's why it's so important to get on those platforms, to get the steadier flows and not be vulnerable to short-term swings where it's more discretionary on buying the latest and best as far as the 1, 3 and 5. So you're right, I mean there's some slight under performance in the near term for a couple of those funds. It probably will have, I think, some effect. But again, that's why it's so important for us to get on the retirement platforms where you are less vulnerable and it's more about the 3- and 5-year numbers than it is the 6 months and 1 year.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I just had a modeling question, which is -- I just wanted to clarify something you mentioned on your pre-recorded commentary. You were talking about the drivers for distribution revenues and expenses and it seemed like you were saying that
componenttext: Okay. And then I just had a modeling question, which is -- I just wanted to clarify something you mentioned on your pre-recorded commentary. You were talking about the drivers for distribution revenues and expenses and it seemed like you were saying that the biggest driver for both has changed in asset. But the impact seemed to be really different for revenues and for expenses. It had a bigger impact on expenses and so they rose faster. So I'm just wondering if that was something specific for the quarter. Or in modeling ahead, should we assume that assets go up x percent and it should have a similar impact?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think maybe one of the things to focus on is the mix of international and U.S. in that equation. Because on the expense side, you're going to have expenses, distribution expenses related to both the international products as well as the U.S. products. B
componenttext: I think maybe one of the things to focus on is the mix of international and U.S. in that equation. Because on the expense side, you're going to have expenses, distribution expenses related to both the international products as well as the U.S. products. But on the revenue side, it's essentially or mostly just the U.S. products.

componenttext: I guess to start off from a capital management perspective, should we view this as kind of a normal quarter for buybacks based on kind of where you're thinking cash flow is going to come in or your cash is sitting today? componenttext: Right, I guess if you look at this quarter, it's roughly in line with basically the prior 4 or 5 quarters. And I think that's a good average. And then depending on market conditions, we'll be opportunistic and flex that one way or the other. In terms of acquisitions, we continue to look. We continue to get presented opportunities around the world and we continue to look. So when it makes sense, we'll do something.
