headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Douglas Sipkin from Ticonderoga.
componenttext: The next question comes from Douglas Sipkin from Ticonderoga.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow-up. Obviously, there's a tremendous secular story on the international, both equity and debt. I mean, can you guys put any color on just how much the sustained dollar weakness is maybe enhancing that. And is that a risk pocket if tha
componenttext: Just wanted to follow-up. Obviously, there's a tremendous secular story on the international, both equity and debt. I mean, can you guys put any color on just how much the sustained dollar weakness is maybe enhancing that. And is that a risk pocket if that were to reverse at all, just a little bit? Or is it really just a driver of this secular trend with better growth dynamics?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's no question we're getting the benefit of the weak dollar and the trend towards investing more offshore. The question, what happens when it goes the other way, and we've had it go the other way, and that will hurt performance and some
componenttext: Well, I think there's no question we're getting the benefit of the weak dollar and the trend towards investing more offshore. The question, what happens when it goes the other way, and we've had it go the other way, and that will hurt performance and some funds and help others depending on the hedging strategies in our Global Bond fund. It doesn't necessarily invest against the dollar all the time. So if they feel like it's going too far, they have the flexibility to move the other way, too. So for us, obviously, probably everything held equal, it's a net-net benefit. I'm not sure what you can do as an entity to hedge yourself against that should it go the other way. But we've been through periods like that before and it's just means certain funds will be out of favor.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just a follow up. I just read a couple of pieces talking about how internationally there's some new potential law changes that will provide more disclosure around commissions and things of that nature, I think in Taiwan, maybe in the U.K. How are
componenttext: And then just a follow up. I just read a couple of pieces talking about how internationally there's some new potential law changes that will provide more disclosure around commissions and things of that nature, I think in Taiwan, maybe in the U.K. How are you guys thinking through that? I mean, will that have any impact on how you sell stuff or is it sort of just more a procedural and not really a change to how you guys are going to sell products?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think those are wrong. I wouldn't just dismiss those kind of issues. I think they -- it just depends what shape and form. You can have drastic moves like what was done in the India market where they did away with the run and sales charge and whether or
componenttext: I think those are wrong. I wouldn't just dismiss those kind of issues. I think they -- it just depends what shape and form. You can have drastic moves like what was done in the India market where they did away with the run and sales charge and whether or not that changes over time I think time will tell. So I think you have to work with the regulators and hopefully come up with some form of disclosure and transparency that works for everyone. But I don't think there's anything in those 2 markets that immediately would be a cause for concern for us right now.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Marc Irizarry from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question comes from Marc Irizarry from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greg, when you think about building the global to local business outside the U.S., I know the market's pretty idiosyncratic, but can you talk about where you're seeing the best share gains locally and where you're not sort of gaining momentum? What are so
componenttext: Greg, when you think about building the global to local business outside the U.S., I know the market's pretty idiosyncratic, but can you talk about where you're seeing the best share gains locally and where you're not sort of gaining momentum? What are some of the impediments to you gaining share there? And then I'll follow.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, generally, it will come down to your relative performance and just like in any market, what's selling. I think for us in the local asset management side, we picked up good share in India and a lot of that's been around just developing fixed income f
componenttext: Well, generally, it will come down to your relative performance and just like in any market, what's selling. I think for us in the local asset management side, we picked up good share in India and a lot of that's been around just developing fixed income funds that have done well in that market. Korea, on the other hand, has been tough market. And then even though the equity markets been up, equity flows in general there have not been very strong. So it's been more institutional for us than retail. But really, that's the 2 that probably stand out in my mind as far as one or the other. And a lot of the other ones, whether it's China with the JV, I mean, still great potential and profitable, but probably a longer-term venture and one that you don't own more than 50%.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And then when you think about your strong capital position that you're in and you've got a decent amount of cash down south, overseas, how do you think about making acquisitions to sort of bolster your market position in some of those local markets
componenttext: Great. And then when you think about your strong capital position that you're in and you've got a decent amount of cash down south, overseas, how do you think about making acquisitions to sort of bolster your market position in some of those local markets?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the fact that we do have a lot of cash overseas and the fact that that's where we're growing gives us a bias towards -- if were going to do an acquisition, all things being equal, will give us a bias towards doing that internationally.
componenttext: Well, I think the fact that we do have a lot of cash overseas and the fact that that's where we're growing gives us a bias towards -- if were going to do an acquisition, all things being equal, will give us a bias towards doing that internationally.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think the other point is we are in more of these markets than most firms that are looking to get into them. So for us to acquire a firm and combine it, there's a strategic premium built in the multiples for people that are trying to get in, Chi
componenttext: Yes. And I think the other point is we are in more of these markets than most firms that are looking to get into them. So for us to acquire a firm and combine it, there's a strategic premium built in the multiples for people that are trying to get in, China, India markets that we've been in for a while. So that kind of precludes us from paying that. And that's how we think about it as well. I mean unless it was really an entirely new type of fund management that we didn't have in that market, then you could rationalize doing it. But you you're not going to have a lot of opportunities to say I'm going to grow scale and put these 2 together and make it accretive with some of the points of entry and what people are paying to get in. So I think that's a little bit of a constraint in a lot of markets where we've seen some deals done.

componenttext: I see. Okay. And then you guys have a pretty good track record of launching new products. You got international equities and obviously Global bonds. Just wondering on a go-forward basis where you think, organically, if you were looking at new product suites, where they might reside?

componenttext: Really, I would say the area with the greatest opportunity would be around taxable asset allocation, real asset-type funds, funds that will be a little bit more defensive in a rising rate environment. So that's really where we built out our solutions capability. It made a lot of hires in the last couple of years and that's why we're going to see 4 or 5 new funds over the next year or so.

componenttext: Just a follow-up, Greg, I think the answer is it's getting better, but when you talk about the trends continue in April around the Global and Hybrid being lumpy, is it that they've gotten better in March and again in April? Or that they are lumpy, still, in March and April. I apologize, but it wasn't exactly clear in your commentary.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. I said there was really -- there was nothing that stood out as being lumpy. I said that we don't comment on lumpy post-March 31 as far as our comments go. And Hybrid has obviously been very attractive. And I think it's more of -- so far business as yo
componenttext: No. I said there was really -- there was nothing that stood out as being lumpy. I said that we don't comment on lumpy post-March 31 as far as our comments go. And Hybrid has obviously been very attractive. And I think it's more of -- so far business as you go. I mean as far as this quarter, new markets are strong and bond markets settle down a bit. So that bodes well for, I think, any Hybrid or Equity fund.

componenttextpreview: Apologies if you covered this already. But I think in the pre-recorded commentary, you talked about how investment gains have been up lately because you're reallocating capital investments and rebalancing corporate investment. I'm just wondering if you ca
componenttext: Apologies if you covered this already. But I think in the pre-recorded commentary, you talked about how investment gains have been up lately because you're reallocating capital investments and rebalancing corporate investment. I'm just wondering if you can give a little color on what changes you're making and why? And whether those gains and losses will stay elevated for a few more quarters?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. I think -- well I think they were unusually high in the last couple of quarters, I guess, is the way to characterize it. They're not -- it's kind of a realtime decision-making process that's hard to predict going forward. But the changes we made were
componenttext: No. I think -- well I think they were unusually high in the last couple of quarters, I guess, is the way to characterize it. They're not -- it's kind of a realtime decision-making process that's hard to predict going forward. But the changes we made were just on the corporate side, more of a conservative approach, I guess, in terms of shorter duration. And then on the product side, I think we've talked about this before. We have a good discipline of after we make investment on monitoring our investment in the SICAV and then recycling it, for a lack of a better word, to new products. So that does crystallize gains from time to time.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Hello, and welcome to the third quarter earnings commentary. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. We're pleased to be reporting another very strong quarter of operating results amidst what remains a volatile macroeconomic environment. Mos
componenttext:
Hello, and welcome to the third quarter earnings commentary. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. We're pleased to be reporting another very strong quarter of operating results amidst what remains a volatile macroeconomic environment. Most importantly, long-term investment performance remains strong across equity and fixed-income strategies and areas that have been under for performing the short term have improved. 
Performance, coupled with the debt and breadth of our global advisor relationships, translated into another quarter of record net flows led by the continued strength of our global fixed-income franchise. We continue execute our long-term strategy of investing in those areas that are complementary to our existing business and strengthen our capabilities in key markets. 
During the quarter, we announced the acquisition of Balanced Equity Management, a well-respected institutional manager in Australia. The acquisition closed in early July and is consistent with our strategy to address home country investing by us with local asset management capabilities in key international markets. Assets under management ended the quarter at $734 billion slightly below May's reported high due to the June pullback in equity markets. Average AUM increased almost 6% to $727 billion. The strength of fixed-income flows combined with the pullback in equity markets in June caused the slight mix shift in AUM by investment objective away from equities towards fixed income. The overall attribution of AUM by sales region was essentially unchanged from March, but Europe and Asia continue to be the fastest-growing regions for us, thanks to continued success in countries such as Italy, Switzerland and Taiwan. 
Turning to Slide 8. Net new flows outpaced market appreciation for the second time in the last 5 quarters. Long-term sales reached a new high, as well as this quarter, but the decrease in redemptions was the key driver of improved new flows. Redemptions have been running higher in the past 2 quarters due to some larger than normal institutional redemption activity that we discussed on previous calls. Long-term sales were strong in both the U.S. and internationally. While the Templeton Global Bond Fund remains our best-selling fund in the U.S. and abroad, our global total return fund continues to gain momentum with over $5 billion of net new flows this quarter from the U.S. in CCAP fund. In addition, this quarter, we saw a further diversification of global fixed-income flows from merging markets debt in Asian bond funds attracting a combined $1 billion of net new flows. 
In the U.S., redemptions from our municipal bond funds slowed throughout the quarter. Net outflows totaled $900 million compared to a peak of $3.5 billion in the prior quarter with a few funds returning to positive flows. We continue to actively communicate our perspective on immunity market to financial advisors to help them allay investor concerns, and our straight talk client use immunity brain chart has been one of our most viewed ever. 
Our U.S. institutional business continued to trend up net positive new flows with several new fundings in global equity mandates. More recently, the team is focused on promoting alternative strategies with roadshows highlighting private equity strategies managed by the global fixed-income and emerging markets equity team, as well as hosting a well-received emerging markets real estate roundtable in Chicago. 
Our international business continues to generate impressive growth on our CCAP range of funds of close to $150 billion in AUM at quarter end. As I mentioned earlier, we continue to have success across Europe and Asia and believe that our global presence will continue to be a key driver of future growth. 
One of the success stories has been Malaysia, with $2 billion in AUM and almost 1/3 of that coming from Sharia Investments for Islamic investors. It's been one of our fastest-growing countries, nearly tripling in the past year. We plan to add 3 Sharia funds to our CCAP range in the near future and will register some of our CCAP funds in Malaysia where the retail market to foreign asset managers. 
Turning to Slide 10. Overall equity outflows slowed during the quarter. However, flows were positive in April and May, with flow reversing course in June as the market pulled back and the industry experienced increased redemptions. Long-term sales of both global and U.S. Equity funds declined due to market volatility, but redemptions from global equity had a much more significant decrease from last quarter, and we had a slight in institutional redemptions from sovereign wealth of clients of near $5 billion. Addition to profit-taking we saw last quarter from Asian Growth Fund reversed net funded strong positive net new flows for this quarter. U.S. equity funds saw a modest increase in redemption activity, but funds that have been attracting flows such as the Franklin growth, rising dividends, U.S. opportunities remain in inflows although at a slower pace. We continue to promote the value of long-term investment and equity funds the financial advisors through the global, the new core, which is an expansion of our 2020 vision campaign. Hybrid net new flows were $1.6 billion, a bit of a decrease from last quarter as it did see a slowing of flows to the Franklin Income Fund that attracted $800 million in net new flows between the U.S. and CCAP funds. In April, we launched a new balance strategy to leverage the strengths of our global fixed income and emerging market teams. The Templeton Emerging Markets Balanced Fund was added to our CCAP lineup and is comanaged by Dr. Michael Hassenstub and Dr. Mark Mobius. Core fixed income flows continue to be very strong with net new flows of $20 billion, as I already explained. 
Overall, relative investment performance remains strong, and we saw improvement in the percent of assets in the top 2 quartiles across all the periods. The most significant change from last quarter was the relative performance of the 5-year period due mostly to Templeton growth and each mutual shares performance improvements. Short-term performance from mutual series and our muni funds remain under pressure, however, both have experienced improving performance in recent months. I'll now turn it over to Ken for operating results.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Greg. The strength of the company continues to be reflected in operating results this quarter. Operating income for the quarter was $683 million, which was an 8% increase from the second quarter and a 31% increase from the prior year. Net incom
componenttext:
Thank you, Greg. The strength of the company continues to be reflected in operating results this quarter. Operating income for the quarter was $683 million, which was an 8% increase from the second quarter and a 31% increase from the prior year. Net income for the quarter was flat from quarter 2 at $503 million, but earnings per share increased slightly to $2.26. 
Our share repurchase program continues to enhance our earnings growth on a per share basis by driving the share count down over time. Investment management fees increased 6% this quarter, slightly more than the increase in average assets under management due to 1 more day and $1.7 million of additional performance fees. This was partially offset by slightly lower effect of fee rate that was due to 2 factors. The first was a slight mix shift to fixed income and no change in sales region mix this quarter that highlighted Greg earlier. And the second was that daily average assets under management, which most of our fees are calculated on was a bit lower than the simple monthly average assets under management for the quarter. Looking forward, I want to remind everybody that we did cause on Balance Equity Management acquisition in early July and their assets under management during to lower effective fee rate than the mix we reported to due to the size and nature of their client accounts. And that acquisition will have a small impact on the reported effective fee rate going forward. 
Additionally, in July, Darby's Emerging Market Fund saw its most successful private equity investments to date returning more than 15x its original investment. And in conjunction with the sale, we now expect to earn about $48 million in carried interest, which will between Franklin and the team, which is consistent of imagery practices, and that will drive both performance fees and compensation and general and administrative expenses higher next quarter. Sales and distribution fees increased 6%, consistent with the increase in average assets under management and with sales. The asset base fee that comprises 69% of this line item increased almost 7% due to increased average assets under management and the 1 additional day in the quarter. Sales component increased 4.5% due to the increase in gross sales that made up 11% of total sales. Shareholder servicing fees were $77.5 million, an increase of 2%, which is less than the increase in billboard accounts. Two things contribute to that: first, with the normal mix shift between open and closed accounts that experience throughout the year; and second, is what we've experienced a number of conversions to omnibus accounts that earn lower fees. During the quarter, we purchased 272,000 Canadian closed accounts, and in July, we purchased 2.2 million U.S. accounts that will be reflected in the fourth quarter results. Other net revenue increased $2.4 million dollars this quarter due mostly to increased investment income from consolidated sponsored investment products. Operating expenses increased 4%, which is less than the 6% increase in revenue. Sales, distribution and marketing expense increased 6%, about 70% of this expense is driven by changes in assets under management with just over half coming from outside the United States. 
The asset base component increased 7% to $505 million, and the sales base component also increased 7% to $177 million. The average sales commission decreased 7% to about $38 million. Compensation and benefits was $340 million, a slight decrease from the prior quarter as increased salaries and incentive compensation were more than upset by lower payroll taxes and employee benefit expenses. 
Looking forward to the fourth quarter, we expect this line to increase about 3% to 4%, reflecting increased headcount, that's up 4% since March. And in addition to that, about 1/2 of the expense associated with splitting carried interest with Darby team competition and benefits will run through other expenses. Information systems and technology and occupancy expenses were both relatively flat compared with last quarter, but we do expect technology expense to increase to a level similar to what we saw last September as projects get completed and are expensed in the fourth quarter. General and administrative and other expenses normalized as expected following the large insurance recovery in the prior quarter. Other income was $4.4 million this quarter, a $45 million increase from last quarter. But as you can see from the chart on Slide 17, the impact of consolidated variable interest entities cause designed to be lower, and I'm sure most of you expecting. Please keep in mind that those losses are reversed in the noncontrolling interest line. Otherwise, the biggest difference in the last quarter was about $17 million less of gains from available for sale investments. Gains and losses on the sale of available for sale investments have been running higher than normal in recent quarters and that's due to a blend of reallocating CCAP investment and the rebalancing of some of our corporate investments. Interest expense was a little higher this month due to a modest increase in our tax reserves. 
Turning to Slide 18. The effective tax rate for the quarter came in higher-than-expected due to increase in the fiscal year-to-date rate to 29.1%. The rates been fairly consistent for the past 4 years. We do experience quarterly volatility as foreign service earnings fluctuate. The operating margin for the quarter was 36.8%. Cash and investments was $8.7 billion at June 30, including about $1 billion from variable interest entities. And we repurchased another 1.6 million shares this quarter, decreasing shares outstanding to 220.4 million. Pay ratio for the quarter was 51%, and we remain committed to returning substantial portion of free cash flow to shareholders over time. However, a substantial portion of cash and investments is invested offshore and is used to see new products and is not currently available for repurchase or dividends. And that concludes our commentary on the third quarter results. As always, if you have any questions, please contact Investor Relations or corporate communications. The contact information is located in the presentation and in the press release.

Most importantly, long-term investment performance remains strong across equity and fixed-income strategies, and areas that have been underperforming in the short term have improved. 
Performance, coupled with the debt and breadth of our global advisor relationships, translated into another quarter of record net flows led by the continued strength of our global fixed income franchise. We continue to execute on our long-term strategy of investing in those areas that are complementary to our existing business and strengthen our capabilities in key markets. 
During the quarter, we announced the acquisition of Balanced Equity Management, a well respected institutional manager in Australia. The acquisition closed in early July and is consistent with our strategy to address home country investing buys, with local asset management capabilities in key international markets. 
Assets under management ended the quarter at $734 billion, slightly below May's reported high due to the June pullback in equity markets. Average AUM increased almost 6% to $727 billion. The strength of fixed income flows combined with the pullback in equity markets in June caused the slight mix shift in AUM by investment objective, away from equities towards fixed income. The overall attribution of AUM by sales region was essentially unchanged from March, but Europe and Asia continue to be the fastest-growing regions for us, thanks to continued success in countries such as Italy, Switzerland and Taiwan. 
Turning to Slide 8. Net new flows outpaced market appreciation for the second time in the last 5 quarters. Long-term sales reached a new high, as well this quarter, but the decrease in redemptions was the key driver of improved net new flows. Redemptions had been running higher the past 2 quarters due to some larger-than-normal institutional redemption activity that we've discussed on previous calls. 
Long-term sales were strong in both the U.S. and internationally. While the Templeton Global Bond Fund remains our best-selling fund in the U.S. and abroad, our global total return fund continues to gain momentum with over $5 billion of net new flows this quarter from the U.S. and SICAV funds. In addition, this quarter, we saw further diversification of global fixed income flows from emerging markets debt in Asian bond funds, attracting a combined $1 billion of net new flows. 
In the U.S., redemptions from our municipal bond funds slowed throughout the quarter. Net new outflows totaled $900 million compared to a peak of $3.5 billion in the prior quarter, with the few funds returning to positive flows. We continue to actively communicate our perspective on the muni market to financial advisors to help them allay investor concerns. And our straight-talk, client-used muni brain chart has been one of our most viewed ever. 
Our U.S. institutional business continued the trend  of net positive new flows with several new fundings in global equity mandates. More recently, the team is focused on promoting alternative strategies with roadshows highlighting private equity strategies managed by the global fixed income and emerging markets equity team, as well as hosting a well received emerging markets real estate roundtable in Chicago. 
Our international business continues to generate impressive growth and our SICAV range of funds approached $150 billion in AUM at quarter end. As I mentioned earlier, we continue to have success across Europe and Asia and believe that our global presence will continue to be a key driver of future growth. 
One of those success stories has been Malaysia, with $2 billion in AUM, and almost 1/3 of that coming from Shariah investments for Islamic investors. It's been one of our fastest-growing countries, nearly tripling in the past year. We plan to add 3 Shariah funds to our SICAV range in the near future and will register some of our SICAV funds in Malaysia, where the retail market has recently been opened to foreign asset managers. 
Turning to Slide 10. Overall equity outflows slowed during the quarter. However, flows were positive in April and May, with flow reversing course in June, as the market pulled back and the industry experienced increased redemptions. Long-term sales of both global and U.S. equity funds declined due to market volatility, but redemptions from global equity had a much more significant decrease from last quarter, when we had a spike in institutional redemptions from sovereign wealth clients of near $5 billion. 
In addition, the profit-taking we saw last quarter from the Asian Growth Fund reversed and that funded strong positive net new flows for this quarter. U.S. equity funds saw a modest increase in redemption activity, but funds that have been attracting flows such as the Franklin growth, rising dividends and U.S. opportunities remained in inflows, although at a slower pace. 
We continue to promote the value of long-term investment and equity funds to financial advisors through the global, the new core theme [ph], which is an extension of our 2020 Vision campaign. Hybrid net new flows were $1.6 billion, a bit of a decrease from last quarter as we did see a slowing of flows to the Franklin Income Fund that attracted $800 million in net new flows between the U.S. and SICAV funds. 
In April, we launched a new balance strategy to leverage the strengths of our global fixed income and emerging market teams. The Templeton Emerging Markets balanced fund was added to our SICAV lineup and is comanaged by Dr. Michael Hassenstub and Dr. Mark Mobius. Core fixed income flows continue to be very strong with net new flows of $20 billion, as I already explained. 
Overall, relative investment performance remains strong, and we saw improvement in the percent of assets in the top 2 quartiles across all the periods. The most significant change from the last quarter was the relative performance of the 5-year period, due mostly to Templeton growth and mutual shares performance improvements. Short-term performance from mutual series in our muni funds remain under pressure. However, both have experienced improving performance in recent months. I'll now turn it over to Ken for operating results.

And in conjunction with this sale, we now expect to earn about $48 million in carried interest, which will be split between Franklin and the team, which is consistent with industry practices, and that will drive both performance fees and compensation and general and administrative expenses higher next quarter.

Sales component increased 4.5% due to the increase in commissionable gross sales that made up 11% of total sales.

The asset base component increased 7% to $505 million, and the sales base component also increased 7% to $177 million. The amortization of deferred sales commission decreased 7% to about $38 million. 
Compensation and benefits was $340 million, a slight decrease from the prior quarter, as increased salaries and incentive compensation were more than offset by lower payroll taxes and employee benefit's expenses.  Looking forward to the fourth quarter, we expect this line to increase about 3% to 4%, reflecting increased headcount that's up 4% since March. And in addition to that, about 1/2 of the expense associated with splitting carried interest with the Darby team will through a compensation and benefits, while the other 1/2 will through other expenses. 
Information systems and technology and occupancy expenses were both relatively flat compared with last quarter, but we do expect technology expense to increase to a level similar to what we saw last September, as projects get completed and are expensed in the fourth quarter. 
General, administrative and other expenses normalized as expected following the large insurance recovery in the prior quarter. Other income was $4.4 million this quarter, a $45 million decrease from last quarter. But as you can see from the chart on Slide 17, the impact of consolidated variable interest entities cause this line to be lower, and I'm sure most of you expecting. Please keep in mind that those losses are reversed in the noncontrolling interest line. Otherwise, the biggest difference from last quarter was about $17 million less of gains from available-for-sale investments. 
Realized gains and losses on the sale of available-for-sale investments had been running higher than normal in recent quarters and that's due to a blend of reallocating SICAV investment and the rebalancing of some of our corporate investments. Interest expense was a little higher this month due to a modest increase in our tax reserve. 
Turning to Slide 18. The effective tax rate for the quarter came in higher than expected due to an increase in the fiscal year-to-date rate to 29.1%. The rate's been fairly consistent for the past 4 years. We do experience quarterly volatility as foreign service earnings fluctuate. 
The operating margin for the quarter was 36.8%. Cash and investments was $8.7 billion at June 30, including about $1 billion from variable interest entities. And we repurchased another 1.6 million shares this quarter, decreasing shares outstanding to $220.4 million. Investment management fees increased 6% this quarter, slightly more than the increase in average assets under management due to 1 more day and $1.7 million of additional performance fees. This was partially offset by slightly lower effective fee rate that was due to 2 factors: The first was a slight mix shift to fixed income and no change in sales region mix this quarter that Greg highlighted earlier; and the second was that daily average assets under management, which most of our fees are calculated on, was a bit lower than the simple monthly average assets under management for the quarter. 
Looking forward, I want to remind everybody that we did close on Balance Equity Management acquisition in early July, and their assets under management do have a materially lower effective fee rate than the mix we've reported today due to the size and nature of their client accounts. And that acquisition will have a small impact on the reported effective fee rate going forward. 
Additionally in July, Darby's emerging market fund sold its most successful private equity investments to date, returning more than 15x its original investment. And in conjunction with this sale, we now expect to earn about $48 million in carried interest, which will be split between Franklin and the team, which is consistent with industry practices, and that will drive both performance fees and compensation and general and administrative expenses higher next quarter. 
Sales and distribution fees increased 6%, consistent with the increase in average assets under management and with sales. The asset base fee that comprises 69% of this line item increased almost 7% due to increased average assets under management and the one additional day in the quarter. Sales component increased 4.5% due to the increase in commissionable gross sales that made up 11% of total sales. 
Shareholder servicing fees were $77.5 million, an increase of 2%, which is less than the increase in billable accounts. Two things contribute to that: First, with the normal mix shift between open and closed accounts that we experienced throughout the year; and second is what we've experienced a number of conversions to omnibus accounts that earn lower fees.  During the quarter, we purchased 272,000 Canadian closed accounts and in July, we purchased 2.2 million U.S. accounts that will be reflected in the fourth quarter results. 
Other net revenue increased $2.4 million this quarter due mostly to increased investment income from consolidated sponsored investment products. Operating expenses increased 4%, which is less than the 6% increase in revenue. Sales, distribution and marketing expense increased 6%, about 70% of this expense is driven by changes in assets under management, with just over half coming from outside the United States.  The asset base component increased 7% to $505 million, and the sales base component also increased 7% to $177 million. The amortization of deferred sales commission decreased 7% to about $38 million. 
Compensation and benefits was $314 million, a slight decrease from the prior quarter, as increased salaries and incentive compensation were more than offset by lower payroll taxes and employee benefit's expenses.  Looking forward to the fourth quarter, we expect this line to increase about 3% to 4%, reflecting increased headcount that's up 4% since March. And in addition to that, about 1/2 of the expense associated with splitting carried interest with the Darby team will run through compensation and benefits, while the other 1/2 will run through other expenses. 
Information systems and technology and occupancy expenses were both relatively flat compared with last quarter, but we do expect technology expense to increase to a level similar to what we saw last September, as projects get completed and are expensed in the fourth quarter. 
General, administrative and other expenses normalized as expected following the large insurance recovery in the prior quarter. Other income was $4.4 million this quarter, a $45 million decrease from last quarter. But as you can see from the chart on Slide 17, the impact of consolidated variable interest entities cause this line to be lower than I'm sure most of you expecting. Please keep in mind that those losses are reversed in the noncontrolling interest line. Otherwise, the biggest difference from last quarter was about $17 million less of gains from available-for-sale investments. 
Realized gains and losses on the sale of available-for-sale investments have been running higher than normal in recent quarters and that's due to a blend of reallocating SICAV investment and the rebalancing of some of our corporate investments. Interest expense was a little higher this month due to a modest increase in our tax reserve. 
Turning to Slide 18. The effective tax rate for the quarter came in higher than expected due to an increase in the fiscal year-to-date rate to 29.1%. The rate's been fairly consistent for the past 4 years. We do experience quarterly volatility as foreign service earnings fluctuate. 
The operating margin for the quarter was 36.8%. Cash and investments was $8.7 billion at June 30, including about $1 billion from variable interest entities. And we repurchased another 1.6 million shares this quarter, decreasing shares outstanding to $220.4 million. Payout ratio for the quarter was 51%, and we remain committed to returning substantial portion of free cash flow to shareholders over time.  However, a substantial portion of cash and investments is invested offshore and is used to see new products and is not currently available for repurchase or dividends. 
Well, that concludes our commentary on the third quarter results. As always, if you have any questions, please contact Investor Relations or Corporate Communications. Their contact information is located in the presentation and in the press release.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Conference Call for the Quarter ended June 30, 2011. My name is Christine, and I will be today's facilitator.
Statements made in this conference call regarding Franklin Resources Inc. which are not historical facts are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent findings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the Risk Factors and MD&A section of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K filing. [Operator Instructions] Now like to turn the call over to Mr. Greg Johnson, Chief Financial Officer. You may begin.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone. Thanks for taking time out of your day to join Ken Lewis and I for this call. Today, we reported a very strong quarter of flows and operating results that continue to illustrate the key strengths of our organization. On a sad n
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone. Thanks for taking time out of your day to join Ken Lewis and I for this call. Today, we reported a very strong quarter of flows and operating results that continue to illustrate the key strengths of our organization. 
On a sad note, we lost our friend, Peter Sasser, who passed away over the weekend. Peter was a member of the Franklin Resources Board of Directors since 1993, has 17-year tenure on our Board, gave us great perspective and helped guide our business, strategy and culture. He will be missed by all who had the honor of working with him. And now I'd like to open it up for your questions.

componenttext: Well, I would say that we're looking at it. componenttext: Okay. headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think one of our goals this year is to offer tactical asset allocation funds, multi-asset strategy funds. And we're getting very close to doing that. And I think we just offered, or we just included one in our cab fund. So will be a suite that thos
componenttext: Yes, I think one of our goals this year is to offer tactical asset allocation funds, multi-asset strategy funds. And we're getting very close to doing that. And I think we just offered, or we just included one in our cab fund. So will be a suite that those asset allocation funds will use, and we anticipate those offerings in the United States towards the end of this year.

componenttext: First, can you maybe just give us an update on where you stand on the institutional channel in terms of the pipeline activity levels and maybe allocation trends? And then just a follow-up on kind of the alternatives front. It sounds like you're maybe pushing those capabilities a bit more in the institutional. So any color on initial client interest for those strategies as well?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, first of all, not a whole lot of changes within the institutional channel. I think some of the pressure in prior quarters, we've seen the dramatic turnaround in Templeton's performance, has taken some of the pressure off the institutional a
componenttext: Well, I think, first of all, not a whole lot of changes within the institutional channel. I think some of the pressure in prior quarters, we've seen the dramatic turnaround in Templeton's performance, has taken some of the pressure off the institutional accounts where we had we had some large redemptions 2 quarters ago. So we don't see any of that activity. We actually saw some increases to existing accounts over the quarter. I think the activity was pretty consistent with what we've seen, as well as the pipeline. It seems the global aggregates and some low duration type fixed income. Some specialty China equities and India equities, nothing really unusual. So global equity continues to probably lead the number of searches, as well as global aggregate and the pipeline now still looks relatively good. I think the positive development, as I've mentioned, is just the Templeton turnaround. That's where the majority of institutional assets are. I think on the alternative side, you're probably referring to maybe the global summits effort and the hedge fund that we've been talking about with our global bond group. And that's something we are out there talking about, and the there a longer lead time. And in that category, we don't expect to get the large assets quickly, but it is getting a positive reception out there. And outside of that, I think it's really the development on the retail side of these asset allocation funds using some alternatives within them that, hopefully, will be well-received in the retail channel.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: Well, I think one of the things we consider is, typically, in the first r quarter, we have some seasonal uptick across most of the expense categories. So I think it would be reasonable to expect that next quarter. But -- and certainly, there has been a lot of discussions about investing in the company and making strategic investments, certain expense line items. But overall, I think it's a measured pace, and I don't think you're going to see any large spike ups in the overall spending levels. So yes, you can overlay that with whatever assumption you want to make on the revenue.

componenttext: Okay. Well, yes, so I think the guidance, and just to be clear, I did mention 2 things that could impact that line. And I think, as we've been doing over several years, we'll continue to do in terms of adding, secondly, that we try to focus obviously in the low cost jurisdictions, And then we've been pretty successful in doing that. So that has, over time, that has the impact of lowering the fixed component and increasing the variability, which is what you want to do in this business.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my follow-up question is staying on the theme of margins. As your non-U.S. business continues to grow, and I probably ask this question every call, so I apologize for repeating myself. But as I look of the distribution margin, it looks like it g
componenttext: Okay. And my follow-up question is staying on the theme of margins. As your non-U.S. business continues to grow, and I probably ask this question every call, so I apologize for repeating myself. But as I look of the distribution margin, it looks like it got a little bit more negative, if you will, maybe simplistic. But how does the overall impact on the margins play out, if the non-U,S. business continues to outgrow the United States?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: The general --  it had, the general answer hasn't changed. There's obviously over simplification. But in terms of overall profitability, U.S., non-U.S. is more or less the same. And that is because the U.S. is more developed market. And while certain aspe
componenttext: The general --  it had, the general answer hasn't changed. There's obviously over simplification. But in terms of overall profitability, U.S., non-U.S. is more or less the same. And that is because the U.S. is more developed market. And while certain aspects of the non-U.S. market are more profitable, we're obviously in kind of startup mode in other markets. So they tend to offset. And on balance, the profitability tends to be the same. The mix between, in this quarter, between the U.S. non-U.S. really didn't change that much, So in terms of the distribution margin, it wasn't too much of a change. But it depends how you're calculating distribution margin. And I think what we tried to do with the disclosures and get off of that concept and just kind of look at distribution revenue and the assets, component of the distribution revenue versus sales component and similarly, on the expense side, looking at the assets component the expense, sale component of the expenses, as well as the amortization of deferred commissions, which are pretty well highlighted in our Q, which I might has filed today.

componenttext: Well, I think we have stated over the last year or two, the area that has been new for us has been the global Ag in emerging markets, and that's we have had significant wins. I don't know what gross numbers is today, but it certainly has contributed. But the majority of the flows are going into the retail global bond fund, as well as the U.S. retail global bond fund.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And that's kind of what I was thinking. And I guess, as a follow-up to that, how effective then has been sort of the 2020 Vision program that you guys launched? And how much of you really tweaked that? And has any of the tweaks that you've done over
componenttext: Okay. And that's kind of what I was thinking. And I guess, as a follow-up to that, how effective then has been sort of the 2020 Vision program that you guys launched? And how much of you really tweaked that? And has any of the tweaks that you've done over the past 2 years enhanced the fixed income flows?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the market share and one of our priorities, obviously, when you look at our asset mix and you say, "Well, Frank was underweighted and U.S. large-cap growth, the U.S. growth in general. And we've always said that we were out there looking for
componenttext: Well, I think the market share and one of our priorities, obviously, when you look at our asset mix and you say, "Well, Frank was underweighted and U.S. large-cap growth, the U.S. growth in general. And we've always said that we were out there looking for a group, we probably one of the best groups internally and we just have to get that message out. So that's been a big part of the 2020 Vision campaign. I think if you look for us, at the market share gains, and it's coming, it's somewhat gets lost when you look at the global bond funds, but we have made significant progress. And I think more importantly, we've got a lot of those funds on investment only platforms that should drive sales, and that's been one of the metrics that we're very focused on, and we know that, that's the retirement areas where you gain those equity sales and they're very steady. So we hope to continue to do that. And we feel it's been very successful, and we also feel going out and talking about 2020, you don't just look at the net result quickly and equity sales, you look at the kind of response you get from your partner with the partnership with the financial advisors and you give them tools, whether the Franklin fund or something else, to sit down with their clients and keep people invested at a difficult time. And that's really what we're trying to do on the marketing side and the value-added side. I think we feel like we have made good progress, and Franklin continues to grow relative to its competitors. But it's been a very difficult asset category over the last few years.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: You guys have been doing a good job. I mean, it seems to me like giving the touch points and being out there, I mean, you don't want to have sort of the long-term ability to drive the equity inflows once it does shift. But just wondering how much of an im
componenttext: You guys have been doing a good job. I mean, it seems to me like giving the touch points and being out there, I mean, you don't want to have sort of the long-term ability to drive the equity inflows once it does shift. But just wondering how much of an impact that was having on the fixed income flows as well? And it seems like just that touch point with the advisors is doing it.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Michael Carrier from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Michael Carrier from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ken, just one of your comments on the prerecorded call, you said that it relates to the Darby on the performance piece. Just want to make sure I'm clear. You said the $48 million, and then in terms of the expenses related to that, I think in the past, whe
componenttext: Ken, just one of your comments on the prerecorded call, you said that it relates to the Darby on the performance piece. Just want to make sure I'm clear. You said the $48 million, and then in terms of the expenses related to that, I think in the past, when would have had these, I think the margin was somewhere around 40%, 50% but I just wanted to make sure? And then just in terms of the mix, in terms of comp, and then other, any granularity there? And the comp side, when you said up to 3% to 4%, I just want to make sure that's the core comp? And then you had the performance fee impact as well?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: You're exactly right. So the economics are about 40% to 50%. So just to do simple math. You can do the 50% and then split that in half between what runs through comps and what runs through other expenses. So and my comment about 3% to 4% was exclusive of
componenttext: You're exactly right. So the economics are about 40% to 50%. So just to do simple math. You can do the 50% and then split that in half between what runs through comps and what runs through other expenses. So and my comment about 3% to 4% was exclusive of the Darby transaction. It was just kind of run rate increases that we're seeing. So 3% to 4%, plus call it, 12-ish on the comp line for the Darby piece.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then, Greg, just in terms of some of the products, I think when we look at the flows into the global fixed income products, it's still that $20 billion. It seems impressive. It's just more where are these flows coming from. So if
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then, Greg, just in terms of some of the products, I think when we look at the flows into the global fixed income products, it's still that $20 billion. It seems impressive. It's just more where are these flows coming from. So if you can provide any granularity, whether it's by the regions, on the distribution side, any color on the institutional side, that's helpful. And then on the multi-asset strategy theme, I think you made some hires. Just in terms of your outlook, what do you guys trying to accomplish there? It sounds like you're seeing some traction there. But just wanted to see what the outlook is over the next 6 to 12 months.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, first of all, the global bond funds flows. And I think if you look at the world and what money funds are paying today, and then you couple that with the concern over your own currency or your own sovereign debt and you may have individuals
componenttext: Well, I think, first of all, the global bond funds flows. And I think if you look at the world and what money funds are paying today, and then you couple that with the concern over your own currency or your own sovereign debt and you may have individuals and worth investors that have a lot invested in their own sovereign debt, in markets like Italy, where we've seen tremendous growth over the last couple of years, it's just the way for those high worth investors diversify some of the more conservative holdings. And I think we've been in a key position because we've had good relationships with the big banks and those that represent a lot of those high networks investors. And obviously, it had very strong, consistent performance with that group. And that's really led to those flows. And that's why I think that, that trend should continue in the near-term because I don't think any of the debt noise and all the sovereign debt issues that are out there are going to go away any time soon. And that's been the case in the U.S. as well, where it's a relatively new category for the retail investor. People are concerned about rates going up. People are concerned about the economy. And this is somewhat of an alternative asset class, where they can get gains from growth in other economies and other stronger currencies. So again, it's just a way to diversify lower risk in a portfolio, and it's gone from 0 to some percentage, it's still very low in the average holder and one that we think will continue to grow. But it's areas in Europe where Switzerland, we're always seeing the growth, as well as Italy for the European market. And then, obviously, a lot of it here in the United States.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: Okay. And then anything on the multi-asset strategy side?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: So I think it's early. And I don't think we -- obviously, this is a huge category for the industry, one that we think we're very well-positioned, as far as all of the breadth of our product line and different styles, that it's a natural extension of what
componenttext: So I think it's early. And I don't think we -- obviously, this is a huge category for the industry, one that we think we're very well-positioned, as far as all of the breadth of our product line and different styles, that it's a natural extension of what we do. And I think having that inflation piece in a portfolio is very important to what advisors and investors are looking for today. So I don't know how -- we don't really put a number out there. But if you look at the kind of growth in the industry with 3 or 4 big players, hopefully, we'll get a piece of that.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: The next question comes from Robert Lee from KBW.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: I just wonder could we maybe just drill down a tiny bit into the global bonds product $185 billion of assets. And obviously, the Templeton global bond price the biggest chunk of that. But you have been talking about the emerging markets product. I guess it's the global Ag and maybe some other things. Just trying to get a better feel of the additional growth, what proportion of that $180 million in change would be kind to global, come from global bond strategy? And what are of the other kind of big chunks within that?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the bulk is the global bonds, and that's probably around $120 billion out of the total. The other big fund is the global total return fund, which just this quarter, had $4.8 billion in net inflows versus $2.5 billion. And I don't have the current si
componenttext: Well, the bulk is the global bonds, and that's probably around $120 billion out of the total. The other big fund is the global total return fund, which just this quarter, had $4.8 billion in net inflows versus $2.5 billion. And I don't have the current size of that fund, but that would be the next big category. And the one that's going faster than the global bond. And obviously, you have more capacity in the total return just because it's a broader mandate with corporate. But again, I go back to the other question that our team gets quite a bit on size and those currency markets and sovereign debt of the largest markets in the world. And trillions of dollars are represented in that zone. If there's any area where you can increase the size of a fund and not inhibit the management, it would be in that category.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just curious, you, I guess, closed or shortly closing your on the balance asset managers in Australia. Obviously, it's an institutional account. But maybe can you talk about in terms of their scale and kind of the strategy there? I think,
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just curious, you, I guess, closed or shortly closing your on the balance asset managers in Australia. Obviously, it's an institutional account. But maybe can you talk about in terms of their scale and kind of the strategy there? I think, if I remember from the press release, it's around $11 billion of assets? And then maybe a little update on where that business is going?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, the Australia market is dominated by the superannuation and probably around 1/3 of that the market is Australian inequity. So 35%. So we felt it was important. I mean, that's such a strong growth area, and it's now increased from 10% to 12% m
componenttext: Yes, I mean, the Australia market is dominated by the superannuation and probably around 1/3 of that the market is Australian inequity. So 35%. So we felt it was important. I mean, that's such a strong growth area, and it's now increased from 10% to 12% mandated into these funds. And it's a lion's share the market. I mean, there's not really an addressable market. It's superannuation, really, is the market. So that means lower fees than you normally going to see because it's institutionally driven, but very cost efficient and still very high margin at the lower fees. So for us, it strengthens our position in the market, where we think the other areas will continue to grow, like global equities. Obviously, Australia has had a tremendous run with the currency, commodities, China, and that's probably created more of a bias towards the local market, and that'll turn at some point. And It'll just strengthen our position by having that local businesses, where we can bring an the other funds over time as well to one of the largest markets in the world.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: Yes, I should've -- actually, I missed that, Ken, thanks for pointing that out. The munis were $3.5 billion in net redemptions in the prior quarter and $900 million this quarter. So that's a dramatic turnaround. And same with the Asian growth, where they had a very choppy quarter. Last quarter, actually, was in outflows and inflows this quarter $750 million. And that was really because of the slowdown in redemptions. So those were the 2 big drivers, munis and Asian growth outside of the other ones that we talked talking about for the sovereign debt fund, sovereign debt funds.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. I appreciate that. And then, even as your cash balances build, I've noticed the lower gains this quarter, but in general, the other income line was pretty small relative to last appears in the past, especially as your cash is building. Anything spec
componenttext: Okay. I appreciate that. Anything specific in there on the negative front as a headwind that isn't perfectly clear to us?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say the highlight is kind of more accounting driven, if you will. First, you have the consolidated densities that had much bigger negative this quarter. And most of that is offset on the, below the net income line for the noncontrolling inter
componenttext: Yes, I would say the highlight is kind of more accounting driven, if you will. First, you have the consolidated densities that had much bigger negative this quarter. And most of that is offset on the, below the net income line for the noncontrolling interests. If you look at -- there's been no real change in even year-over-year on the core dividend interest category, which is, I guess, roughly around $10 million the quarter. And then the rest of that variability is either due to the accounting or the markets, or resulting from gains that we take. So there's 2 things that drives the variability, there's the mark-to-market. And we have, it's in the file about $900 million of trading securities that will get marked and which kind of show you what category investments therein. And then, also, we have the consolidated BIEs that don't affect the bottom line, but certainly do introduce volatility into this particular line item.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then final question, as cash build, some version of the same question we always ask every quarter. Payout ratio used to be 90%-ish. It's been 50%-ish, a little more for the last 4 quarters. Just curious, I've covered you guys for a long time, so it's
componenttext: And then final question, as cash build, some version of the same question we always ask every quarter. Payout ratio used to be 90%-ish. It's been 50%-ish, a little more for the last 4 quarters. Just curious, I've covered you guys for a long time, so it's consistent, or inconsistently consistent returning. And so I still have confidence that it will continue to be that. But I'm just curious on what in recent times would you be saving such a war chest on? I mean, fuel front, conservatism, balance sheet consolidation, just curious on what goes on in your mind?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, when we look at it, sort of kind of a multifaceted discussion. But certainly, keep in mind that a lot of the cash is outside the U.S. Also, we do utilize a lot of cash for product development, and probably more so than any of our peers in the industr
componenttext: Yes, when we look at it, sort of kind of a multifaceted discussion. But certainly, keep in mind that a lot of the cash is outside the U.S. Also, we do utilize a lot of cash for product development, and probably more so than any of our peers in the industry. And that pays off. If you look at it sort of as R&D spend, which is investing back in the business. So I mean, those are kind of the 2 major factors. So we balance that with returning capital shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. And I guess, you can see from our historic record that it's been the focus. But very much a balancing act, and not much has really changed.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I do think we do have a very experienced Board, and they see the benefit of having a very conservative balance sheet. And it's kind of an intangible out there, that's the high rating for an asset manager. When you get in difficult markets, like we hav
componenttext: And I do think we do have a very experienced Board, and they see the benefit of having a very conservative balance sheet. And it's kind of an intangible out there, that's the high rating for an asset manager. When you get in difficult markets, like we have over the last few years, we think it's one of the big reasons why we've been able to come out of that stronger than we came into it. And it is important to clients to have that strong balance sheet because they don't really want to invest in companies where they're worried about how they're going to survive a big downturn in the market. So I think that's an intangible that still is very important in why we will always generally be looked at as too conservative of the balance sheet. But I think the Board is still going to look at tax issues and things and all those things around special dividends are always out there.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Jeff Hopson from Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: The next question comes from Jeff Hopson from Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: You referenced your recent success with the global total return bond front. Curious if those flows are coming from the same types of customers, channels, countries as the other global fixed income product? And just curious of your thoughts as far as, ulti
componenttext: You referenced your recent success with the global total return bond front. Curious if those flows are coming from the same types of customers, channels, countries as the other global fixed income product? And just curious of your thoughts as far as, ultimately, the size of that product versus the other ones, or the other big fund of is there any reason why it couldn't be bigger? Or do you think because of the credit risk, it will probably be smaller? Or any thoughts on that?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's nowhere near the concern on size at this point. And it does have a broader mandate to generally invest in if you call, want to call it more mid-cap type securities than the big sovereign debt global bond fund. So probably, from that perspecti
componenttext: I think it's nowhere near the concern on size at this point. And it does have a broader mandate to generally invest in if you call, want to call it more mid-cap type securities than the big sovereign debt global bond fund. So probably, from that perspective, you would be somewhat limited by size, where you wouldn't be in the other fun, but I'm not sure what number and how far that has to go before that's a concert because you're investing in corporate, as well as sovereign debt. I think the market is really the same for both. I think some -- this one is viewed as a little bit more aggressive and has that a little bit better return because of that. But as far as how it's being sold, we're seeing the sales at the same markets. One of the markets that I didn't mention earlier, in addition to Switzerland, would be Germany. Again, a market that we've been telling a story for a long time. But with the recent concerns around the Euro, again, which is all new in the last year or two, we've seen significant flows out of Germany into these funds as well.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from Cynthia Mayer from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess just a quick follow-up on that. The $5 billion of flows to the global total return really seems huge. And it seems like it was mostly from overseas. I'm wondering if all of the worries over sovereign debt have some people moving out of a severance
componenttext: I guess just a quick follow-up on that. The $5 billion of flows to the global total return really seems huge. And it seems like it was mostly from overseas. I'm wondering if all of the worries over sovereign debt have some people moving out of a severance fund and into that fund? Do you have any sense of exchanges, for instance?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that if someone was concerned about sovereign debt, they'd probably get out of both funds. I think it's more the -- we've kind of lead with the global bond, and then they've seen that they can get some incremental return and maybe telling the
componenttext: Yes, I think that if someone was concerned about sovereign debt, they'd probably get out of both funds. I think it's more the -- we've kind of lead with the global bond, and then they've seen that they can get some incremental return and maybe telling the story around global total return in addition to the global bond fund. But I just haven't heard that, and that you could be right, Cynthia, I just haven't heard if that's the case, people looking to go out to diversify more away from this sovereign debt.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess just a follow-up to the discussion of the home country investing bias. You mentioned Australia is an example of that. And just in general, should we think about as a phenomenon of that's typical wherever you have a local market that
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess just a follow-up to the discussion of the home country investing bias. You mentioned Australia is an example of that. And just in general, should we think about as a phenomenon of that's typical wherever you have a local market that's usually outperforming the rest of the world. But basically, people will invest at home until they discover their home markets under performing? And if that's true, I mean, should we assume that it's a little harder for you to sell in countries where the local markets really outperforming, and that's the kind of place where you would look for local manager if you thought it was sustainable?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think that's exactly right. It's almost impossible, especially if you have a newer market that's been up, like in India or China, over the last decade, relative to other markets. It becomes very difficult to come in there and sell other fun
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think that's exactly right. It's almost impossible, especially if you have a newer market that's been up, like in India or China, over the last decade, relative to other markets. It becomes very difficult to come in there and sell other funds. So -- but we also know that over time, that will change. And it always does. And there's every country you can look at. Now it's the case, really, in the U.S., you could argue for a while the U.S. market was doing very well, and people feel like they needed additional risk, and then kind of reversed. So that's a fair statement.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: Okay. And just maybe one more follow-up. The global as the new core. That campaign, is that a U.S. campaign or is that all over?

componenttext: Okay. And then, I mean, have you seen any incremental interest? I know you had a choppy quarter or two. componenttext: Well, I think we are anticipating that. And we see the slowdown in the redemption rates.
