But hopefully, the Templeton growth and foreign funds can pick up that flag.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just a follow-up, have you guys given any consideration to raising the dividend sum more consistent basis? It does seem like you guys, obviously, have a preferable bias towards buybacks. But I look at your cash and I can appreciate it's a big pie
componenttext: And then just a follow-up, have you guys given any consideration to raising the dividend sum more consistent basis? It does seem like you guys, obviously, have a preferable bias towards buybacks. But I look at your cash and I can appreciate it's a big piece international. But when I look at your dividend yield, relative to firms, which you guys are doing dramatically better than it just continues to jump at me, is just alarming low. So I'm just curious on your thoughts there.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, our focus has been on institutionally growing dividend. And I think you could solid growth rating, company also grows quickly. So which is a good problem to have. But if you kind of look at our historical growth in dividend, it's pretty healthy. I he
componenttext: Yes, our focus has been on institutionally growing dividend. And I think you could solid growth rating, company also grows quickly. So which is a good problem to have. But if you kind of look at our historical growth in dividend, it's pretty healthy. I hear you on the yield. But that's because I think it's mostly a function of the company growing very quickly.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Marc Irizarry from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Next question comes from Marc Irizarry from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greg, I wonder if you can just speak a little bit to the concentration of flows? And then also, the new some of the new products that you tend to launch? Maybe of the multi-asset class and asset allocation product. Are you concerned about the overconcentr
componenttext: Greg, I wonder if you can just speak a little bit to the concentration of flows? And then also, the new some of the new products that you tend to launch? Maybe of the multi-asset class and asset allocation product. Are you concerned about the overconcentration of flows in global bond? And how much do you think, or how quickly do you think you can get some new products out there to sort of get?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: So again, I think, like anything, you always have to take a step back from flows before you draw the conclusion that the only thing that people are interested in Franklin Templeton is global bond. I mean, that's a big portion of your net number. But on th
componenttext: So again, I think, like anything, you always have to take a step back from flows before you draw the conclusion that the only thing that people are interested in Franklin Templeton is global bond. I mean, that's a big portion of your net number. But on the gross basis, it's not nearly as concerning, when you look at the amount being sold in all the other areas. So I think the key strengths, and you know better than I. the flows in the industry and the pressure, the traditional equity, managers are under and especially domestic equity managers, you can have very strong gross sales and still have fairly large net redemptions. And that's been a headwind for everyone. So we have been consistent about pounding the messaging on our other funds. We feel like we're making good headway, we're making progress in market share, but that's not going to show up on a net flow number until those flows really turn around the other way. So I don't -- I'm not that concerned. I think, I still feel there's things that get lost in the shuffle. I mean, we've raised $1 billion in Shariah compliance funds. We're offering new funds there. That's an exciting new area for us. We've talked about the tactical asset allocation. That's another huge category that we think we could get nice momentum. And I think the seeds that we planted in place with the long-term records on the Franklin growth funds, should put us in great position when that turns around. So again, you look at the gross trends, I don't get nearly as concerned as the net numbers get reported.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just in terms of U.S. retail contribution, are you seeing some incremental pressure on fees or maybe demands from the U.S. distribution channel? And then outside the U.S., are you seeing maybe some areas where the architecture sort of open
componenttext: Great. And then just in terms of U.S. retail contribution, are you seeing some incremental pressure on fees or maybe demands from the U.S. distribution channel? And then outside the U.S., are you seeing maybe some areas where the architecture sort of opening up a little bit at the or competition is?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think those trends are always in place in your distribution, and that's going to, hopefully, find an equilibrium, and the pressures is always going to be on that side. But I wouldn't say if anything new or anything that's changed because there are
componenttext: Well, I think those trends are always in place in your distribution, and that's going to, hopefully, find an equilibrium, and the pressures is always going to be on that side. But I wouldn't say if anything new or anything that's changed because there are some other consolidation and I always one of the concerns out there. So -- and then internationally, I would say the same. I think there's always pressure, there's always new competitors coming in. But it's a very difficult in these markets. And I think the consistency of Franklin Templeton has been there through the ups and downs had served us very well with those relationships. And it's very hard to come in and think you're going to get shelf space or get distribution quickly because you've got the next new hot fund. And we spent a lot of years building relationships in those markets, and then happen to have the right timing with the Global Bond Fund, where we're able to leverage those. But that was a decade of work to get there for the last few years.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Conference Call for the Quarter ended June 30, 2011. My name is Christine, and I will be today's facilitator.Statements made in this conference call regarding Franklin Resources Inc., which are
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Conference Call for the Quarter ended June 30, 2011. My name is Christine, and I will be today's facilitator.
Statements made in this conference call regarding Franklin Resources Inc., which are not historical facts, are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the Risk Factors and MD&A section of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K filing. [Operator Instructions] Now I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Greg Johnson, Chief Executive Officer. You may begin.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone. Thanks for taking time out of your day to join Ken Lewis and I for this call. Today, we reported a very strong quarter of flows and operating results that continue to illustrate the key strengths of our organization. On a sad n
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone. Thanks for taking time out of your day to join Ken Lewis and I for this call. Today, we reported a very strong quarter of flows and operating results that continue to illustrate the key strengths of our organization. 
On a sad note, we lost our friend, Peter Sacerdote, who passed away over the weekend. Peter was a member of the Franklin Resources Board of Directors since 1993, a 17-year tenure on our board, gave us great perspective as he helped guide our business, strategy and culture. He will be missed by all who had the honor of working with him. 
And now I'd like to open it up for your questions.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Roger Freeman from Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Roger Freeman from Barclays.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess first, on the -- your European business. You probably -- I heard in the comments that -- the investment made on earnings call about looking to outsource their transfer agent function over there. And I wanted to see what your views on that were, gi
componenttext: I guess first, on the -- your European business. You probably -- I heard in the comments that -- the investment made on earnings call about looking to outsource their transfer agent function over there. And I wanted to see what your views on that were, given that you've got a reasonable presence in Europe. Do you find -- do you see the pending regulatory changes there as an impediment of doing business with your structure today?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that we're looking at it. And I think we do have somewhat different business models with respect to the amount of assets held in U.K. and Europe with our respect -- with our CCAB Funds [ph] that are $150 billion. We don't have a lot of U
componenttext: Well, I would say that we're looking at it. And I think we do have somewhat different business models with respect to the amount of assets held in U.K. and Europe with our respect -- with our CCAB Funds [ph] that are $150 billion. We don't have a lot of U.K. assets. We have the recent acquisition. It's not on our system at this point. So it's something we're going to look at. But at this stage, we don't anticipate any changes.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, secondly, just with respect to alternatives, I wanted to see if we could get an update on the -- and with the Pelagos acquisition late last year, what your thoughts are around that enabling you to offer any kind of alternative pro
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, secondly, just with respect to alternatives, I wanted to see if we could get an update on the -- and with the Pelagos acquisition late last year, what your thoughts are around that enabling you to offer any kind of alternative product and our Cordiac Fund [ph]. You'd said at the time it might take 12 months to figure out if there's a way to get an update 6 months into it.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, yes, one of our goals this year is to offer tactical asset allocation funds, multi-asset strategy funds. And we're getting very close to doing that. And I think we just offered or we just included one in our CCAB Fund [ph]. So Pelagos would
componenttext: Yes, I think, yes, one of our goals this year is to offer tactical asset allocation funds, multi-asset strategy funds. And we're getting very close to doing that. And I think we just offered or we just included one in our CCAB Fund [ph]. So Pelagos would be a sleeves that those asset allocation funds will use, and we anticipate those offerings in the United States towards the end of this year.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: The next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, can you maybe just give us an update on where you stand on the institutional channel in terms of the pipeline activity levels and maybe allocation trends? And then just a follow-up on kind of the alternatives front. It sounds like you're maybe push
componenttext: First, can you maybe just give us an update on where you stand on the institutional channel in terms of the pipeline activity levels and maybe allocation trends? And then just a follow-up on kind of the alternatives front. It sounds like you're maybe pushing those capabilities a bit more in the institutional. So any color on initial client interest for those strategies as well.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, first of all, not a whole lot of changes within the institutional channel. I think some of the pressure in prior quarters, we seem -- the dramatic turnaround in Templeton's performance has taken some of the pressure off the institutional ac
componenttext: Well, I think, first of all, not a whole lot of changes within the institutional channel. I think some of the pressure in prior quarters, we seem -- the dramatic turnaround in Templeton's performance has taken some of the pressure off the institutional accounts, where we had we had some large redemptions 2 quarters ago. So we don't see any of that activity. We actually saw some increases to existing accounts over the quarter. I think the activity was pretty consistent with what we've seen as well as the pipeline. It seems the global aggregates, some low duration type fixed income, some specialty China equities and India equities, nothing really unusual. So global equity continues to probably lead the number of searches as well as global aggregate, and the pipeline now still looks relatively good. And I think we -- I think the positive development, as I mentioned, is just the Templeton turnaround. That's where the majority of the institutional assets are. I think on the alternative side, you're probably referring to maybe the global summits effort and the hedge fund that we've been talking about with our global bond group. And that's something we are out there talking about, and it was a longer lead time in that category. We don't expect to get large assets quickly, but it is getting a positive reception out there. And outside of that, I think it's really the development on the retail side of these asset allocation funds using some alternatives within them that hopefully will be well received in the retail channel.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe just a question for Ken. It seems like despite a less favorable AUM mix, you continue to hold the line here on expenses so driving margins higher. So I know you guys gave us some guidance on a few expense line items for next quarter.
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe just a question for Ken. It seems like despite a less favorable AUM mix, you continue to hold the line here on expenses so driving margins higher. So I know you guys gave us some guidance on a few expense line items for next quarter. But just assuming flows and revenues continue to trend higher, and just curious to get your take on how much more margin upside you think we can see from here.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think one of the things to consider is, typically, in the fourth quarter, we have some seasonal uptick across most of the expense categories. So I think it would be reasonable to expect that next quarter, but -- and certainly, there has been a lot
componenttext: Well, I think one of the things to consider is, typically, in the fourth quarter, we have some seasonal uptick across most of the expense categories. So I think it would be reasonable to expect that next quarter, but -- and certainly, there has been a lot of discussions about investing in the company and making strategic investments in certain expense line items. But overall, I think it's a measured pace, and I don't think you're going to see any large spike ups in the overall spending levels. So, yes, you can overlay that with whatever assumption you want to make on the revenue.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: The next question comes from Bill Katz from Citigroup.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: Just want to come back to your guidance into the fiscal fourth quarter. Just on the compensation side, just sort of curious, to the extent that your relative performance has bounced back, particularly some of the longer durations that you called out in the press release and your prepared remarks, would there be any potential pressure there? Or to ask another way, what relief vows could you maybe pull, if you will, to maybe offset some of that pressure, if any?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Basic question is in terms of comp, your guidance is probably a little better than people in the moment were anticipating, I would presume, in their expectations. So given the improvement in relative performances, so I'm wondering, is there any upward bia
componenttext: Basic question is in terms of comp, your guidance is probably a little better than people in the moment were anticipating, I would presume, in their expectations. So given the improvement in relative performances, so I'm wondering, is there any upward bias to that compensation? And if so, are there other areas of the firm that you could offset some of that wage inflation away?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Oh, okay. Well, yes, so I think in the guidance, and just to be clear, I did mention 2 things that could impact that line. One is just a general upward bias, and I think we were thinking in the term -- in the near term, about 3% to 4%. That factors in inc
componenttext: Oh, okay. Well, yes, so I think in the guidance, and just to be clear, I did mention 2 things that could impact that line. One is just a general upward bias, and I think we were thinking in the term -- in the near term, about 3% to 4%. That factors in increased headcount that also factors in expectations around variable compensation. And I think as we've been doing over several years, we'll continue to do in terms of adding, secondly, that we try to focus obviously in the low cost jurisdictions. And then we've been pretty successful in doing that. And so that has -- over time, that has the impact of lowering the fixed component and increasing the variability, which is what you want to do in this business.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And my follow-up question is staying on the theme of margins. As your non-U.S. business continues to grow, and I probably asked this question before, so I apologize for repeating myself. But as I look at the distribution margin, it l
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And my follow-up question is staying on the theme of margins. As your non-U.S. business continues to grow, and I probably asked this question before, so I apologize for repeating myself. But as I look at the distribution margin, it looks like it got a little bit more negative, if you will, maybe always simplistic. But how does the overall impact on the margins play out if the non-U.S. business continues to outgrow the United States?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, should you ask that? All right. Not just you, but I don't think get [ph] that question. The general -- it had -- the general answer hasn't changed. There's -- it's obviously over simplification. But in terms of overall profitability, U.S., non-U.S. i
componenttext: Yes, should you ask that? All right. Not just you, but I don't think get [ph] that question. The general -- it had -- the general answer hasn't changed. There's -- it's obviously over simplification. But in terms of overall profitability, U.S., non-U.S. is more or less the same. And that is because in the -- the U.S. is more a developed market. And while certain aspects of the non-U.S. market are more profitable, we're obviously in kind of startup mode in other markets. So they tend to offset. And on balance, the profitability tends to be the same. The mix between -- in this quarter, between the U.S. non-U.S. really didn't change that much. So in terms of the distribution margin, it wasn't too much of a change. But it depends how you're calculating distribution margin. And I think what we tried to do with the disclosures is kind off of that concept and just kind of look at distribution revenue and the assets -- component of the distribution revenue versus sales component and the -- similarly on the expense side, looking at the assets, component of the expense, the sale component of expense as well as the amortization of deferred commissions, which are pretty well highlighted in our Q which, I might add, was filed today.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: The next question comes from Ken Worthington from JPMorgan.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

And what kind of distribution should we expect over the next 6 months to 1 year out of the Darby and I guess all the other related investment product funds?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right. So the -- first, the specific transaction that I mentioned is an old vintage fund, probably one of the oldest vintage funds, one of the oldest investments in the Darby group, that's taken a long time. But certainly, returning 50x the money have goo
componenttext: Right. So the -- first, the specific transaction that I mentioned is an old vintage fund, probably one of the oldest vintage funds, one of the oldest investments in the Darby group, that's taken a long time. But certainly, returning 50x the money have good results on that. The Darby group, which I think is probably under the $4 billion number that you mentioned, is really our private equity brand. It's kind of our all private equity funds. And they are starting to mature. I don't think we're going to see of this magnitude in the near term. But certainly, as we are starting to see more of that, we will do our best to telegraph that.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: Is it something where there is hundreds of million to dollars of gain? I would assume if it's under $4 billion, there's a lot -- it seems like there's a lot of -- potentially a lot of gains coming? Is that kind of a fair characterization?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's fair but over a long period of time as well.
componenttext: I think it's fair but over a long period of time as well.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And for Paul, just looking at India, can you tell us what kind of assets you're managing out of India at this point? And there was a media report over the weekend that the Indian government is considering ending the tax deduction on equity mutual fu
componenttext: Okay. And for Paul, just looking at India, can you tell us what kind of assets you're managing out of India at this point? And there was a media report over the weekend that the Indian government is considering ending the tax deduction on equity mutual funds. And I guess if something like that were to happen, is that a meaningful kind of data point?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, also on the positive side, but that market in general, from a regulatory point of view, is very dynamic. There was a period of time when the commissions paid was in questions and then that has changed. So that's a positive development. In terms of t
componenttext: Well, also on the positive side, but that market in general, from a regulatory point of view, is very dynamic. There was a period of time when the commissions paid was in questions and then that has changed. So that's a positive development. In terms of the assets under management relative to our total, I don't have the number handy, but it's not...

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Greggory Warren from Morningstar.
componenttext: The next question comes from Greggory Warren from Morningstar.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: When you look back at your flows over the last, say, 2-plus years, really since the market bottomed in March of '09, you've seen about $115 billion in net new flows, most of that really coming to the fixed income side of the business. But how much of that
componenttext: When you look back at your flows over the last, say, 2-plus years, really since the market bottomed in March of '09, you've seen about $115 billion in net new flows, most of that really coming to the fixed income side of the business. But how much of that -- are you really seeing any new institutional business in there? Or is that all of that -- being driven by financial advisors? And then I had a quick follow-up on that.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we have stated over the last year or 2 the area that has been new for us has been the Global Ag in emerging markets debt and that we have had significant wins. I don't know what the gross number is today but it certainly has contributed. But
componenttext: Well, I think we have stated over the last year or 2 the area that has been new for us has been the Global Ag in emerging markets debt and that we have had significant wins. I don't know what the gross number is today but it certainly has contributed. But the majority of the flows are going into the retail Global Bond Fund as well as the U.S. retail Global Bond Fund.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And that's kind of what I was thinking. And I guess as a follow-up to that, how effective then has been sort of the 2020 Vision program that you guys launched? And how much have you really tweaked that? And has any of the tweaks that you've done ove
componenttext: Okay. And that's kind of what I was thinking. And I guess as a follow-up to that, how effective then has been sort of the 2020 Vision program that you guys launched? And how much have you really tweaked that? And has any of the tweaks that you've done over the past 2 years enhanced the fixed income flows?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the market share and one of our priorities, obviously, when you look at our asset mix and you say, "Well, Frank looks under-weighted in U.S. large-cap growth or U.S. growth in general. And we've always said that we were out there looking for
componenttext: Well, I think the market share and one of our priorities, obviously, when you look at our asset mix and you say, "Well, Frank looks under-weighted in U.S. large-cap growth or U.S. growth in general. And we've always said that we were out there looking for a group. We probably one of the best groups internally, and we just had to get that message out. So that's been a big part of the 2020 Vision campaign. And I think if you look for us at the market share gains, and it's coming, it somewhat gets lost when you look at the Global Bond Funds, but we have made significant progress. And I think more importantly, we've gotten a lot of those funds on investment-only platforms that should drive sales. And that's been one of the metrics that we're very focused on, and we know that that's the retirement areas where you gain those equity sales and they're very steady. So we hope to continue to do that. And we feel it's been very successful, and we also feel when going out there and talking about 2020, you don't just look at the net result quickly and equity sales, you look at the kind of response you get from your partner with the partnership with the financial advisors and it gave them tools, whether the Franklin fund or something else, to sit down with their clients and keep people invested at a difficult time. And that's really what we're trying to do on the marketing side in the value-added side. But I think we feel like we have made good progress, and Franklin continues to grow relative to its competitors. But it's been a very difficult asset category over the last few years.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, you guys have been doing a great job. So I mean, it just -- it seem to me like giving the touch points and being out there, I mean, you don't want to have sort of that long-term ability to drive the equity inflows once it does shift. But just wonder
componenttext: Well, you guys have been doing a great job. So I mean, it just -- it seem to me like giving the touch points and being out there, I mean, you don't want to have sort of that long-term ability to drive the equity inflows once it does shift. But just wondering how much of an impact that was having on the fixed income flows as well, and it seems like just that touch point with the advisors is doing it.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Uh-huh.
componenttext: Uh-huh.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Michael Carrier from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question comes from Michael Carrier from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ken, just one of your comments on the prerecorded call, you said that it relates to the Darby on the performance piece. Just want to make sure I'm clear. You said the $48 million, and then in terms of the expenses related to that, I think in the past, whe
componenttext: Ken, just one of your comments on the prerecorded call, you said that it relates to the Darby on the performance piece. Just want to make sure I'm clear. You said the $48 million, and then in terms of the expenses related to that, I think in the past, when you've had these, I think the margin was somewhere around 40%, 50% but I just wanted to make sure. And then just in terms of the mix, in terms of comp and then other, any granularity there? And then on the comp side, when you said up 3% to 4%, I just want to make sure that's the core comp, and then you had the performance fee impact as well.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: You're exactly right. So the economics are about 40% to 50%. So just to do simple math, you can do the 50% and then split that in half between what runs through comps and what runs through other expenses, so -- and in my comment about the 3% to 4% was exc
componenttext: You're exactly right. So the economics are about 40% to 50%. So just to do simple math, you can do the 50% and then split that in half between what runs through comps and what runs through other expenses, so -- and in my comment about the 3% to 4% was exclusive of the Darby transaction. It was just kind of run rate increases that we're seeing. So 3% to 4% plus, call it, 12-ish on the comp line for the Darby piece.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then, Greg, just in terms of some of the products, I think when we look at the flows into the global fixed income products, it's still at $20 billion. It seems impressive. It's just more where are these flows coming from? So if y
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then, Greg, just in terms of some of the products, I think when we look at the flows into the global fixed income products, it's still at $20 billion. It seems impressive. It's just more where are these flows coming from? So if you can provide any granularity, whether it's by the regions, on the distribution side, any color on the institutional side, that's helpful. And then on the multi-asset strategy theme, I think you made some hires. Just in terms of your outlook, what are you guys trying to accomplish there? It sounds like you're seeing some traction there. But just wanted to see what the outlook is over the next 6 to 12 months.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, first of all, the Global Bond Fund flows. And we -- I think if you look at the world and what money funds are paying today and then you couple that with the concern over your own currency or your own sovereign debt and you may have individu
componenttext: Well, I think, first of all, the Global Bond Fund flows. And we -- I think if you look at the world and what money funds are paying today and then you couple that with the concern over your own currency or your own sovereign debt and you may have individuals and high net worth investors that have a lot invested in their own sovereign debt, in markets like Italy, where we've seen tremendous growth over the last couple of years, it's just the way for those high net worth investors to diversify some of the more conservative holdings. And I think we've been in a key position because we've had good relationships with the big banks and those that represent a lot of those high net worth investors. And obviously, you've had very strong consistent performance with that group, and that's really led to those flows. And that's why I think that that trend should continue in the near-term because I don't think any of the debt noise and all the sovereign debt issues that are out there are going to go away any time soon. And that's been the case in the U.S. as well, where it's a relatively new category for the retail investor. People are concerned about rates going up. People are concerned about the economy. And this is somewhat of an alternative asset class, where they can get gains from growth in other economies and other stronger currencies. So again, it's just a way to diversify a lower risk in a portfolio, and it's gone from 0 to some percentage. It's still very low in the average holder and one that we think will continue to grow. But it's the areas in Europe where Switzerland, we're always seeing in the growth as well as Italy for the European market and then obviously a lot of it here in the United States.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then anything on the multi-asset strategy side?
componenttext: Okay. And then anything on the multi-asset strategy side?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: So I think it's early. And I don't think we -- obviously, this is a huge category for the industry, one that we think we're very well-positioned as far as all of the breadth of our product line and different styles, that it's a natural extension of what w
componenttext: So I think it's early. And I don't think we -- obviously, this is a huge category for the industry, one that we think we're very well-positioned as far as all of the breadth of our product line and different styles, that it's a natural extension of what we do. And I think having that inflation piece in a portfolio is very important to what advisors and investors are looking for today. So I don't know how -- we don't really put a number out there. But if you look at the kind of growth in the industry with 3 or 4 big players, hopefully, we'll get a piece of that.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Robert Lee from KBW.
componenttext: The next question comes from Robert Lee from KBW.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just wonder, could we maybe just drill down a tiny bit into the global bond product and its $185 billion of assets? And obviously, the Templeton Global Bond price is the biggest chunk of that. But you have been talking about emerging markets product. I
componenttext: I just wonder, could we maybe just drill down a tiny bit into the global bond product and its $185 billion of assets? And obviously, the Templeton Global Bond price is the biggest chunk of that. But you have been talking about emerging markets product. I guess it's the Global Ag and maybe some other things. Just trying to get a better feel for the additional -- what proportion of that $180 million in change to be kind of the global -- coming from global bond strategy? And what are the other kind of big chunks within that?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the bulk is the global bonds, and that's probably around $120 billion out of the total. The other big fund is the Global Total Return Fund, which just this quarter had $4.8 billion in net inflows versus $2.5 billion. And I don't have the current siz
componenttext: Well, the bulk is the global bonds, and that's probably around $120 billion out of the total. The other big fund is the Global Total Return Fund, which just this quarter had $4.8 billion in net inflows versus $2.5 billion. And I don't have the current size of that fund, but that would be the next big category and the one that's going faster than the global bond. And obviously, you have more capacity in the total return just because it's a broader mandate with corporate's. But again, I go back to the other question that our team gets quite a bid on size and those currency markets and sovereign debt are the largest markets in the world, and trillions of dollars are represented in that. So if there's any area where you can increase the size of a fund and not inhibit the management, it would be in that category.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just curious, you -- I guess you closed or shortly closing your clothes on the balanced asset managers in Australia. Obviously, it's an institutional account. But maybe can you talk about in terms of their scale and kind of the strategy th
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just curious, you -- I guess you closed or shortly closing your clothes on the balanced asset managers in Australia. Obviously, it's an institutional account. But maybe can you talk about in terms of their scale and kind of the strategy there? I think, if I remember from the press release, it's around $11 billion of assets, and then maybe a little update on what their business is like.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, the Australian market is dominated by the superannuation and probably around 1/3 of that market is Australian equity. So it's only 35%. So we felt it was important. I mean, that's such a strong growth area, and it's now increased from 10% to
componenttext: Yes, I mean, the Australian market is dominated by the superannuation and probably around 1/3 of that market is Australian equity. So it's only 35%. So we felt it was important. I mean, that's such a strong growth area, and it's now increased from 10% to 12% mandated into these funds. And it's a lion's share of the market. I mean, there's not really an addressable market. It's superannuation, really, is the market. So that means lower fees than you're normally going to see because it's institutionally driven but very cost-efficient and still very high margin at the lower fees. So for us, it strengthens our position in the market, where we think the other areas will continue to grow like global equities. Obviously, Australia has had a tremendous run with the currency, commodities, China, and that's probably created even more of a bias towards the local market and that'll turn at some point. And it'll just strengthen our position by having that local presence, where we can bring in the other funds over time as well to one of the largest markets in the world.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Glenn Schorr from Nomura Securities.
componenttext: The next question comes from Glenn Schorr from Nomura Securities.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just curious, gross sales were up, long-term redemptions were down a lot. I don't know how much of that you consider a seasonal thing versus something particularly about last quarter. But I'm curious on -- I see the things obviously driving close on produ
componenttext: Just curious, gross sales were up, long-term redemptions were down a lot. I don't know how much of that you consider a seasonal thing versus something particularly about last quarter. But I'm curious on -- I see the things obviously driving close on product preference, but is there anything you are doing specifically to help stem the flow of redemptions because there's a big change quarter on quarter?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we did mention last quarter. I mean, we had a $4.8 billion in redemptions in some large sovereign wealth funds, a lower margin. But on the Templeton side, and that's really what...
componenttext: Yes, I think we did mention last quarter. I mean, we had a $4.8 billion in redemptions in some large sovereign wealth funds, a lower margin. But on the Templeton side, and that's really what...

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: But it still kind came down another $5 billion or $6 billion beyond that?
componenttext: But it still kind came down another $5 billion or $6 billion beyond that?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I know, and overall, it was a more stable quarter, I think, in general. And we didn't have any other chunky institutional redemptions.
componenttext: Yes, I know, and overall, it was a more stable quarter, I think, in general. And we didn't have any other chunky institutional redemptions.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I would just add, in terms of being proactive the last few quarters, we've done a lot of work on the bidding side. And we've seen some of the benefits there in the lower redemption. We did a great brain chart out to the advisors that was very well-rec
componenttext: And I would just add, in terms of being proactive the last few quarters, we've done a lot of work on the bidding side. And we've seen some of the benefits there in the lower redemption. We did a great brain chart out to the advisors that was very well-received so.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I should've -- I missed that. Ken, thank you for pointing it out. The munis were $3.5 billion in net redemptions in the prior quarter and $900 million this quarter. So that's a dramatic turnaround. And same with the Asian growth, where they had a ver
componenttext: Yes, I should've -- I missed that. Ken, thank you for pointing it out. The munis were $3.5 billion in net redemptions in the prior quarter and $900 million this quarter. So that's a dramatic turnaround. And same with the Asian growth, where they had a very choppy quarter. Last quarter, actually, was in outflows, at inflows this quarter, $750 million. And that was really because of the slowdown in redemptions. So those were the 2 big drivers, munis and Asian growth outside of the other ones that we talked about with the Sovereign Debt Fund, some or plus [ph].

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, and I appreciate that. And then even as your cash balances build, I've noticed the lower gains this quarter. But in general, the other income line was pretty small relative to lots of peers in the past especially as your cash is building. Anything s
componenttext: Okay, and I appreciate that. And then even as your cash balances build, I've noticed the lower gains this quarter. But in general, the other income line was pretty small relative to lots of peers in the past especially as your cash is building. Anything specific in there on the negative front as a headwind that isn't perfectly clear to us?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say the highlight is kind of more accounting driven, if you will. First, you have the consolidated variable interest entities that had -- they are much bigger negative this quarter. And most of that is offset on the -- below the net income li
componenttext: Yes, I would say the highlight is kind of more accounting driven, if you will. First, you have the consolidated variable interest entities that had -- they are much bigger negative this quarter. And most of that is offset on the -- below the net income line for the noncontrolling interests. If you look at -- there's been no real change in even year-over-year on the core dividend interest category, which is, I guess, roughly around $10 million a quarter. And then the rest of that variability is either due to the accounting or the markets or based -- of resulting from gains that we take. If you're -- so there's 2 things that drive the variability. There's the mark-to-market. And we have -- it's in the file. And we filed about $900 million of trading securities that will get marked and which kind of show you what category investments therein. And then also, we have the consolidated BIEs [ph] that don't affect the bottom line but certainly do introduce volatility into this particular line item.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then final question, as cash build with some version of the same question we always ask every quarters, payout ratio used to be 90%-ish. It's been 50%-ish and a little more for the last 4 quarters. Just curious, I've covered you guys for a long time,
componenttext: And then final question, as cash build with some version of the same question we always ask every quarters, payout ratio used to be 90%-ish. It's been 50%-ish and a little more for the last 4 quarters. Just curious, I've covered you guys for a long time, so it's consistent -- or inconsistently consistent returning. And so I still have confidence that it will continue to be that. But I'm just curious on what in recent times would you be saving such a war chest on? I mean, fuel front, conservatism, balance sheet consolidation, just curious on what goes on in your mind.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, when we look at it, sort of kind of a multifaceted discussion. But certainly, keep in mind that a lot of the cash is outside the U.S. Also, we do utilize a lot of cash for product development and probably more so than any of our peers in the industry
componenttext: Yes, when we look at it, sort of kind of a multifaceted discussion. But certainly, keep in mind that a lot of the cash is outside the U.S. Also, we do utilize a lot of cash for product development and probably more so than any of our peers in the industry, and that pays off. It's kind of -- if you look at it sort of as a R&D spend, which is investing back at the business. So I mean, those are kind of the 2 major factors. So we balance that with returning capital shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. And I guess you can see from our historic record that it's been a focus. But it's very much a balancing act, and not much has really changed.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I do think we do have a very experienced board, and they see the benefit of having a very conservative balance sheet. And it's kind of an intangible out there, that's the high rating for an asset manager. And when you get in difficult markets, li
componenttext: Yes, and I do think we do have a very experienced board, and they see the benefit of having a very conservative balance sheet. And it's kind of an intangible out there, that's the high rating for an asset manager. And when you get in difficult markets, like we've had over the last few years, we think it's one of the big reasons why we've been able to come out of that stronger than we came into it. And it is important to clients to have that strong balance sheet because they don't really want to invest in companies where they're worried about how they're going to survive a big downturn in the market. So I think that's an intangible that still is very important in why we will always generally be looked at as too conservative on the balance sheet. But I think the board is still going to look at tax issues and things, and all those things around a special dividend are always out there.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Jeff Hopson from Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: The next question comes from Jeff Hopson from Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: You referenced your recent success with the Global Total Return Bond Fund. Curious if those flows are coming from the same types of customers, channels, countries as the other global fixed income product. And just curious of your thoughts as far as ultima
componenttext: You referenced your recent success with the Global Total Return Bond Fund. Curious if those flows are coming from the same types of customers, channels, countries as the other global fixed income product. And just curious of your thoughts as far as ultimately the size of that product versus the other ones or the other big fund, if that -- is there any reason why it couldn't be bigger? Or do you think because of the credit risk it will probably be smaller? Or any thoughts on that?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's nowhere near a concern on size at this point. And it does have a broader mandate to generally invest in, if you call it, want to call it, more mid-cap type securities than the big Sovereign Debt Global Bond Fund. So probably, from that perspe
componenttext: I think it's nowhere near a concern on size at this point. And it does have a broader mandate to generally invest in, if you call it, want to call it, more mid-cap type securities than the big Sovereign Debt Global Bond Fund. So probably, from that perspective, you won't -- would be somewhat limited by size, where you wouldn't be in the other fund, but I'm not sure what number and how far that has to go before that's a concern because you are investing in corporates as well as sovereign debt. I think the market is really the same for both. I think some -- this one is viewed as a little bit more aggressive and has had a little bit better return because of that. But as far as how it's being sold, it's -- we're seeing the sales at the same markets. One of the markets that I didn't mention earlier in addition to Switzerland would be Germany, again, a market that we've been telling a story for a long time. But with the recent concerns around the Euro, that was -- it's -- again, which is all new in the last year or 2, we've seen significant flows out of Germany into these funds as well.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Cynthia Mayer from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: The next question comes from Cynthia Mayer from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess just a quick follow-up on that. The $5 billion of flows to the global total return really seems huge, and it seem like it was mostly from overseas. I'm wondering if all of the worries over sovereign debt have some people moving out of a sovereign
componenttext: I guess just a quick follow-up on that. The $5 billion of flows to the global total return really seems huge, and it seem like it was mostly from overseas. I'm wondering if all of the worries over sovereign debt have some people moving out of a sovereign fund and into that fund. Do you have any sense of exchanges, for instance?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think that if someone was concerned about sovereign debt, they probably get out of both funds. I think it's more the -- we've kind of lead with the global bond, and then they've seen that they can get some incremental return and maybe telli
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think that if someone was concerned about sovereign debt, they probably get out of both funds. I think it's more the -- we've kind of lead with the global bond, and then they've seen that they can get some incremental return and maybe telling the story around global total return in addition to the Global Bond Fund. But I just haven't heard that, and that you could be right, Cynthia, I just haven't heard if that's the case, people looking to go out to diversify more away from the sovereign debt.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess just a follow-up, too, to the discussion of the home country investing bias. You mentioned Australia is an example of that. And just in general, should we think of that as a phenomenon of -- that's typical wherever you have a local
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess just a follow-up, too, to the discussion of the home country investing bias. You mentioned Australia is an example of that. And just in general, should we think of that as a phenomenon of -- that's typical wherever you have a local market that's usually outperforming the rest of the world? But basically, people will invest at home until they discover their home markets under performing. And if that's true, I mean, should we assume that it's a little harder for you to sell in countries where the local markets really outperforming, and that's the kind of place where you would look for a local manager if you thought it was sustainable?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think that's exactly right. It's almost impossible especially if you have a newer market that's been up like in India or China over the last decade relative to other markets. It becomes very difficult to come in there and sell other funds,
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think that's exactly right. It's almost impossible especially if you have a newer market that's been up like in India or China over the last decade relative to other markets. It becomes very difficult to come in there and sell other funds, so -- but we also know that over time that will change, and it always does. And there's every country you can look at. Now it's the case, really, in the U.S you could argue for a while. The U.S. market was doing very well, and people just feel like they needed the additional risk and then that kind of reversed itself. So that's a fair statement.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just maybe one more follow-up. The global as the new core, that campaign, is that a U.S. campaign? Or is that all over?
componenttext: Okay. And just maybe one more follow-up. The global as the new core, that campaign, is that a U.S. campaign? Or is that all over?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's all over.
componenttext: It's all over.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: The next question comes from Douglas Sipkin from Ticonderoga.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: Just wanted to follow up a little bit on the international equity business. I just wanted to get a clarification and then ask a question. I just wanted to make sure. I think you had said most of the -- a lot of the institutional assets are, in fact, in sort of the international equity bucket, is that correct?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I mean, have you seen any incremental interest? I know you had a choppy quarter or 2. But obviously, with the 1 and 3, your numbers on some of the Templeton equities are very strong. I was just curious if you've seen a notable pick up in i
componenttext: Okay. And then, I mean, have you seen any incremental interest? I know you had a choppy quarter or 2. But obviously, with the 1 and 3, your numbers on some of the Templeton equities are very strong. I was just curious if you've seen a notable pick up in interest on the part of clients, obviously, given the softening of the markets. I was just wondering maybe you might be seeing some of that.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we are anticipating that, and we've seen a slowdown in the redemption rates. So that's your first step that -- and then hopefully, we'll get people back to talking about those funds again and get some new people interested in them. So we did
componenttext: Well, I think we are anticipating that, and we've seen a slowdown in the redemption rates. So that's your first step that -- and then hopefully, we'll get people back to talking about those funds again and get some new people interested in them. So we did have a mutual discovery, which we did very well in all this year. It's not just like most mutual series funds is underperforming in the market to date this year. But hopefully, the Templeton growth and foreign funds can pick up that flag.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just a follow-up, have you guys given any consideration to raising the dividend some more in a consistent basis? It does seem like you guys obviously have a preferable bias towards buybacks. But I look at your cash, and I can appreciate the big p
componenttext: And then just a follow-up, have you guys given any consideration to raising the dividend some more in a consistent basis? It does seem like you guys obviously have a preferable bias towards buybacks. But I look at your cash, and I can appreciate the big piece international. But when I look at your dividend yield relative to firms, which you guys are doing dramatically better than it just continues to jump out at me, is just alarmingly low. So I'm just curious on your thoughts there.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, the focus -- our focus has been on continually growing dividend. And I think you could -- in solid growth rate, the company also grows quickly, so -- which is a good problem to have. But if you kind of look at our historical growth in dividend, it's
componenttext: Yes, the focus -- our focus has been on continually growing dividend. And I think you could -- in solid growth rate, the company also grows quickly, so -- which is a good problem to have. But if you kind of look at our historical growth in dividend, it's pretty healthy. I hear you on the yield, but that's because I think it's mostly a function of the company growing very quickly.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: The last question comes from Marc Irizarry from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The last question comes from Marc Irizarry from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greg, I wonder if you could just speak a little bit to the concentration of flows and then also the new -- some of the new products that you tend to launch, maybe of about the multi-asset class and asset allocation products. Are you concerned about the ov
componenttext: Greg, I wonder if you could just speak a little bit to the concentration of flows and then also the new -- some of the new products that you tend to launch, maybe of about the multi-asset class and asset allocation products. Are you concerned about the overconcentration of flows in global bond? And how much do you think or how quickly do you think you can get some new products out there to sort of mitigate [indiscernible]?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: So again, I think, like anything, you always have to take a step back from flows before you draw a conclusion that the only thing that people are interested in a Franklin Templeton is global bond. I mean, that's the big portion of your net number. But on
componenttext: So again, I think, like anything, you always have to take a step back from flows before you draw a conclusion that the only thing that people are interested in a Franklin Templeton is global bond. I mean, that's the big portion of your net number. But on a gross basis, it's not nearly as concerning when you look at the amount being sold in all the other areas. So I think the key strengths, and you know better than I, the flows in the industry and the pressure, the traditional equity, managers are under and especially domestic equity managers, you can have very strong gross sales and still have fairly large net redemptions. And that's been a headwind for everyone. So we have been consistent about pounding the message in on our other funds. We feel like we're making good headway, we're making progress in market share, but that's not going to show up on a net flow number until those flows really turn around the other way. So I don't -- I'm not that concerned. I think I still feel there's things that get lost in a shuffle. I mean, we've raised $1 billion in Shariah compliant funds. We're offering new funds there. That's an exciting new area for us. We talked about tactical asset allocation. That's another huge category that we think we could get a nice momentum. And I think that the seeds that we planted in place with the long-term records on the Franklin growth funds should put us in great position when that turns around. So again, you look at the gross trends, you  don't -- I don't get nearly as concerned as net numbers get reported.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just in terms of U.S. retail distribution, are you seeing some incremental pressure on fees or maybe demands from the U.S. distribution channel? And then outside the U.S., are you seeing maybe some areas where the architecture is sor
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just in terms of U.S. retail distribution, are you seeing some incremental pressure on fees or maybe demands from the U.S. distribution channel? And then outside the U.S., are you seeing maybe some areas where the architecture is sort of opening up a little bit, introducing a little more competition for you on the shelf process [ph]?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think those are -- those trends are always in place and your distribution, and that's going to hopefully find an equilibrium. And the pressure is always going to be on that side. But I wouldn't say if anything new or anything that's changed becaus
componenttext: Well, I think those are -- those trends are always in place and your distribution, and that's going to hopefully find an equilibrium. And the pressure is always going to be on that side. But I wouldn't say if anything new or anything that's changed because there's some other consolidation, and that was always one of the concerns out there, so -- and then internationally, I would say the same. I think there's always pressure, there's always new competitors coming in, but it's very difficult in many of these markets. And I think the consistency of Franklin Templeton has been there through the ups and downs had served us very well with those relationships. And it's very hard just to come in and think you're going to get shelf space or get distribution quickly because you've got the next new hot fund. And we spend a lot of years building relationships in those markets and then -- and happened to have the right timing with the Global Bond Fund, where we're able to leverage those. But that was a decade of work to get there for the last few years.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Conference Call for the Quarter ended June 30, 2011. My name is Christine, and I will be today's facilitator.Statements made in this conference call regarding Franklin Resources Inc., which are
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Conference Call for the Quarter ended June 30, 2011. My name is Christine, and I will be today's facilitator.
Statements made in this conference call regarding Franklin Resources Inc., which are not historical facts, are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the Risk Factors and MD&A section of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K filing. [Operator Instructions] Now I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Greg Johnson, Chief Executive Officer. You may begin.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone. Thanks for taking time out of your day to join Ken Lewis and I for this call. Today, we reported a very strong quarter of flows and operating results that continue to illustrate the key strengths of our organization. On a sad n
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone. Thanks for taking time out of your day to join Ken Lewis and I for this call. Today, we reported a very strong quarter of flows and operating results that continue to illustrate the key strengths of our organization. 
On a sad note, we lost our friend, Peter Sacerdote, who passed away over the weekend. Peter was a member of the Franklin Resources Board of Directors since 1993, his 17-year tenure on our board, gave us great perspective as he helped guide our business, strategy and culture. He will be missed by all who had the honor of working with him. 
And now I'd like to open it up for your questions.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Roger Freeman from Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Roger Freeman from Barclays.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess first, on the -- your European business. You probably -- heard in the comments that -- the Invesco [ph]  made on earnings call about looking to outsource their transfer agent function over there. And I wanted to see what your views on that were, g
componenttext: I guess first, on the -- your European business. You probably -- heard in the comments that -- the Invesco [ph]  made on earnings call about looking to outsource their transfer agent function over there. And I wanted to see what your views on that were, given that you've got a reasonable presence in Europe. Do you find -- do you see the pending regulatory changes there as an impediment to doing business with your structure today?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that we're looking at it. And I think we do have somewhat different business models with respect to the amount of assets held in U.K. and Europe with our respect -- with our CCAB Funds [ph] that are $150 billion. We don't have a lot of U
componenttext: Well, I would say that we're looking at it. And I think we do have somewhat different business models with respect to the amount of assets held in U.K. and Europe with our respect -- with our CCAB Funds [ph] that are $150 billion. We don't have a lot of U.K. assets. We have the recent acquisition. It's not on our system at this point. So it's something we're going to look at. But at this stage, we don't anticipate any changes.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, secondly, just with respect to alternatives, I wanted to see if we could get an update on the -- and with the Pelagos acquisition late last year, what your thoughts are around that enabling you to offer any kind of alternative pro
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, secondly, just with respect to alternatives, I wanted to see if we could get an update on the -- and with the Pelagos acquisition late last year, what your thoughts are around that enabling you to offer any kind of alternative product in our Cordiac Fund [ph]. You said at the time it might take 12 months to figure out so I just thought I'd  get an update 6 months into it.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, yes, one of our goals this year is to offer tactical asset allocation funds, multi-asset strategy funds. And we're getting very close to doing that. And I think we just offered or we just included one in our CCAB Fund [ph]. So Pelagos would
componenttext: Yes, I think, yes, one of our goals this year is to offer tactical asset allocation funds, multi-asset strategy funds. And we're getting very close to doing that. And I think we just offered or we just included one in our CCAB Fund [ph]. So Pelagos would be a sleeve that those asset allocation funds will use, and we anticipate those offerings in the United States toward the end of this year.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: The next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, can you maybe just give us an update on where you stand on the institutional channel in terms of the pipeline activity levels and maybe allocation trends? And then just to follow-up on kind of the alternatives front. It sounds like you're maybe pus
componenttext: First, can you maybe just give us an update on where you stand on the institutional channel in terms of the pipeline activity levels and maybe allocation trends? And then just to follow-up on kind of the alternatives front. It sounds like you're maybe pushing those capabilities a bit more in the institutional. So any color on initial client interest for those strategies as well.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, first of all, not a whole lot of changes within the institutional channel. I think some of the pressure in prior quarters, we seem -- the dramatic turnaround in Templeton's performance has taken some of the pressure off the institutional ac
componenttext: Well, I think, first of all, not a whole lot of changes within the institutional channel. I think some of the pressure in prior quarters, we seem -- the dramatic turnaround in Templeton's performance has taken some of the pressure off the institutional accounts, where we had we had some large redemptions 2 quarters ago. So we don't see any of that activity. We actually saw some increases to existing accounts over the quarter. I think the activity was pretty consistent with what we've seen as well as the pipeline. It seems the global aggregates, some low duration type fixed income, some specialty China equities and India equities, nothing really unusual. So global equity continues to probably lead the number of searches as well as global aggregate, and the pipeline now still looks relatively good. And we  -- I think the positive development, as I mentioned, is just the Templeton turnaround. That's where the majority of the institutional assets are. I think on the alternative side, you're probably referring to maybe the global summits effort and the hedge fund that we've been talking about with our global bond group. And that's something we are out there talking about, and it was a longer lead time in that category. We don't expect to get large assets quickly, but it is getting a positive reception out there. And outside of that, I think it's really the development on the retail side of these asset allocation funds using some alternatives within them that hopefully will be well received in the retail channel.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe just a question for Ken. It seems like despite a less favorable AUM mix, you continue to hold the line here on expenses so driving margins higher. So I know you guys gave us some guidance on a few expense line items for next quarter.
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe just a question for Ken. It seems like despite a less favorable AUM mix, you continue to hold the line here on expenses so driving margins higher. So I know you guys gave us some guidance on a few expense line items for next quarter. But just assuming flows and revenues continue to trend higher, and just curious to get your take on how much more margin upside you think we can see from here.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think one of the things to consider is, typically, in the fourth quarter, we have some seasonal uptick across most of the expense categories. So I think it would be reasonable to expect that next quarter, but -- and certainly, there has been a lot
componenttext: Well, I think one of the things to consider is, typically, in the fourth quarter, we have some seasonal uptick across most of the expense categories. So I think it would be reasonable to expect that next quarter, but -- and certainly, there has been a lot of discussions about investing in the company and making strategic investments in certain expense line items. But overall, I think it's a measured pace, and I don't think you're going to see any large spike ups in the overall spending levels. So, yes, you can overlay that with whatever assumption you want to make on the revenue.
