componenttext: Basic question is in terms of comp, your guidance is probably a little better than people in the moment were anticipating, I would presume, in their expectations. So given the improvement in relative performances, so I'm wondering, is there any upward bias to that compensation? And if so, are there other areas of the firm that you could offset some of that wage inflation with?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Oh, okay. Well, yes, so I think in the guidance, and just to be clear, I did mention 2 things that could impact that line. One is just a general upward bias, and I think we were thinking in the term -- in the near term, about 3% to 4%. That factors in inc
componenttext: Oh, okay. Well, yes, so I think in the guidance, and just to be clear, I did mention 2 things that could impact that line. One is just a general upward bias, and I think we were thinking in the term -- in the near term, about 3% to 4%. That factors in increased headcount that also factors in expectations around variable compensation. And I think as we've been doing over several years, we'll continue to do in terms of adding head count [ph],  we try to focus obviously in the low cost jurisdictions. And then we've been pretty successful in doing that. And so that has -- over time, that has the impact of lowering the fixed component and increasing the variability, which is what you want to do in this business.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And my follow-up question is staying on the theme of margins. As your non-U.S. business continues to grow, and I probably asked this question before, so I apologize for repeating myself. But as I look at the distribution margin, it l
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And my follow-up question is staying on the theme of margins. As your non-U.S. business continues to grow, and I probably asked this question before, so I apologize for repeating myself. But as I look at the distribution margin, it looks like it got a little bit more negative, if you will, maybe it's a little over simplistic. But how does the overall impact on the margins play out if the non-U.S. business continues to outgrow the United States?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, you do ask that? All right. Not just you, but I don't think I get [ph] that question. The general -- it had -- the general answer hasn't changed. There's -- it's obviously over simplification. But in terms of overall profitability, U.S., non-U.S. is
componenttext: Yes, you do ask that? All right. Not just you, but I don't think I get [ph] that question. The general -- it had -- the general answer hasn't changed. There's -- it's obviously over simplification. But in terms of overall profitability, U.S., non-U.S. is more or less the same. And that is because in the -- the U.S. is more a developed market. And while certain aspects of the non-U.S. market are more profitable, we're obviously in kind of startup mode in other markets. So they tend to offset. And on balance, the profitability tends to be the same. The mix between -- in this quarter, between the U.S. non-U.S. really didn't change that much. So in terms of the distribution margin, it wasn't too much of a change. But it depends how you're calculating distribution margin. And I think what we tried to do with the disclosures is kind off of that concept and just kind of look at distribution revenue and the assets -- component of the distribution revenue versus sales component and the -- similarly on the expense side, looking at the assets, component of the expense, the sale component of expense as well as the amortization of deferred commissions, which are pretty well highlighted in our Q which, I might add, was filed today.

It's kind of our all private equity funds. And they are starting to mature. I don't think we're going to see anything of this magnitude in the near term. But certainly, as we are starting to see more of that, we will do our best to telegraph that.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: When you look back at your flows over the last, say, 2-plus years, really since the market bottomed in March of '09, you've seen about $115 billion in net new flows, most of that really coming to the fixed income side of the business. But how much of that
componenttext: When you look back at your flows over the last, say, 2-plus years, really since the market bottomed in March of '09, you've seen about $115 billion in net new flows, most of that really coming to the fixed income side of the business. But how much of that -- are you really seeing any new institutional business in there? Or is that all of that -- being driven by financial advisors? And then I had a quick follow-up on that.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we have stated over the last year or 2 the area that has been new for us has been the Global Ag in emerging markets debt and that we have had significant wins. I don't know what the gross number is today but it certainly has contributed. But
componenttext: Well, I think we have stated over the last year or 2 the area that has been new for us has been the Global Ag in emerging markets debt and that we have had significant wins. I don't know what the gross number is today but it certainly has contributed. But the majority of the flows are going into the retail Global Bond Fund as well as the U.S. retail Global Bond Fund.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And that's kind of what I was thinking. And I guess as a follow-up to that, how effective then has been sort of the 2020 Vision program that you guys launched? And how much have you really tweaked that? And has any of the tweaks that you've done ove
componenttext: Okay. And that's kind of what I was thinking. And I guess as a follow-up to that, how effective then has been sort of the 2020 Vision program that you guys launched? And how much have you really tweaked that? And has any of the tweaks that you've done over the past 2 years enhanced the fixed income flows?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the market share and one of our priorities, obviously, when you look at our asset mix and you say, "Well, Franklin is under-weighted in U.S. large-cap growth or U.S. growth in general. And we've always said that we were out there looking for
componenttext: Well, I think the market share and one of our priorities, obviously, when you look at our asset mix and you say, "Well, Franklin is under-weighted in U.S. large-cap growth or U.S. growth in general. And we've always said that we were out there looking for a group, we probably have one of the best groups internally, and we just had to get that message out. So that's been a big part of the 2020 Vision campaign. And I think if you look for us at the market share gains, and it's coming, it somewhat gets lost when you look at the Global Bond Funds, but we have made significant progress. And I think more importantly, we've gotten a lot of those funds on investment-only platforms that should drive sales. And that's been one of the metrics that we're very focused on, and we know that that's the retirement areas where you gain those equity sales and they're very steady. So we hope to continue to do that. And we feel it's been very successful, and we also feel when going out there and talking about 2020, you don't just look at the net result quickly and equity sales, you look at the kind of response you get from your partner with the partnership with the financial advisors and it gave them tools, whether it was a Franklin fund or something else, to sit down with their clients and keep people invested at a difficult time. And that's really what we try to do on the marketing side in the value-added side. But I think we feel like we have made good progress, and Franklin continues to grow relative to its competitors. But it's been a very difficult asset category here for the last few years.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, you guys have been doing a great job. So I mean, it just -- it seem to me like getting the touch points and being out there, I mean, you  want to have sort of that long-term ability to drive the equity inflows once it does shift. But just wondering
componenttext: Well, you guys have been doing a great job. So I mean, it just -- it seem to me like getting the touch points and being out there, I mean, you  want to have sort of that long-term ability to drive the equity inflows once it does shift. But just wondering how much of an impact that was having on the fixed income flows as well, and it seems like just that touch point with the advisors is doing it.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ken, just one of your comments on the prerecorded call, you said that it relates to the Darby on the performance piece. Just want to make sure I'm clear. You said the $48 million, and then in terms of the expenses related to that, I think in the past, whe
componenttext: Ken, just one of your comments on the prerecorded call, you said that it relates to the Darby on the performance piece. Just want to make sure I'm clear. You said the $48 million, and then in terms of the expenses related to that, I think in the past, when you've had these, I think the margin was somewhere around 40%, 50% but I just wanted to make sure. And then just in terms of the mix, in terms of comp and then other, any granularity there? And then on the comp side, when you said up 3% to 4%, I just want to make sure that's the core comp, and then you had the performance fee impact as well.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: You're exactly right. So the economics are about 40% to 50%. So just to do simple math, you can do the 50% and then split that in half between what runs through comp and what runs through other expenses, so -- and in my comment about the 3% to 4% was excl
componenttext: You're exactly right. So the economics are about 40% to 50%. So just to do simple math, you can do the 50% and then split that in half between what runs through comp and what runs through other expenses, so -- and in my comment about the 3% to 4% was exclusive of the Darby transaction. It was just kind of run rate increases that we're seeing. So 3% to 4% plus, call it, 12-ish on the comp line for the Darby piece.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then, Greg, just in terms of some of the products, I think when we look at the flows into the global fixed income products, it's still at $20 billion. It seems impressive. It's just more where are these flows coming from? So if y
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then, Greg, just in terms of some of the products, I think when we look at the flows into the global fixed income products, it's still at $20 billion. It seems impressive. It's just more where are these flows coming from? So if you can provide any granularity, whether it's by the regions, on the distribution side, any color on the institutional side, that's helpful. And then on the multi-asset strategy team, I think you made some hires. Just in terms of your outlook, what are you guys trying to accomplish there? It sounds like you're seeing some traction there. But just wanted to see what the outlook is over the next 6 to 12 months.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, first of all, the Global Bond Fund flows. And we -- I think if you look at the world and what money funds are paying today and then you couple that with the concern over your own currency or your own sovereign debt and you may have individu
componenttext: Well, I think, first of all, the Global Bond Fund flows. And we -- I think if you look at the world and what money funds are paying today and then you couple that with the concern over your own currency or your own sovereign debt and you may have individuals and high net worth investors that have a lot invested in their own sovereign debt, in markets like Italy, where we've seen tremendous growth over the last couple of years, it's just a way for those high net worth investors to diversify some of the more conservative holdings. And I think we've been in a key position because we've had good relationships with the big banks and those that represent a lot of those high net worth investors. And obviously, you've had very strong consistent performance with that group, and that's really led to those flows. And that's why I think that that trend should continue in the near-term because I don't think any of the debt noise and all the sovereign debt issues that are out there are going to go away any time soon. And that's been the case in the U.S. as well, where it's a relatively new category for the retail investor. People are concerned about rates going up. People are concerned about the economy. And this is somewhat of an alternative asset class, where they can get gains from growth in other economies and other stronger currencies. So again, it's just a way to diversify in lower risk in a portfolio, and it's gone from 0 to some percentage. It's still very low in the average holder and one that we think will continue to grow. But it's the areas in Europe where Switzerland, we're always seeing the growth as well as Italy for the European market and then obviously a lot of it here in the United States.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: Okay. And then anything on the multi-asset strategy side?

componenttextpreview: So I think it's early. And I don't think we -- obviously, this is a huge category for the industry, one that we think we're very well-positioned as far as all of the breadth of our product line and different styles, that it's a natural extension of what w
componenttext: So I think it's early. And I don't think we -- obviously, this is a huge category for the industry, one that we think we're very well-positioned as far as all of the breadth of our product line and different styles, that it's a natural extension of what we do. And I think having that inflation piece in a portfolio is very important to what advisors and investors are looking for today. So I don't know how -- we don't really put a number out there. But if you look at the kind of growth in the industry with 3 or 4 big players, hopefully, we'll get a piece of that.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: The next question comes from Robert Lee from KBW.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just wonder, could we maybe just drill down a tiny bit into the global bond product and its $185 billion of assets? And obviously, the Templeton Global Bond price is the biggest chunk of that. But you have been talking about emerging markets product. I
componenttext: I just wonder, could we maybe just drill down a tiny bit into the global bond product and its $185 billion of assets? And obviously, the Templeton Global Bond price is the biggest chunk of that. But you have been talking about emerging markets product. I guess it's the Global Ag and maybe some other things. Just trying to get a better feel for the additional -- what proportion of that $180 million in change to be kind of the global -- coming from global bond strategy? And what are the other kind of big chunks within that?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the bulk is the global bonds, and that's probably around $120 billion out of the total. The other big fund is the Global Total Return Fund, which just this quarter had $4.8 billion in net inflows versus $2.5 billion. And I don't have the current siz
componenttext: Well, the bulk is the global bonds, and that's probably around $120 billion out of the total. The other big fund is the Global Total Return Fund, which just this quarter had $4.8 billion in net inflows versus $2.5 billion. And I don't have the current size of that fund, but that would be the next big category and the one that's growing faster than the global bond. And obviously, you have more capacity in the total return just because it's a broader mandate with corporate's. But again, I go back to the other question that our team gets quite a bid on size and those currency markets and sovereign debt are the largest markets in the world, and trillions of dollars are represented in that. So if there's any area where you can increase the size of a fund and not inhibit the management, it would be in that category.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just curious, you -- I guess you closed or shortly closing your closed on the balanced asset managers in Australia. Obviously, it's an institutional account. But anything you talk about in terms of their scale and kind of the strategy ther
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just curious, you -- I guess you closed or shortly closing your closed on the balanced asset managers in Australia. Obviously, it's an institutional account. But anything you talk about in terms of their scale and kind of the strategy there? I think, if I remember from the press release, it's around $11 billion of assets, and then maybe a little update on what their business is like.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, the Australian market is dominated by the superannuation and probably around 1/3 of that market is Australian equity. So it's only [ph] 35%. So we felt it was important. I mean, that's such a strong growth area, and it's now increased from 10
componenttext: Yes, I mean, the Australian market is dominated by the superannuation and probably around 1/3 of that market is Australian equity. So it's only [ph] 35%. So we felt it was important. I mean, that's such a strong growth area, and it's now increased from 10% to 12% mandated into these funds. And it's a lion's share of the market. I mean, there's not really an addressable market. Its superannuation, really, is the market. So that means lower fees than you're normally going to see because it's institutionally driven but very cost-efficient and still very high margin at the lower fees. So for us, it strengthens our position in the market, where we think the other areas will continue to grow like global equities. Obviously, Australia has had a tremendous run with the currency, commodities, China, and that's probably created even more of a bias towards the local market and that'll turn at some point. And it'll just strengthen our position by having that local presence, where we can bring in the other funds over time as well to one of the largest markets in the world.

componenttext: And I would just add, in terms of being proactive the last few quarters, we've done a lot of work on the bidding side. And we've seen some of the benefits there in the lower redemption. We did a great brain chart out to the advisors that was very well-received so.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I should've -- I missed that. Ken, thank you for pointing it out. The munis were $3.5 billion in net redemptions in the prior quarter and $900 million this quarter. So that's a dramatic turnaround. And same with the Asian growth, where they had a ver
componenttext: Yes, I should've -- I missed that. Ken, thank you for pointing it out. The munis were $3.5 billion in net redemptions in the prior quarter and $900 million this quarter. So that's a dramatic turnaround. And same with the Asian growth, where they had a very choppy quarter. Last quarter, actually, was in outflows, had inflows this quarter, $750 million. And that was really because of the slowdown in redemptions. So those were the 2 big drivers, munis and Asian growth outside of the other ones that we talked about with the Sovereign Debt Fund, some or plus [ph].

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, and I appreciate that. And then even as your cash balances build, I've noticed the lower gains this quarter. But in general, the other income line was pretty small relative to lots of peers in the past especially as your cash is building. Anything s
componenttext: Okay, and I appreciate that. And then even as your cash balances build, I've noticed the lower gains this quarter. But in general, the other income line was pretty small relative to lots of peers in the past especially as your cash is building. Anything specific in there on the negative front as a headwind that isn't perfectly clear to us?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say the highlight is kind of more accounting driven, if you will. First, you have the consolidated variable interest entities that had -- they are much bigger negative this quarter. And most of that is offset on the -- below the net income li
componenttext: Yes, I would say the highlight is kind of more accounting driven, if you will. First, you have the consolidated variable interest entities that had -- they are much bigger negative this quarter. And most of that is offset on the -- below the net income line for the noncontrolling interests. If you look at -- there's been no real change in even year-over-year on the core dividend interest category, which is, I guess, roughly around $10 million a quarter. And then the rest of that variability is either due to the accounting or the markets or based -- of resulting from gains that we take. If you're -- so there's 2 things that drive the variability. There's the mark-to-market. And we have -- it's in the file. And we probably have about $900 million of trading securities that will get marked and which kind of show you what category investments there in. And then also, we have the consolidated BIEs [ph] that don't affect the bottom line but certainly do introduce volatility into this particular line item.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then final question, as cash build with some version of the same question we always ask every quarter is, payout ratio used to be 90%-ish. It's been 50%-ish and a little more for the last 4 quarters. Just curious, I've covered you guys for a long time
componenttext: And then final question, as cash build with some version of the same question we always ask every quarter is, payout ratio used to be 90%-ish. It's been 50%-ish and a little more for the last 4 quarters. Just curious, I've covered you guys for a long time, so it's consistent -- or inconsistently consistent returning. And so I still have confidence that it will continue to be that. But I'm just curious on what in recent times would you be saving such a war chest on? I mean, fuel front, conservatism, balance sheet consolidation, just curious on what goes on in your mind.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, when we look at it, sort of kind of a multifaceted discussion. But certainly, keep in mind that a lot of the cash is outside the U.S. Also, we do utilize a lot of cash for product development and probably more so than any of our peers in the industry
componenttext: Yes, when we look at it, sort of kind of a multifaceted discussion. But certainly, keep in mind that a lot of the cash is outside the U.S. Also, we do utilize a lot of cash for product development and probably more so than any of our peers in the industry, and that pays off. It's kind of -- if you look at it sort of as a R&D spend, which is investing back in the business. So I mean, those are kind of the 2 major factors. So we balance that with returning capital shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. And I guess you can see from our historic record that it's been a focus. But it's very much a balancing act, and not much has really changed.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I do think we do have a very experienced board, and they see the benefit of having a very conservative balance sheet. And it's kind of an intangible out there, that's a high rating for an asset manager. And when you get in difficult markets, like
componenttext: Yes, and I do think we do have a very experienced board, and they see the benefit of having a very conservative balance sheet. And it's kind of an intangible out there, that's a high rating for an asset manager. And when you get in difficult markets, like we've had over the last few years, we think it's one of the big reasons why we've been able to come out of that stronger than we came into it. And it is important to clients to have that strong balance sheet because they don't really want to invest in companies where they're worried about how they're going to survive a big downturn in the market. So I think that's an intangible that still is very important in why we will always generally be looked at as too conservative on the balance sheet. But I think the board is still going to look at tax issues and things, and all those things around a special dividend are always out there.

componenttext: The next question comes from Jeff Hopson from Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: You referenced your recent success with the Global Total Return Bond Fund. Curious if those flows are coming from the same types of customers, channels, countries as the other global fixed income product. And just curious of your thoughts as far as ultima
componenttext: You referenced your recent success with the Global Total Return Bond Fund. Curious if those flows are coming from the same types of customers, channels, countries as the other global fixed income product. And just curious of your thoughts as far as ultimately the size of that product versus the other ones or the other big fund, if that -- is there any reason why it couldn't be bigger? Or do you think because of the credit risk it will probably be smaller? Or any thoughts on that?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's nowhere near a concern on size at this point. And it does have a broader mandate to generally invest in, if you call it, want to call it, more mid-cap type securities than the big Sovereign Debt Global Bond Fund. So probably, from that perspe
componenttext: I think it's nowhere near a concern on size at this point. And it does have a broader mandate to generally invest in, if you call it, want to call it, more mid-cap type securities than the big Sovereign Debt Global Bond Fund. So probably, from that perspective, you won't -- would be somewhat limited by size, where you wouldn't be in the other fund, but I'm not sure what number and how far that has to go before that's a concern because you are investing in corporates as well as sovereign debt. I think the market is really the same for both. I think some -- this one is viewed as a little bit more aggressive and has had a little bit better return because of that. But as far as how it's being sold, it's -- we're seeing the sales at the same markets. One of the markets that I didn't mention earlier in addition to Switzerland would be Germany, again, a market that we've been telling a story for a long time. But with the recent concerns around the Euro, that was -- it's -- again, which is all new in the last year or 2, we've seen significant flows out of Germany into these funds as well.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: The next question comes from Cynthia Mayer from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

componenttext: I guess just a quick follow-up on that. The $5 billion of flows to the global total return really seems huge, and it seemed like it was mostly from overseas. I'm wondering if all of the worries over sovereign debt have some people moving out of a sovereign fund and into that fund. Do you have any sense of exchanges, for instance?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think that if someone was concerned about sovereign debt, they'd probably get out of both funds. I think it's more the -- we've kind of lead with the global bond, and then they've seen that they can get some incremental return and maybe tel
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think that if someone was concerned about sovereign debt, they'd probably get out of both funds. I think it's more the -- we've kind of lead with the global bond, and then they've seen that they can get some incremental return and maybe telling the story around global total return in addition to the Global Bond Fund. But I just haven't heard that, and that you could be right, Cynthia, I just haven't heard if that's the case, people looking to go out to diversify more away from the sovereign debt.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess just a follow-up, too, to the discussion of the home country investing bias. You mentioned Australia is an example of that. And just in general, should we think of that as a phenomenon of -- that's typical wherever you have a local
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess just a follow-up, too, to the discussion of the home country investing bias. You mentioned Australia is an example of that. And just in general, should we think of that as a phenomenon of -- that's typical wherever you have a local market that's usually outperforming the rest of the world? But basically, people will invest at home until they discover their home markets under performing. And if that's true, I mean, should we assume that it's a little harder for you to sell in countries where the local markets really outperforming, and that's the kind of place where you would look for a local manager if you thought it was sustainable?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think that's exactly right. It's almost impossible especially if you have a newer market that's been up like in India or China over the last decade relative to other markets. It becomes very difficult to come in there and sell other funds,
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think that's exactly right. It's almost impossible especially if you have a newer market that's been up like in India or China over the last decade relative to other markets. It becomes very difficult to come in there and sell other funds, so -- but we also know that over time that will change, and it always does. And there's every country you can look at. Now it's the case, really, in the U.S you could argue for a while. The U.S. market was doing very well, and people didn't feel like they needed the additional risk and then that kind of reversed itself. So that's a fair statement.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: And then just a follow-up, have you guys given any consideration to raising the dividend some more in a consistent basis? It does seem like you guys obviously have a preferable bias towards buybacks. But I look at your cash, and I can appreciate the big piece international. But when I look at your dividend yield relative to firms, which you guys are doing dramatically better than it just continues to jump out at me, is just alarmingly low. So I'm just curious on your thoughts there.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, the focus -- our focus has been on continually growing the dividend. And I think you could -- in solid growth rate, the company also grows quickly, so -- which is a good problem to have. But if you kind of look at our historical growth in dividend, i
componenttext: Yes, the focus -- our focus has been on continually growing the dividend. And I think you could -- in solid growth rate, the company also grows quickly, so -- which is a good problem to have. But if you kind of look at our historical growth in dividend, it's pretty healthy. I hear you on the yield, but that's because I think it's mostly a function of the company growing very quickly.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greg, I wonder if you could just speak a little bit to the concentration and flows and then also the new -- some of the new products that you tend to launch, maybe of about the multi-asset class and asset allocation products. Are you concerned about the o
componenttext: Greg, I wonder if you could just speak a little bit to the concentration and flows and then also the new -- some of the new products that you tend to launch, maybe of about the multi-asset class and asset allocation products. Are you concerned about the overconcentration of flows in global bond? And how much do you think or how quickly do you think you can get some new products out there to sort of mitigate [indiscernible]?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: So again, I think, like anything, you always have to take a step back from flows before you draw a conclusion that the only thing that people are interested in at Franklin Templeton is global bond. I mean, that's the big portion of your net number. But on
componenttext: So again, I think, like anything, you always have to take a step back from flows before you draw a conclusion that the only thing that people are interested in at Franklin Templeton is global bond. I mean, that's the big portion of your net number. But on a gross basis, it's not nearly as concerning when you look at the amount being sold in all the other areas. So I think the key strengths, and you know better than I, the flows in the industry and the pressure, the traditional equity, managers are under and especially domestic equity managers, you can have very strong gross sales and still have fairly large net redemptions. And that's been a headwind for everyone. So we have been consistent about pounding the message in on our other funds. We feel like we're making good headway, we're making progress in market share, but that's not going to show up on a net flow number until those flows really turn around the other way. So I don't -- I'm not that concerned. I think I still feel there's things that get lost in the shuffle. I mean, we've raised $1 billion in Shariah compliant funds. We're offering new funds there. That's an exciting new area for us. We talked about tactical asset allocation. That's another huge category that we think we could get a nice momentum. And I think that the seeds that we planted in place with the long-term records on the Franklin growth funds should put us in great position when that turns around. So again, you look at the gross trends, you  don't -- I don't get nearly as concerned as net numbers get reported.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: Okay, great. And then just in terms of U.S. retail distribution, are you seeing some incremental pressure on fees or maybe demands from the U.S. distribution channel? And then outside the U.S., are you seeing maybe some areas where the architecture is sort of opening up a little bit, introducing a little more competition for you on the shelf process [ph]?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think those are -- those trends are always in place and your distribution, and that's going to hopefully find an equilibrium. And the pressure is always going to be on that side. But I wouldn't say it's anything new or anything that's changed beca
componenttext: Well, I think those are -- those trends are always in place and your distribution, and that's going to hopefully find an equilibrium. And the pressure is always going to be on that side. But I wouldn't say it's anything new or anything that's changed because of some of the consolidation, and that was always one of the concerns out there, so -- and then internationally, I would say the same. I think there's always pressure, there's always new competitors coming in, but it's very difficult in many of these markets. And I think the consistency of Franklin Templeton has been there through the ups and downs had served us very well with those relationships. And it's very hard just to come in and think you're going to get shelf space or get distribution quickly because you've got the next new hot fund. And we spend a lot of years building relationships in those markets and then -- and happened to have the right timing with the Global Bond Fund, where we're able to leverage those. But that was a decade of work to get there for the last few years.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

componenttext:
Welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Commentary for the quarter ended September 30, 2011. 
Statements made in this commentary regarding Franklin Resources Inc., which are not historical facts, are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the Risk Factors and MD&A section of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K filing.
[Operator Instructions]

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the fourth quarter commentary. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; with Ken Lewis, our CFO. Our fourth quarter cap was overall a very successful year for the firm. Fourth quarter net new flows of $3.1 billion brought total flows for the year to almost $37 b
componenttext:
Welcome to the fourth quarter commentary. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; with Ken Lewis, our CFO. Our fourth quarter cap was overall a very successful year for the firm. Fourth quarter net new flows of $3.1 billion brought total flows for the year to almost $37 billion, one of our best years ever despite heightened market volatility over the past quarter. 
Long term sales for the year exceeded $200 billion for the first time with the more than 50% coming from non-U.S. sources. That success was reflected in our operating results as revenues exceeded $7.1 billion and operating income and earnings per share rose 36% for the year.  Driving those results was a growth in operating revenue of 22% with expenses increasing 15%. The greatest source of our organic asset growth continued to be our global Fixed Income business with $11 billion in net new flows for the quarter. Equity markets continue to be under pressure amidst negative market sentiments following the downgrade of the U.S. Treasury debt rating and the increasing concerns related to sovereign debt in the Eurozone. 
Most importantly, our long-term investment performance rankings have remained strong in this market environment with the majority of our assets ranking in Lippers first quartile over the past 10 years. Strategically, we have continued to expand our global presence in key markets, including the acquisition of Australian-based Balanced Equity Management, which closed in July and the continued integration of U.K.-based Rensberg under the Franklin Templeton brand. In addition to expanding our capabilities across the globe, we continue to strengthen our presence in existing markets. We launched several new funds to meet evolving investor demand and extend our product lineup, particularly in technical asset allocation and won several new sovereign and institutional mandates this quarter. 
Overall, relative investment performance remains solid across our equity and fixed income strategies. Over the past 2 months, there's been increased retention focused on the short-term underperformance of some of our global bond strategies due primarily to the rally in long dated U.S. Treasuries and the strengthening of the U.S. dollar and yen relative to other currencies held in those portfolios. This is not the first time this strategy has experienced a period of short-term underperformance. But over the long term, it has delivered outstanding risk adjusted return relative to its peers. 
We're also encouraged at the funds recent rebound in relative performance over the past few weeks. I'd also like to remind everyone that 40% of our fixed income assets under management are in U.S. products where several of our funds benefited from the rally in Treasuries. This diversification continues to offer our clients many appealing investment options and cross-selling opportunities for our sales teams. 
Our assets under management were up 2% for the year but we were not immune to the downturn in global markets seen in recent months. This is evidenced by a 10% decrease in AUM to $659.9 billion for the quarter, average AUM also decreased to 2% to $714.4 billion. Positive fixed income flows combined with the continued slump in equity markets continued to drive the mix in AUM by investment objective towards fixed income. The mix of AUM by sales region was essentially unchanged from June, but Europe and Asia continued to be the fastest-growing regions for us. Despite industry outflows in Italy and Germany, Italy remained our top selling non-U.S. market this quarter followed by Hong Kong and Germany. 
Turning to Slide 10, the decrease in AUM since June was due almost entirely to market depreciation of $87.6 billion. Net new flows remained positive at $3.1 billion. Though the part of the summer was clearly more favorable as market turmoil impacted flows later in the quarter. Long-term sales dropped 8% this quarter but increased 4% versus the quarter a year ago. Lower net new flows resulted from a combination of declining long-term gross sales and increasing redemptions in retail funds through the second half of the quarter, as well as a few large institutional redemptions. 
Long-term sales were once again strongest in global fixed income this quarter. The Templeton Global Bond Fund and the Global Total Return Fund continued to be our best sellers but did suffered net outflows in 1 week late in the quarter. Concerns over a decline in short-term performance drilled these outflows. We believe that most financial advisors who are familiar with the investment strategies for these funds remained confident that when the high levels of market volatility subside and fundamentals once again drive currencies, credit spreads and interest rates, the fund's NAVs will extend their recent recovery. 
While long-term growth sales and other asset classes have generally declined this quarter, sales in our tax refunds have picked up, resulting in decline in net outflows to $300 million for the quarter, the lowest level since the first quarter of the fiscal year. In fact, 10 more funds returned to positive flows. 
Our Institutional business experienced some significant redemptions and new mandates this quarter. In the global equity category, we saw redemptions of $2.7 billion in institutional separate account closures from 5 investors in a variety of global strategies. However this was partially offset by several new institutional mandates and new sovereign and pension fund accounts in both the U.S. and internationally. 
We continue to expand our international product offerings this quarter, including the registration of 11 C Cap funds for sale in Romania. In addition, we completed the acquisition of Australian-based Balanced Equity Management in July. In the U.K., the former Rensburg Trust have been converted to OIX and will now be actively promoted under the Franklin Templeton Investments brand. We also launched the Global Asset Allocation Fund in July to extend our product lineup in tactical asset allocation. 
Looking a little further along the product development cycle, you can see the potential long-term benefits of these types of investments. The C Cap versions of our Franklin World Perspectives Fund, which we launched near the depths of the financial crisis hit their key 3-year anniversary marks earlier this month, with both top quartile relative performance numbers and exceptional absolute returns since inception. This is a unique product created to leverage the strengths of the firm's local asset management teams around the world by combining our global perspective and local focus within a single portfolio, providing clients with a global growth fund featuring access to both local research and local asset management. 
Overall, we're pleased with our continued sales amount of during this fiscal year. We ended the year with $221 billion in long-term gross sales, a 17% increase over the record-breaking year in 2010. Europe was the largest contributor of assets and net sales with $87 billion and $22 billion respectively. Taiwan remains our largest market in Asia with $21 billion in assets while Hong Kong is closing in on the $10 billion mark. Our business in Malaysia also continues to grow quickly with $2 billion in assets further illustrating the strength and breath of our global business and product offerings. 
Turning to Slide 12, overall equity outflows have steadily increased since March due to the pullback in equity markets and flows have been negative since June as the industry experienced redemptions. Long-term sales of both global and U.S. equity funds declined in the face of the market turmoil and redemptions from global equity were elevated this quarter due to institutional withdrawals I mentioned earlier. A few funds on the retail side attracted increased sales and net new flows compared to last quarter, most notably the Franklin gold and precious metals and the Franklin India blue-chip funds. But overall, we saw an increase in outflows from retail investors. 
U.S. equity funds saw a continued increase in redemption activity though some funds have been attracting continued debt inflow such as the Franklin growth, rising dividends and Franklin utilities. We continue to promote the value of long-term investment global equity funds to financial advisors and their clients through the GLOBAL - THE NEW CORE theme, which is an extension of our 2020 Vision campaign. We've also focused on maintaining transparent and informative commentaries with advisors and investors, especially following the recent events that led to increased market volatility and have provided commentary with a market perspective from a variety of portfolio managers. 
Hybrid funds, including the Franklin income fund experienced net outflows of $800 million this quarter, primarily due to a variable annuity insurance program redemption. Global international fixed income flows were once again strongly positive for the quarter led by Global Bond and Global Total Return. U.S. fixed income slipped into outflows, the tax-free fixed income net outflows improved significantly with the Franklin Federal Intermediate-term tax-free income fund showing the biggest turnaround in this category. Cash management products had inflows of $600 million this quarter but still represent a very small part of our business. I will now turn it over to Ken for the operating results.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks, Greg. The strength of the company continues to be reflected in our operating results. Operating income for the quarter was $688 million, a 1% increase from the third quarter and a 35% from the prior year and a record for the company. Net inc
componenttext:
Okay, thanks, Greg. The strength of the company continues to be reflected in our operating results. Operating income for the quarter was $688 million, a 1% increase from the third quarter and a 35% from the prior year and a record for the company. Net income for the quarter was down 17% from the third quarter at $416 million and earnings per share decreased accordingly to $1.88 due to unrealized mark-to-market losses on various investments, which I'll discuss in a moment. 
Net income for the year was $1.9 billion, up 33% from the prior year and earnings per share was $8.62 for the year, up 36% from the prior year. Investment management fees increased 2% for the quarter and included some items requiring explanation. Normalizing the results to exclude these items, results in the 3% decreased in investment management fees, which makes sense given a 2% decrease in average assets under management and a slight reduction to the blended effectively fee rate due to the mixshift towards fixed income that Greg mentioned earlier, as well as the acquisition of Balanced Equity Management in July. 
Balanced Equity Management has a lower effective fee rate due to the size of nature of their client base. Part of the increase in total investment management fee revenue was attributable to an increase in performance face of $47.6 million and that related to the carried interest from the sale of assets from Darby emerging markets fund which we mentioned last quarter. 
It's also worth noting that on October 3, the second and final piece of a previously discussed redemption of a very low and flat fee advisory count was incurred. The first portion of this redemption was reported in the first fiscal quarter of the year and the remaining $11 billion of assets in this account will come out in this month's assets under management release but effect on our earnings should be immaterial as the account was only generating about $2 million of annual revenue. What you should see as a result is a decrease in average assets under management with nearly offsetting the increase in the effectively rate. 
Sales and distribution fees decreased 7% consistent with the decrease in average assets under management and sales. The asset base revenue component, which comprises most of this line declined 2% due to decreased average assets under management and the sales component decreased by 6.8% because of the decrease in U.S. sales, which was partially offset by an increase in international sales. Shareholder servicing fees were $75.5 million, a decrease of 3%, which is less than a decrease in billable accounts due to the July purge of 2.2 million U.S. accounts that we mentioned last quarter. The remaining decrease was attributable to a decline in networking fees due to the conversion of network accounts into omnibus accounts.  Other net revenue was essentially flat for the quarter. 
Now turning to expenses on Slide 16, we can see that they decreased 2% compared with the previous quarter. The decrease of 7% in sales, distribution and marketing expense was consistent with the 7% increase in revenue. Compensation and benefits was $309 million, a slight decrease from the prior quarter as increased salaries and incentive compensation were more than offset by lower sick and vacation pay, retirement and commission expenses. 
Information Systems and Technology expenses were up 21% this quarter as projects were expensed is completed in the final quarter of the fiscal year. Occupancy expense was up 10% due to the increases in building maintenance, utility costs and equipment depreciation. General, administrative and other expense was up 32% this quarter largely due to $11.1 million of fees related to the Darby carried interest payments and seasonal increase in advertising and promotional expenses. Now because the relationship between noncontrolling interest and consolidated sponsored investment products and variable interest entities was having some confusion since they impact different parts of the income statement, we've updated Slide 17 to make their relationship clear. Other income net of noncontrolling interests swung to a loss of $68.5 million compared to a gain of almost $30 million last quarter. The primary reason for that change was mark-to-market losses in investment securities. And although we had income from dividends, interest capital gains, gains on available-for-sale investments and positive foreign exchange revaluations, we experienced approximately $160 million of mark-to-market unrealized losses in our equity method and trading investments, consolidated sponsored investment products and consolidated variable interest entities. 
And of course, we seen those marks turn favorable as the market environment has improved recently. Interest expense was a little higher this month due to an increase in our tax reserve. 
Turning to Slide 18. The year-to-date effective tax rate increased 1.5% this quarter, although this rate is higher than we expected, the increase is primarily due to a shift in the net earnings mix towards higher tax jurisdictions as a significant portion of our unrealized losses on investments were in lower tax jurisdictions and that reduced earnings in those jurisdictions as a percentage of taxable income. The annual rate has been fairly consistent over the past 4 years but we do experience quarterly volatility particularly as foreign-sourced earnings fluctuate. 
The operating margin for the quarter was 37.5% and that's roughly flat with the last 4 quarters. Cash and investments was $9.4 billion at September 30, including about $1 billion from variable interest entities. And we repurchased 3.1 million shares this quarter, decreasing shares outstanding to 217.7 million. Note that our 36% year-over-year growth in earnings per share exceeded the growth in net income attributable to the company by approximately 3% due to the benefits of EPS accretion resulting from this program. 
The payout ratio for the quarter was 94% due to the acceleration of repurchase activity as our stock price decreased. We remain committed to returning a substantial portion of free cash flow to shareholders over time. However, a substantial portion of cash and investments is held offshore or used to see new products and may not be available for repurchases or dividends. 
And that concludes our commentary on the fourth quarter results. As always, if you have any questions, please contact Investor Relations or Corporate Communications. Their contact information is located in the presentation and the press release. Thank you.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

Welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Commentary for the quarter ended September 30, 2011. 
Statements made in this commentary regarding Franklin Resources Inc., which are not historical facts, are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the Risk Factors and MD&A sections of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K filing. This commentary was pre-recorded.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Hello, and welcome to the fourth quarter earnings commentary. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. Our fourth quarter cap was, overall, a very successful year for the firm. Fourth quarter net new flows of $3.1 billion brought total flows
componenttext:
Hello, and welcome to the fourth quarter earnings commentary. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. Our fourth quarter cap was, overall, a very successful year for the firm. Fourth quarter net new flows of $3.1 billion brought total flows for the year to almost $37 billion, one of our best years ever, despite heightened market volatility over the past quarter. 
Long term sales for the year exceeded $200 billion for the first time, with more than 50% coming from non-U.S. sources. That success was reflected in our operating results, as revenues exceeded $7.1 billion and operating income and earnings per share rose 36% for the year.  Driving those results was a growth in operating revenue of 22% with expenses increasing 15%. 
The greatest source of our organic asset growth continued to be our global fixed income business with $11 billion in net new flows for the quarter. Equity markets continue to be under pressure amidst negative market sentiments, surrounding global financial markets, following the downgrade of the U.S. Treasury debt rating and the increasing concerns related to sovereign debt in the Eurozone. 
Most importantly, our long-term investment performance rankings have remained strong in this market environment with the majority of our assets ranking in Lipper's first quartile over the past 10 years. Strategically, we have continued to expand our global presence in key markets, including the acquisition of Australian-based Balanced Equity Management, which closed in July and the continued integration of U.K.-based Rensburg under the Franklin Templeton brand. 
In addition to expanding our capabilities across the globe, we continue to strengthen our presence in existing markets. We launched several new funds to meet evolving investor demand and extend our product lineup, particularly in technical asset allocation and won several new sovereign and institutional mandates this quarter. 
Overall, relative investment performance remains solid across our equity and fixed income strategies. Over the past 2 months, there's been increased retention focused on the short-term underperformance of some of our global bond strategies, due primarily to the rally in long-dated U.S. Treasuries and the strengthening of the U.S. dollar and yen relative to other currencies held in those portfolios. This is not the first time a strategy has experienced a period of short-term underperformance. But over the long term, it has delivered outstanding risk-adjusted return relative to its peers. 
We're also encouraged at the fund's recent rebound in relative performance over the past few weeks. I'd also like to remind everyone that 40% of our fixed income assets under management are in U.S. products, where several of our funds benefited from the rally in treasuries. This diversification continues to offer our clients many appealing investment options and cross-selling opportunities for our sales teams. 
Our assets under management were up 2% for the year but we were not immuned to the downturn in global markets seen in recent months. This is evidenced by a 10% decrease in AUM to $659.9 billion for the quarter. Average AUM also decreased 2% to $714.4 billion. Positive fixed income flows combined with the continued slump in equity markets continued to drive the mix in AUM by investment objective towards fixed income. The mix of AUM by sales region was essentially unchanged from June, but Europe and Asia continued to be the fastest-growing regions for us. Despite industry outflows in Italy and Germany, Italy remained our top selling non-U.S. market this quarter followed by Hong Kong and Germany. 
Turning to Slide 10. The decrease in AUM since June was due almost entirely to market depreciation of $87.6 billion. Net new flows remained positive at $3.1 billion. Though the early part of the summer was clearly more favorable, as market turmoil impacted flows later in the quarter. Long-term sales dropped to 8% this quarter but increased 4% versus the quarter a year ago. Lower net new flows resulted from a combination of declining long-term gross sales and increasing redemptions in retail funds through the second half of the quarter, as well as a few large institutional redemptions. 
Long-term sales were once again strongest in global fixed income this quarter. The Templeton Global Bond Fund and the Global Total Return Fund continued to be our best sellers but did suffer net outflows in one week late in the quarter. Concerns over a decline in short-term performance drilled these outflows. We believe that most financial advisors, who are familiar with the investment strategy for these funds, remained confident that when the high levels of market volatility subside and fundamentals once again drive currencies, credit spreads and interest rates, the fund's NAVs will extend their recent recovery. 
While long-term growth sales and other asset classes had generally declined this quarter, sales in our tax refunds have picked up, resulting in decline in net outflows to $300 million for the quarter, the lowest level since the first quarter of the fiscal year. In fact, 10 more funds returned to positive flows. 
Our institutional business experienced some significant redemptions and new mandates this quarter. In the global equity category, we saw redemptions of $2.7 billion in institutional separate account closures from 5 investors in a variety of global strategies. However, this was partially offset by several new institutional mandates and new sovereign and pension fund accounts in both the U.S. and internationally. 
We continue to expand our international product offerings this quarter, including the registration of 11 C Cap funds for sale in Romania. In addition, we completed the acquisition of Australian-based Balanced Equity Management in July. In the U.K., the former Rensburg Unit Trust have been converted to OEIC and will now be actively promoted under the Franklin Templeton Investments brand. We also launched the Global Asset Allocation Fund in July to extend our product lineup in tactical asset allocation. 
Looking a little further along the product development cycle, you can see the potential long-term benefits of these types of investments. The C Cap versions of our Franklin World Perspectives Fund, which we launched near the depths of the financial crisis hit their key 3-year anniversary marks earlier this month, with both top quartile relative performance numbers and exceptional absolute returns since inception. This is a unique product created to leverage the strengths of the firm's local asset management teams around the world by combining our global perspective and local focus within a single portfolio, providing clients with a global growth fund, featuring access to both local research and local asset management. 
Overall, we are pleased with our continued sales momentum during this fiscal year. We ended the year with $221 billion in long-term gross sales, a 17% increase over the record-breaking year in 2010. Europe was the largest contributor of assets and net sales with $87 billion and $22 billion respectively. Taiwan remains our largest market in Asia with $21 billion in assets, while Hong Kong is closing in on the $10 billion mark. Our business in Malaysia also continues to grow quickly with $2 billion in assets further illustrating the strength and breadth of our global business and product offerings. 
Turning to Slide 12. Overall equity outflows have steadily increased since March due to the pullback in equity markets and flows have been negative since June as the industry experienced redemptions. Long-term sales of both global and U.S. equity funds declined in the face of the market turmoil, and redemptions from global equity were elevated this quarter due to institutional withdrawals I mentioned earlier. A few funds on the retail side attracted increased sales and net new flows compared to last quarter, most notably the Franklin Global precious metals and the Franklin India Bluechip funds. But overall, we saw an increase in outflows from retail investors. 
U.S. equity funds saw a continued increase in redemption activity, though some funds have been attracting continued debt inflow such as the Franklin Growth, Rising Dividends and Franklin Utilities. We continue to promote the value of long-term investment in global equity funds to financial advisors and their clients through the GLOBAL - THE NEW CORE theme, which is an extension of our 2020 Vision campaign. We have also focused on maintaining transparent and informative commentaries with advisors and investors, especially following the recent events that led to increased market volatility and have provided commentary with market perspective from a variety of portfolio managers. 
Hybrid funds, including the Franklin Income Fund experienced net outflows of $800 million this quarter, primarily due to a variable annuity insurance program redemption. Global international fixed income flows were once again strongly positive for the quarter led by Global Bond and Global Total Return. U.S. fixed income slipped into outflows. The tax-free fixed income net outflows improved significantly with the Franklin Federal Intermediate-Term Tax-free Income Fund, showing the biggest turnaround in this category. Cash management products had inflows of $600 million this quarter but still represent a very small part of our business. 
I will now turn it over to Ken for the operating results.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks, Greg. The strength of the company continues to be reflected in our operating results. Operating income for the quarter was $688 million, a 1% increase from the third quarter and a 35% from the prior year and a record for the company. Net inc
componenttext:
Okay, thanks, Greg. The strength of the company continues to be reflected in our operating results. Operating income for the quarter was $688 million, a 1% increase from the third quarter and a 35% from the prior year and a record for the company. Net income for the quarter was down 17% from the third quarter at $416 million. And earnings per share decreased accordingly to $1.88 due to unrealized marked-to-market losses on various investments, which I'll discuss in a moment. 
Net income for the year was $1.9 billion, up 33% from the prior year and earnings per share was $8.62 for the year, up 36% from the prior year. Investment management fees increased 2% for the quarter and included some items requiring explanation. Normalizing the results to exclude these items, results in the 3% decrease in investment management fees, which makes sense given a 2% decrease in average assets under management and a slight reduction to the blended effective fee rate due to the mix shift towards fixed income that Greg mentioned earlier, as well as the acquisition of Balanced Equity Management in July. 
Balanced Equity Management has a lower effective fee rate due to the size and nature of their client base. Part of the increase in total investment management fee revenue was attributable to an increase in performance fees of $47.6 million, and that related to the carried interest from the sale of assets from Darby emerging markets fund which we mentioned last quarter. 
It's also worth noting that on October 3, the second and final piece of a previously discussed redemption of a very low and flat-fee advisory count was incurred. The first portion of this redemption was reported in the first fiscal quarter of the year, and the remaining $11 billion of assets in this account will come out in this month's assets under management release, so the effect on our earnings should be immaterial, as the account was only generating about $2 million of annual revenue. What you should see, as a result, is a decrease in average assets under management with a nearly-offsetting increase in the effectively rate. 
Sales and distribution fees decreased 7% consistent with the decrease in average assets under management and sales. The asset-based revenue component, which comprises most of this line declined 2% due to decreased average assets under management and, the sales component decreased by 6.8% because of a decrease in U.S. sales, which was partially offset by an increase in the international sales. Shareholder servicing fees were $75.5 million, a decrease of 3%, which is less than the decrease in billable accounts due to the July purge of 2.2 million U.S. accounts that we mentioned last quarter. The remaining decrease was attributable to a decline in networking fees due to the conversion of network accounts into omnibus accounts.  Other net revenue was essentially flat for the quarter. 
Now turning to expenses on Slide 16, we can see that they decreased 2% compared with the previous quarter. The decrease of 7% in sales, distribution and marketing expense was consistent with the 7% increase in revenue. Compensation and benefits was $309 million, a slight decrease from the prior quarter as increased salaries and incentive compensation were more than offset by lower sick and vacation pay, retirement and commission expenses. 
Information systems and technology expenses were up 21% this quarter as projects were expensed and is completed in the final quarter of the fiscal year. Occupancy expense was up 10% due to the increases in building maintenance, utility costs and equipment depreciation. 
General, administrative and other expense was up 32% this quarter largely due to $11.1 million of fees related to the Darby carried interest payment and a seasonal increase in advertising and promotional expenses. 
Now because the relationship between noncontrolling interest and consolidated sponsored investment products and variable interest entities was causing some confusion, since they impact different parts of the income statement, we've updated Slide 17 to make their relationship clearer. 
Other income net of noncontrolling interests swung to a loss of $68.5 million compared to a gain of almost $30 million last quarter. The primary reason for that change was marked-to-market losses in investment securities. And although we had income from dividends, interest capital gains, gains on available-for-sale investments and positive foreign exchange revaluations, we experienced approximately $160 million of marked-to-market unrealized losses in our equity method and trading investments, consolidated sponsored investment products and consolidated variable interest entities.  And of course, we've seen those marks turn favorable as the market environment has improved recently. Interest expense was a little higher this month due to an increase in our tax reserve. 
Turning to Slide 18. The year-to-date effective tax rate increased 1.5% this quarter. Although this rate is higher than we expected, the increase is primarily due to a shift in the net earnings mix towards higher tax jurisdictions, as a significant portion of our unrealized losses on investments were in lower tax jurisdictions, and that reduced earnings in those jurisdictions as a percentage of taxable income. The annual rate has been fairly consistent over the past 4 years, but we do experience quarterly volatility, particularly, as foreign-source earnings fluctuate. 
The operating margin for the quarter was 37.5%, and that's roughly flat with the last 4 quarters. Cash and investments was $9.4 billion at September 30, including about $1 billion from variable interest entities. And we repurchased 3.1 million shares this quarter, decreasing shares outstanding to 217.7 million. Note that our 36% year-over-year growth in earnings per share exceeded the growth in net income attributable to the company by approximately 3% due to the benefits of EPS accretion, resulting from this program. 
The payout ratio for the quarter was 94% due to the acceleration of repurchase activity as our stock price decreased. We remain committed to returning a substantial portion of free cash flow to shareholders over time. However, a substantial portion of cash and investments is held offshore or used to see new products and may not be available for repurchases or dividends. 
And that concludes our commentary on the fourth quarter results. As always, if you have any questions, please contact Investor Relations or Corporate Communications. Their contact information is located in the presentation and the press release. Thank you.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome, thanks you for taking the time out to join Ken Lewis and I today for our call. I think, first of all, considering the volatility during the first we're pleased to report positive net flows of just over $3
componenttext: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome, thanks you for taking the time out to join Ken Lewis and I today for our call. I think, first of all, considering the volatility during the first we're pleased to report positive net flows of just over $3 billion. We're also pleased to report record operating earnings of $688 million. And now, we'd like to open it up for your questions. Thank you.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Cynthia Mayer from Bank of America.

And also, I think you mentioned some inflows, I'm wondering what the net is of institutional flows to the international global equity overall?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that's a good question. I think there were 5 different one peak and each of them less for a different reason within global equities. There were 2  kind of long-standing state relationships that one in emerging markets and one in [indiscernible] an
componenttext: I think that's a good question. I think there were 5 different one peak and each of them less for a different reason within global equities. There were 2  kind of long-standing state relationships that one in emerging markets and one in [indiscernible] and some of that is performance, and some of it is moving to passive. But it did result in, I think, about $1.6 billion and $1.7 billion, between the 2 of those. And then we had another significant in account in the variable annuity side on the mutual series, discovery side that moved to an in-house manager within one of the large insurance companies that wasn't as much performance-related. And sometimes there's just timing differences. When these redemptions were been made, it could've been lagging at that time and taken a while. And more of the recent rebound in performance may not have been considered.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
