componenttext: Okay. And just as a follow-up, I think you mentioned Italy was your top-selling area. Was that sales of global bond? And what if any impact you think the European agreement on recapitalizing the banks would have on European's appetite for Global Bond Fund?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's a little early to assess that. I still think it as an alternative category, and obviously, a positive overall for how that fund is positioned and how well it's done. And some of the weakness, which we felt was more short-term certainly
componenttext: Well, I think it's a little early to assess that. I still think it as an alternative category, and obviously, a positive overall for how that fund is positioned and how well it's done. And some of the weakness, which we felt was more short-term certainly turned around here in the last few weeks. So as far as what happens in terms of flows, I think just overall, as you would expect over the last week, we had negative outflows in the global bond category. And that pressure continued early into the New Year. We don't really like to comment a whole lot on where fund flows are going. But I think in this case, just due to some of the information that's been out there, we'll say that we have been pleased to see how it has been very steady despite that one short period of underperformance. And net-net, year-to-date, probably around breakeven overall within an improving trend. And U.S. doing better than Europe as far as looking at the flows within the 2 regions.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up with the Global Bond Fund. I understand the performance has snapped back pretty sharply in the last month other so. But just given the performance hiccup, if you will, are you concerned at all that you might be a risk of some of reverse h
componenttext: Just a follow-up with the Global Bond Fund. I understand the performance has snapped back pretty sharply in the last month other so. But just given the performance hiccup, if you will, are you concerned at all that you might be a risk of some of reverse halo effect where maybe some of your other global fixed income funds might be susceptible to a slowdown in flows either across kind of retailer and channels?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. I think any time you have that kind of volatility, yes, there will be a speed bump and slow things down. And certain people will have a new appreciation for the kind of volatility that you can see in that kind of a fund. And we've always
componenttext: I don't think so. I think any time you have that kind of volatility, yes, there will be a speed bump and slow things down. And certain people will have a new appreciation for the kind of volatility that you can see in that kind of a fund. And we've always said that this is a fund that's not been benchmark-oriented. And as far as how it's run end of its performance has been so outstanding over time that you will have short-term periods of underperformance. And if you look back in the history of this fund, it's had a couple of periods where it's been down 7% or 8%. So it's not unusual to have that. And it's the kind of style a lot of people are looking for as far as trying to get that outflow from active management in there. So we've already been encouraged by the snapback in flows and positive flows with the U.S. certainly on the U.S. side with Global Bond Fund. I think if you look at the absolute numbers and for the year, nobody's lost money in that. Our relative performance is down a little bit, but that's been coming back. But as far as the -- it has a positive return for the year, close to a positive return today. I think that, that's very important in the psychology of money and new money coming in. And we're still encouraged by the tremendous overall record that it has, and short-term things can move very quickly especially with currencies.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just given kind of the decline in the AUM and the slowdown in net flows more recently. Are you at the stage where you may be starting to kind of tap the brakes on some projects or reinvestment spending? And then just more broadly, how much
componenttext: Okay. And then just given kind of the decline in the AUM and the slowdown in net flows more recently. Are you at the stage where you may be starting to kind of tap the brakes on some projects or reinvestment spending? And then just more broadly, how much flexibility do you have on the expense side to kind of defend margins looking forward assuming the markets remain volatile?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Ken, I'll take that one. As you probably expect in the answer, we are definitely closely monitoring the expenses. I'd say in the short-term, our objective is to keep expenses relatively flat for the next quarter, and some lines will be more succes
componenttext: This is Ken, I'll take that one. As you probably expect in the answer, we are definitely closely monitoring the expenses. I'd say in the short-term, our objective is to keep expenses relatively flat for the next quarter, and some lines will be more successful than others. But certainly that's the message for the troops that we're watching expenses. We haven't decided to take any formal programs of cost reductions or any of that. But certainly, we're delaying and deferring the projects. So I think there is a fair amount of flexibility, but it takes a little bit of time. And so just as a were back global financial crisis in 2008 -- 2007, 2008, pretty thoughtful about it, if the markets come back if it's a protracted decline or what have you, and then we kind of make decisions realtime.

componenttext: I don't think anything's changed. I think we have seen a pick up in the total return fund that has corporates in there as well, but in addition to sovereign debt. So I think that's taken some of the pressure of the global bond side. And certainly if there's any silver lining in the last quarter, one could argue of more capacity on the selloff and some redemptions. But the reality is, sovereign debt, it's a huge and liquid pool, and we don't see any constraints at this time.

componenttext: And maybe one a little bit -- heavy ICI board, sort of curious and I know you haven't been there very long, in fact, perform on tape as saying, everything's on a joint board, if you will. headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think there's much news there from what's been published in the press. And it's a high priority in Washington, and they're looking at ways to deal with the perception of the systemic risk involved with maintaining the dollar NAV. I think it's impo
componenttext: I don't think there's much news there from what's been published in the press. And it's a high priority in Washington, and they're looking at ways to deal with the perception of the systemic risk involved with maintaining the dollar NAV. I think it's important to note changes have been made to date to improve the credit and liquidity and money funds. But there's an urgency to do more than that. And that's really when it see everything is on the table, everything is on the table as far as looking at alternatives from capital requirements and different ways just to deal with first losses and funds and things like that. So it's going to continue, and you're going to hear things, but I don't have anything new to report from what's already out there.

There was also some expense line items that are correlated to market values, so the valuation of mutual fund performance awards and all of that. So you see some credits in there reducing the expense. So in general, I would say that for this level of revenue, the expense line item is a little bit below you would normally expect to see going forward.  And I don't see any real changes on some of the recent actions in Europe as far as the banks, and the banks are critical to distribution. But I think the overall trend to be more receptive to outside managers is something that still continues today. And I don't really have anything to add on anything else on that.

componenttext: Sure. One of the line items that have some seasonality is a general and administrative and other. With the reclassification that we did last year, advertising. And seasonally that does decrease in the first quarter, so I would expect to see that. And as well, as we talked about kind of watching the expenses, that's usually the criticize that we can control and react to, reduce travel, that kind of thing. On the technology side, I think this is a pretty good run rate. It might be a little bit of seasonal uptick in that line, but I wouldn't call it significant.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Greg, you mentioned some of the new products that you guys have been working on the asset allocation, the world perspective fund, I think those were hit in the 3 years. I guess, what are you seeing from a traction standpoint? Where is the interest?
componenttext: Okay. Greg, you mentioned some of the new products that you guys have been working on the asset allocation, the world perspective fund, I think those were hit in the 3 years. I guess, what are you seeing from a traction standpoint? Where is the interest? And then in terms of these products, do they fund into a variety of your products, or specific products onto themselves?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's still early to -- it's only been out there a few months as far as the tactical asset allocation. They do feed in multiple funds, probably over 10. So our expectations there that will take a little bit of time to get going. I think the World P
componenttext: I think it's still early to -- it's only been out there a few months as far as the tactical asset allocation. They do feed in multiple funds, probably over 10. So our expectations there that will take a little bit of time to get going. I think the World Perspectives Fund just give us another area on the global equity side where we have leverage the local asset managers and really built a strong record that in hitting the 3-year number, we highlight that because that's always a hurdle for getting on platforms and making sure you've been out there for 3 years. So that hasn't gotten a lot of attention in the system, but now it that it has strong performance and out there for a while and has a unique story, it's one that we'd be talking about next year. But really, as far as flows, I think we're pleased to see that munis have come back and continue to come back. And hopefully, it will be in   a positive net mode this quarter. It's a long way from where we were a few quarters ago. I think the Franklin Income Fund had a -- hybrid had an unusually tough quarter, and most of that again was due to a variable annuity account that affected the flow number there. And I expect the income fund to  come back as well as far as those being the areas that I think are going to do well.

componenttext: One of your competitors recently talked about more indexing initiatives and fixed income because of low current yields. Have you heard any conversations within some of your some of products face about lowering some of your abnormally higher fixed-income fees of your other products?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the good news is, we're in the lower end of that as far as expenses, and that's always been that way if you like munis in governments. I think global bonds is in category of its own, not your typical fixed income that would be under the normal kin
componenttext: I think the good news is, we're in the lower end of that as far as expenses, and that's always been that way if you like munis in governments. I think global bonds is in category of its own, not your typical fixed income that would be under the normal kind of pressure. But I think that's fair. Everybody in the higher to mid end in fixed income in a lower-yield environment, it's going to put pressure, not only on the yield you can pay, but also where you fall in your liquid categories. And the expenses become very important in how you're ranked in total returns. So we haven't felt that pressure in many of our fund.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greg, maybe you can address your strategy outside the U.S. particularly in parts of Asia where maybe growth outlook is a bit stronger. How are you thinking about acquisitions? You got a decent amount of cash overseas. Is that sort of an advantage for you
componenttext: Greg, maybe you can address your strategy outside the U.S. particularly in parts of Asia where maybe growth outlook is a bit stronger. How are you thinking about acquisitions? You got a decent amount of cash overseas. Is that sort of an advantage for you to go out and start to accelerate your growth in some of those faster-growing regions, particularly as some of your competitions are looking there as well?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we've addressed that question on many different calls. And for us, the answer is always looking for what we think makes sense. And I think one problem you have is if you're in these markets and you're a local manager, you're not going to pay
componenttext: Well, I think we've addressed that question on many different calls. And for us, the answer is always looking for what we think makes sense. And I think one problem you have is if you're in these markets and you're a local manager, you're not going to pay a strategic premium to buy another manager in that market. And there's many U.S. managers or European managers they're doing the same thing that want to get in those markets. And if you look at India and some of the prices that they pay to get into that market, that would it make sense for us if we're already in it. I think it's a barrier today that's still very much in place. But we're certainly looking at anything that we think fills a gap or can make us stronger and we combine and get cost savings that way. But a lot of these faster-growing markets are going to be much higher premium for higher multiple to buy into, and we're already in it.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

componenttext: Okay. And then could you just talk about capital priorities. Obviously, you guys have been busy buying back some stock or what have you. How are you thinking about your capital priorities?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think no new news on that front. In terms of returning dollars to shareholders, preference to buybacks, focusing on the dividend growth rate that should continue. And as you saw, we're opportunistic, and when we see opportunity like that, we'll do that
componenttext: I think no new news on that front. In terms of returning dollars to shareholders, preference to buybacks, focusing on the dividend growth rate that should continue. And as you saw, we're opportunistic, and when we see opportunity like that, we'll do that again.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

componenttext: Our next question comes from Ken Worthington from JPMorgan.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: To follow up on Cynthia's question, in terms of the sales in Templeton Equity, is there any merit to thought that the success in the bond fund has monopolized the sales effort or maybe diverted sales from the equity side of Templeton? And could it be that
componenttext: To follow up on Cynthia's question, in terms of the sales in Templeton Equity, is there any merit to thought that the success in the bond fund has monopolized the sales effort or maybe diverted sales from the equity side of Templeton? And could it be that the choppiness in global bond or total return maybe becoming a catalyst to better sales on the equity side of Templeton? Because, again, to Cynthia's point, it seems that the performance there, the asset classes that in favor, but maybe the bond fund has been so successful it's just the easy thing to sell. So any merit to that?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think one, I -- and probably should have done this earlier is point to, if you look at where we had most of our add-ons and wins on the institutional side, there in global equity and global bonds during this quarter, so you just had some big large ones
componenttext: I think one, I -- and probably should have done this earlier is point to, if you look at where we had most of our add-ons and wins on the institutional side, there in global equity and global bonds during this quarter, so you just had some big large ones that overshadowed those come out. But we have a lot of $200 million, $300 million wins. So that tells you it's not really a performance issue, and we had some add-ons that were significant to existing accounts as well. There's always reason that certain fund on the institutional side and maybe that, that one underperformed the overall composite. There's things that can happen that way, and that could be the case in one of those. I think the distribution effort has been very much focused. One of our priorities for the year was to make sure that Templeton was getting the right exposure in the system. And we actually saw that the Templeton foreign fund improved its sales quite a bit market share within the nonproprietary channel here. And we're going to continue that. The campaign that we're running now is global. It's the new core. It very much highlights Templeton. So our goal is to make sure that we're always balanced in what we're talking about despite sometimes the sales flows may not reflect them.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: So there was a lot of noise in the operating line this quarter related to the market volatility, and it was unrealized. And the whole book when you look at it is still in a net gain position, and so we kind of -- keep in mind that a lot of this seed capit
componenttext: So there was a lot of noise in the operating line this quarter related to the market volatility, and it was unrealized. And the whole book when you look at it is still in a net gain position, and so we kind of -- keep in mind that a lot of this seed capital, so we're keeping that contained, if you will, re-purposing old investments that have been successful or didn't work out into new investments. But that does leave you exposed to equity markets and the like. But that's our approach. It's kind of -- we have pools of investments that we used for product development purposes that in a sense notionally fixed, if you will. And the business seems to know that that's a limited resource, but you still get this exposure. And so I would add, obviously, as markets pick up, there would be a reasonable assumption to see a lot more green bars on that Slide 17 replacing the red ones this quarter.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess, a general one, I know it's sort of early in this market move, but are you guys speaking up at all any increased interest of the retail side to get back into equities? Usually people go to fixed income first, but given where rates have been, I'm j
componenttext: I guess, a general one, I know it's sort of early in this market move, but are you guys speaking up at all any increased interest of the retail side to get back into equities? Usually people go to fixed income first, but given where rates have been, I'm just wondering if you're seeing a little bit more light in the tunnel for retail equities given the movement in market in October?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I definitely see there's more light, but that probably means redemptions will slow down versus sales speaking up. And it's just going to take I think a little bit more time to convince the equity buyer that the best it's time to jump back in. And there's
componenttext: I definitely see there's more light, but that probably means redemptions will slow down versus sales speaking up. And it's just going to take I think a little bit more time to convince the equity buyer that the best it's time to jump back in. And there's just been a lot of volatility in the marketplace, and I think that just works against the long-term investor right now.

componenttext: Our next question comes from Bill Katz from Citi.

componenttext: Just a follow-up, a little more clarity, in terms of the world allocation funds where the 3-year performance have moved into that anniversary. Just curious where you might see the best short-term opportunity.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it could be either one. I mean, it just depends which group. I think the good news with Europe is that you can get on platforms, and that could mean faster world of assets, more like an institutional accounts versus the U.S. where it takes you mor
componenttext: I think it could be either one. I mean, it just depends which group. I think the good news with Europe is that you can get on platforms, and that could mean faster world of assets, more like an institutional accounts versus the U.S. where it takes you more time as the distribution system has to work with the advisors to get them comfortable with it. So probably on the immediate term, you could argue that Europe would be a quicker immediate opportunity. But I think remains to be seen, and I wouldn't bet either way.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

componenttext: And one more, in terms of -- I think you mentioned in your prepared remarks earlier today that some funds into Romania, so it laid out a whole set of funds and also some SICAV shifting to -- conversion to ONX with the new platforms. What kind of ramp in terms of that new business?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I mean, I don't think the Romania would be something that's going to move the needle very much for us in the near-term. I think the Mintzberg is getting that position properly. And if the European market continues to move, that's something that would agai
componenttext: I mean, I don't think the Romania would be something that's going to move the needle very much for us in the near-term. I think the Mintzberg is getting that position properly. And if the European market continues to move, that's something that would again be a new offering for us and one that we're going to try to build, and that's going to prayer to the U.K. market. But again, these are not big initiatives that we expect. They're going to take time to build.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Conference Call for the quarter ended September 30, 2011. My name is John, and I'll be your operator for today.Please note that the financial results to be discussed in this conference call are
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Conference Call for the quarter ended September 30, 2011. My name is John, and I'll be your operator for today.
Please note that the financial results to be discussed in this conference call are preliminary. Statements made in this conference call regarding Franklin Resources, Inc., which are not historical facts, are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from the future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the Risk Factors and MD&A sections of Franklin's most recent Form 10-Q filing. [Operator Instructions] 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. Greg Johnson. Mr. Johnson, you may begin.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome. Thanks for taking time out to join Ken Lewis and I today for our call. I think, first of all, considering the volatility during the quarter, we are pleased to report positive net flows of just over $3 bill
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome. Thanks for taking time out to join Ken Lewis and I today for our call. I think, first of all, considering the volatility during the quarter, we are pleased to report positive net flows of just over $3 billion. We are also pleased to report record operating earnings of $688 million. 
And now, we'd like to open it up to your questions. Thank you.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Cynthia Mayer from Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Cynthia Mayer from Bank of America.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just maybe question on the institutional global international flows you guys mentioned in the recorded commentary. It seems like given how good the 1- and 3-year performances for Templeton equity, I'm wondering what's behind institutional redemptions you
componenttext: Just maybe question on the institutional global international flows you guys mentioned in the recorded commentary. It seems like given how good the 1- and 3-year performances for Templeton equity, I'm wondering what's behind institutional redemptions you mentioned. And also I think you mentioned some inflows, I'm wondering what the net is of institutional flows to international global equity overall?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that's a good question. And there were, I think, 5 different lumpy and each of them was for a different reason within global equities. There were 2  kind of long-standing state relationships that one in emerging markets and one in [Audio Gap]a
componenttext:
I think that's a good question. And there were, I think, 5 different lumpy and each of them was for a different reason within global equities. There were 2  kind of long-standing state relationships that one in emerging markets and one in 
[Audio Gap]
and some of that is performance, and some of it's moving to passive, but it did result in, I think, about $1.6 billion and $1.7 billion, between the 2 of those. And then we had another significant account in the variable annuity side on the Mutual Series Discovery side that moved to an in-house manager within one of the large insurance companies that wasn't as much performance-related. And sometimes there's just timing differences. When these redemptions were made, it could have been lagging at that time and then taken a while. And more of the recent rebound in performance may not have been considered.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just as a follow-up, I think you mentioned Italy was your top-selling area. Was that sales of Global Bond? And what if any impact, do you think, the European agreement on recapitalizing the banks would have on European's appetite for Global Bond
componenttext: Okay. And just as a follow-up, I think you mentioned Italy was your top-selling area. Was that sales of Global Bond? And what if any impact, do you think, the European agreement on recapitalizing the banks would have on European's appetite for Global Bond Fund?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's probably a little early to assess that. I still think it's viewed as an alternative category, and obviously, a positive overall for how that fund is positioned and how well it's done. And some of the weakness, which we felt was more sho
componenttext: Well, I think it's probably a little early to assess that. I still think it's viewed as an alternative category, and obviously, a positive overall for how that fund is positioned and how well it's done. And some of the weakness, which we felt was more short term certainly turned around here in the last few weeks. So as far as what happens in terms of flows, I think, just overall, as you would expect the last week we had negative outflows within the global bond category and that pressure continued early into the New Year. We don't really like to comment a whole lot on where fund flows are going, but I think in this case, just due to some of the misinformation that's been out there, we'll say that we have been pleased to see how it has been very steady despite that one short period of underperformance. And net-net, year-to-date, probably around breakeven overall with an improving trend and U.S. doing better than Europe as far as looking at the flows within the 2 regions.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up with the Global Bond Fund. I understand the performance has snapped back pretty sharply in the last month other so. But just given the performance hiccup, if you will, are you concerned at all that you might be at risk of somewhat of a ki
componenttext: Just a follow-up with the Global Bond Fund. I understand the performance has snapped back pretty sharply in the last month other so. But just given the performance hiccup, if you will, are you concerned at all that you might be at risk of somewhat of a kind of a reverse halo effect where maybe some of your other global fixed income funds might be susceptible to a slowdown in flows, either across kind of retailer institutional channels?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. I think any time you have that kind of volatility, yes, it'll be a speed bump and slow things down. And certain people will have a new appreciation for the kind of volatility that you can see in that kind of a fund. And we've always said
componenttext: I don't think so. I think any time you have that kind of volatility, yes, it'll be a speed bump and slow things down. And certain people will have a new appreciation for the kind of volatility that you can see in that kind of a fund. And we've always said that this is a fund that's not really benchmark-oriented. And as far as how it's run and how its performance has been so outstanding over time that you will have short-term periods of underperformance. And if we look back in the history of this fund, it's had a couple of periods where it's been down 7% or 8%. So it's not unusual to have that. And it's the kind of style that I think a lot of people are looking for as far as trying to get that outflow from active management in there. So we've already been encouraged by the snapback in flows and positive flows with the U.S. -- certainly on the U.S. side with Global Bond. I think if you look at the absolute numbers and for the year, nobody's lost money in that. Our relative performance is down a little bit, but that's been coming back. But as far as the -- it has a positive return for the year, close to a positive return today. So that -- I think that, that's very important in the psychology of money and new money coming in. And we're still encouraged by the tremendous overall record that it has. And short-term things can move very quickly especially with currencies.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just given kind of the decline in AUM and the slowdown in net flows more recently, are you at the stage where you may be starting to kind of tap the brakes on some projects or reinvestment spending? And then just more broadly, how much flex
componenttext: Okay. And then just given kind of the decline in AUM and the slowdown in net flows more recently, are you at the stage where you may be starting to kind of tap the brakes on some projects or reinvestment spending? And then just more broadly, how much flexibility do you have on the expense side to kind of defend margins looking forward, assuming the markets remain volatile?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right. This is Ken, I'll take that one. As you probably expect in the answer, we are definitely closely monitoring the expenses. I'd say in the short term, our objective is to keep expenses relatively flat for the next quarter, and some lines will be more
componenttext: Right. This is Ken, I'll take that one. As you probably expect in the answer, we are definitely closely monitoring the expenses. I'd say in the short term, our objective is to keep expenses relatively flat for the next quarter, and some lines will be more successful than others for that. But certainly, that's the message for the troops, that we're watching expenses, though we haven't decided to take any formal programs of cost reductions or any of that. But certainly, we're delaying and deferring projects. So I think there is a fair amount of flexibility, but it takes a little bit of time. And so just as we were back in the global financial crisis in 2008 -- 2007, 2008, we're pretty thoughtful about it if the markets come back, if it's a protracted decline or what have you, and then we kind of make decisions real time.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Bill Katz from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bill Katz from Citi.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just one more yet again on the Global Bond Fund. Just from a bigger picture perspective, given the diversification of the platform, any thoughts around capacity and potentially closing that fund to avoid some of the -- maybe some of the redemption stresse
componenttext: Just one more yet again on the Global Bond Fund. Just from a bigger picture perspective, given the diversification of the platform, any thoughts around capacity and potentially closing that fund to avoid some of the -- maybe some of the redemption stresses and I guess market dislocations. Just sort of curious if you have thoughts on that.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think anything's changed. I think we have seen a pickup in the total return fund that has corporates in there as well in addition to sovereign debt, so I think that, that's taken some of the pressure off the growth on the Global Bond side. Certain
componenttext: I don't think anything's changed. I think we have seen a pickup in the total return fund that has corporates in there as well in addition to sovereign debt, so I think that, that's taken some of the pressure off the growth on the Global Bond side. Certainly, if there's any silver lining in the last quarter is one could argue you have more capacity on the selloff and some redemptions. But the reality is sovereign debt it's a huge and liquid pool, and we don't see any constraints at this time.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

componenttext: And maybe one a little bit on to being pat [ph], but congratulations on becoming the new head of the ICI Board. Just sort of curious and I know you haven't really been in it for very long, in fact, but money market performed -- I think you're on tape as saying, everything's was on the drawing board, if you will, so maybe your initial thoughts on where you see the money market perform, seems to be a lot of uncertainty, sort of curious of your thoughts.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think there's much news there from what's been published in the press, and it's a high priority in Washington. And they're looking at ways to deal with the perception of the systemic risk involved with maintaining the dollar NAV. I think it's impo
componenttext: I don't think there's much news there from what's been published in the press, and it's a high priority in Washington. And they're looking at ways to deal with the perception of the systemic risk involved with maintaining the dollar NAV. I think it's important to note that the changes have been made to date to improve the credit and liquidity in money funds. But there's an urgency to do more than that. And that's really when I see everything's on the table -- everything is on the table as far as looking at alternatives from capital requirements and different ways just to deal with first losses in funds and things like that. So it's going to continue and you're going to hear things, but I don't really have anything new to report from what's been already out there.

componenttext: I'll take the comp question first. Yes, there were some accrual adjustments. There was also -- there were some expense line items that are correlated to market values, so the valuation of mutual fund performance awards and all of that, so you saw some credits in there reducing the expense. So in general, I would say that for this level of revenue, the expense line items a little bit below what you would normally expect to see going forward.  And I don't see any real changes on some of the recent actions in Europe as far as the banks, and the banks are critical to distribution. But I think the overall trend of open architecture and being more receptive to outside managers is something that still continues today. And I don't really have anything to add on anything else on that.

componenttext: Sure. One of the line items that have some seasonality in it is the general, administrative and other. On the technology side, I think this is a pretty good run rate. It might be -- there might be a little bit of seasonal uptick in that line, but I wouldn't call it significant.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

componenttext: Okay. And then Greg, just -- you mentioned some of the new products that you guys have been working on: the asset allocation, the World Perspective Fund. I think those were hit in the 3 years. I guess, where is -- like, what are you seeing from a traction standpoint? Where is the interest? And then in terms of these products, do they fund into a variety of your products or are they just specific products in and of themselves?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's still early to -- it's only been out there a few months as far as the tactical asset allocation. They do feed into multiple funds, probably over 10. So our expectations there are that will take a little bit of time to get going. I think the W
componenttext: I think it's still early to -- it's only been out there a few months as far as the tactical asset allocation. They do feed into multiple funds, probably over 10. So our expectations there are that will take a little bit of time to get going. I think the World Perspectives Fund just gives us another arrow on the global equities side where we have leveraged the local asset managers and really built a very strong record that in hitting the 3-year number, we highlight that because that's always a hurdle for getting on platforms and making sure you've been out there for 3 years. So that hasn't gotten a lot of attention in the system, but now it that it has strong performance and have been out there for a while and has a unique story, it's one that, that we'll be talking about in the next year. But really, as far as flows, I think we're pleased to see that munis have come back and continue to come back and hopefully it will be in   a positive net mode this quarter, which is a long way from where we were a few quarters ago. I think the Franklin income fund had a -- hybrid had an unusually tough quarter and most of that again was due to a variable annuity account that affected the flow number there. And I expect the income fund to  come back as well as far. So those will be the areas that I think are going to continue to do well.

componenttext: One of your competitors recently talked about more indexing initiatives in fixed income because of low current yields. Have you heard of any conversations within some of your some of products fees about lowering some of your abnormally higher fixed-income fees, say, in some of your other products?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the good news is that we're on the lower end of that as far as expenses and have always been that way if you look at the munis in governments. I think the Global Bond is in a category of its own, not your typical fixed income that would be u
componenttext: Well, I think the good news is that we're on the lower end of that as far as expenses and have always been that way if you look at the munis in governments. I think the Global Bond is in a category of its own, not your typical fixed income that would be under the normal kind of pressure. But I think that's fair. Anybody on the higher to mid- end in fixed income in a lower-yield environment, it's going to put pressure, not only on the yield you can pay, but also where you fall in your liquid categories. And the expenses become very important in how you're ranked in total returns. So we haven't felt that pressure in many of our funds.

componenttext: Greg, maybe you can address your strategy outside the U.S., particularly in parts of Asia, where maybe the growth outlook is a bit stronger. How are you thinking about acquisitions? You've got also a decent amount of cash, I guess, overseas. And is that sort of an advantage for you to go out and maybe start to accelerate your growth in some of those faster-growing regions, particularly if some of the competitions are looking there as well?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we've addressed that question on many different calls. And for us, the answer is we're always out there looking for what we think makes sense. And I think the one problem you have is if you're in these markets and you're a local manager, you
componenttext: Well, I think we've addressed that question on many different calls. And for us, the answer is we're always out there looking for what we think makes sense. And I think the one problem you have is if you're in these markets and you're a local manager, you're not going to pay a strategic premium to buy another manager in that market and there's many U.S. managers or European managers that are doing the same thing that want to get into those markets. And if you look at India and some of the prices that were paid to get into that market, that wouldn't make sense for us if we're already in it. I think that's a barrier today that's still very much in place. But we're certainly looking at anything that we think fills the gap or can make us stronger and we can combine and get cost savings that way. But a lot of these faster-growing markets are going to be at much higher premium and higher multiple to buy into, and we're already in it.

So any merit to that?

componenttextpreview: I think, one, and I probably should have done this earlier is point to -- if you look at where we had most of our add-ons and wins on the institutional side, there were in global equity and Global Bonds during this quarter, so you just had some big large
componenttext: I think, one, and I probably should have done this earlier is point to -- if you look at where we had most of our add-ons and wins on the institutional side, there were in global equity and Global Bonds during this quarter, so you just had some big large ones that overshadowed those numbers come out. But we had a lot of $200 million, $300 million wins. So that tells you it's not really a performance issue, and we had some add-ons that were significant to existing accounts as well. There's always reason that certain fund on the institutional side and it maybe that, that one underperformed the overall composite. There's things that can happen that way and that could be the case in one of those. I don't -- I think the distribution effort has been very much focused. One of our priorities for the year was to make sure that Templeton was getting the right exposure in the system. And we actually saw that the Templeton foreign fund improved its sales quite a bit, market share within the nonproprietary channel here. And we're going to continue that. The campaign that we're running now is global. It's the new core, very much highlights Templeton. So our goal is to make sure that we're always balanced in what we're talking about despite sometimes that the sales flows may not reflect them.

componenttextpreview: Sure. So there was a lot of noise within an operating line this quarter related to the market volatility, and it was unrealized. And the whole book when you look at it, it's still in a net gain position. And so we kind of -- keep in mind that a lot of thi
componenttext: Sure. So there was a lot of noise within an operating line this quarter related to the market volatility, and it was unrealized. And the whole book when you look at it, it's still in a net gain position. And so we kind of -- keep in mind that a lot of this is seed capital, so we're keeping that contained and, if you will, re-purposing old investments that have either been successful or didn't work out into new investments. But that does leave you exposed to equity markets and the like. But that's our approach. It's kind of -- we have pools of investments that we used for product development purposes that are, in a sense, fixed -- notionally fixed, if you will. And the business units know that, that's a limited resource. But you still get this exposure, and so -- and I would add, obviously, as markets pick up, there'll be a reasonable assumption to see a lot more green bars on that Slide 17 replacing the red ones this quarter.

componenttext: I'd definitely say there's more light, but that probably means that redemptions will slow down versus sales picking up. headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Commentary for the quarter ended September 30, 2011. Statements made in this commentary regarding Franklin Resources Inc., which are not historical facts, are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Pr
componenttext:
Welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Commentary for the quarter ended September 30, 2011. 
Statements made in this commentary regarding Franklin Resources Inc., which are not historical facts, are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the Risk Factors and MD&A sections of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K filing. This commentary was pre-recorded.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Hello, and welcome to the fourth quarter earnings commentary. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. Our fourth quarter cap was, overall, a very successful year for the firm. Fourth quarter net new flows of $3.1 billion brought total flows
componenttext:
Hello, and welcome to the fourth quarter earnings commentary. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. Our fourth quarter cap was, overall, a very successful year for the firm. Fourth quarter net new flows of $3.1 billion brought total flows for the year to almost $37 billion, one of our best years ever, despite heightened market volatility over the past quarter. 
Long term sales for the year exceeded $200 billion for the first time, with more than 50% coming from non-U.S. sources. That success was reflected in our operating results, as revenues exceeded $7.1 billion and operating income and earnings per share rose 36% for the year.  Driving those results was a growth in operating revenue of 22% with expenses increasing 15%. 
The greatest source of our organic asset growth continued to be our global fixed income business with $11 billion in net new flows for the quarter. Equity markets continue to be under pressure amidst negative market sentiments, surrounding global financial markets, following the downgrade of the U.S. Treasury debt rating and the increasing concerns related to sovereign debt in the Eurozone. 
Most importantly, our long-term investment performance rankings have remained strong in this market environment with the majority of our assets ranking in Lipper's first quartile over the past 10 years. Strategically, we have continued to expand our global presence in key markets, including the acquisition of Australian-based Balanced Equity Management, which closed in July and the continued integration of U.K.-based Rensburg under the Franklin Templeton brand. 
In addition to expanding our capabilities across the globe, we continue to strengthen our presence in existing markets. We launched several new funds to meet evolving investor demand and extend our product lineup, particularly in technical asset allocation and won several new sovereign and institutional mandates this quarter. 
Overall, relative investment performance remains solid across our equity and fixed income strategies. Over the past 2 months, there's been increased retention focused on the short-term underperformance of some of our global bond strategies, due primarily to the rally in long-dated U.S. Treasuries and the strengthening of the U.S. dollar and yen relative to other currencies held in those portfolios. This is not the first time a strategy has experienced a period of short-term underperformance. But over the long term, it has delivered outstanding risk-adjusted return relative to its peers. 
We're also encouraged at the fund's recent rebound in relative performance over the past few weeks. I'd also like to remind everyone that 40% of our fixed income assets under management are in U.S. products, where several of our funds benefited from the rally in treasuries. This diversification continues to offer our clients many appealing investment options and cross-selling opportunities for our sales teams. 
Our assets under management were up 2% for the year but we were not immune to the downturn in global markets seen in recent months. This is evidenced by a 10% decrease in AUM to $659.9 billion for the quarter. Average AUM also decreased 2% to $714.4 billion. Positive fixed income flows combined with the continued slump in equity markets continued to drive the mix in AUM by investment objective towards fixed income. The mix of AUM by sales region was essentially unchanged from June, but Europe and Asia continued to be the fastest-growing regions for us. Despite industry outflows in Italy and Germany, Italy remained our top selling non-U.S. market this quarter followed by Hong Kong and Germany. 
Turning to Slide 10. The decrease in AUM since June was due almost entirely to market depreciation of $87.6 billion. Net new flows remained positive at $3.1 billion. Though the early part of the summer was clearly more favorable, as market turmoil impacted flows later in the quarter. Long-term sales dropped 8% this quarter but increased 4% versus the quarter a year ago. Lower net new flows resulted from a combination of declining long-term gross sales and increasing redemptions in retail funds through the second half of the quarter, as well as a few large institutional redemptions. 
Long-term sales were once again strongest in global fixed income this quarter. The Templeton Global Bond Fund and the Global Total Return Fund continued to be our best sellers but did suffer net outflows in one week late in the quarter. Concerns over a decline in short-term performance drilled these outflows. We believe that most financial advisors, who are familiar with the investment strategy for these funds, remained confident that when the high levels of market volatility subside and fundamentals once again drive currencies, credit spreads and interest rates, the fund's NAVs will extend their recent recovery. 
While long-term growth sales and other asset classes had generally declined this quarter, sales in our tax refunds have picked up, resulting in decline in net outflows to $300 million for the quarter, the lowest level since the first quarter of the fiscal year. In fact, 10 more funds returned to positive flows. 
Our institutional business experienced some significant redemptions and new mandates this quarter. In the global equity category, we saw redemptions of $2.7 billion in institutional separate account closures from 5 investors in a variety of global strategies. However, this was partially offset by several new institutional mandates and new sovereign and pension fund accounts in both the U.S. and internationally. 
We continue to expand our international product offerings this quarter, including the registration of 11 C Cap funds for sale in Romania. In addition, we completed the acquisition of Australian-based Balanced Equity Management in July. In the U.K., the former Rensburg Unit Trust have been converted to OEIC and will now be actively promoted under the Franklin Templeton Investments brand. We also launched the Global Asset Allocation Fund in July to extend our product lineup in tactical asset allocation. 
Looking a little further along the product development cycle, you can see the potential long-term benefits of these types of investments. The C Cap versions of our Franklin World Perspectives Fund, which we launched near the depths of the financial crisis hit their key 3-year anniversary marks earlier this month, with both top quartile relative performance numbers and exceptional absolute returns since inception. This is a unique product created to leverage the strengths of the firm's local asset management teams around the world by combining our global perspective and local focus within a single portfolio, providing clients with a global growth fund, featuring access to both local research and local asset management. 
Overall, we are pleased with our continued sales momentum during this fiscal year. We ended the year with $221 billion in long-term gross sales, a 17% increase over the record-breaking year in 2010. Europe was the largest contributor of assets and net sales with $87 billion and $22 billion respectively. Taiwan remains our largest market in Asia with $21 billion in assets, while Hong Kong is closing in on the $10 billion mark. Our business in Malaysia also continues to grow quickly with $2 billion in assets further illustrating the strength and breadth of our global business and product offerings. 
Turning to Slide 12. Overall equity outflows have steadily increased since March due to the pullback in equity markets and flows have been negative since June as the industry experienced redemptions. Long-term sales of both global and U.S. equity funds declined in the face of the market turmoil, and redemptions from global equity were elevated this quarter due to institutional withdrawals I mentioned earlier. A few funds on the retail side attracted increased sales and net new flows compared to last quarter, most notably the Franklin Gold and Precious Metals and the Franklin India Bluechip funds. But overall, we saw an increase in outflows from retail investors. 
U.S. equity funds saw a continued increase in redemption activity, though some funds have been attracting continued debt inflow such as the Franklin Growth, Rising Dividends and Franklin Utilities. We continue to promote the value of long-term investment in global equity funds to financial advisors and their clients through the GLOBAL - THE NEW CORE theme, which is an extension of our 2020 Vision campaign. We have also focused on maintaining transparent and informative commentaries with advisors and investors, especially following the recent events that led to increased market volatility and have provided commentary with market perspective from a variety of portfolio managers. 
Hybrid funds, including the Franklin Income Fund experienced net outflows of $800 million this quarter, primarily due to a variable annuity insurance program redemption. Global international fixed income flows were once again strongly positive for the quarter led by Global Bond and Global Total Return. U.S. fixed income slipped into outflows. The tax-free fixed income net outflows improved significantly with the Franklin Federal Intermediate-Term Tax-free Income Fund, showing the biggest turnaround in this category. Cash management products had inflows of $600 million this quarter but still represent a very small part of our business. 
I will now turn it over to Ken for the operating results.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The strength of the company continues to be reflected in our operating results. Operating income for the quarter was $688 million, a 1% increase from the third quarter and a 35% from the prior year and a record for the company. Net income for the quarter
componenttext:
The strength of the company continues to be reflected in our operating results. Operating income for the quarter was $688 million, a 1% increase from the third quarter and a 35% from the prior year and a record for the company. Net income for the quarter was down 17% from the third quarter at $416 million. And earnings per share decreased accordingly to $1.88 due to unrealized marked-to-market losses on various investments, which I'll discuss in a moment. 
Net income for the year was $1.9 billion, up 33% from the prior year and earnings per share was $8.62 for the year, up 36% from the prior year. Investment management fees increased 2% for the quarter and included some items requiring explanation. Normalizing the results to exclude these items, results in the 3% decrease in investment management fees, which makes sense given a 2% decrease in average assets under management and a slight reduction to the blended effective fee rate due to the mix shift towards fixed income that Greg mentioned earlier, as well as the acquisition of Balanced Equity Management in July. 
Balanced Equity Management has a lower effective fee rate due to the size and nature of their client base. Part of the increase in total investment management fee revenue was attributable to an increase in performance fees of $47.6 million, and that related to the carried interest from the sale of assets from Darby emerging markets fund which we mentioned last quarter. 
It's also worth noting that on October 3, the second and final piece of a previously discussed redemption of a very low and flat-fee advisory count was incurred. The first portion of this redemption was reported in the first fiscal quarter of the year, and the remaining $11 billion of assets in this account will come out in this month's assets under management release, though effect on our earnings should be immaterial, as the account was only generating about $2 million of annual revenue. What you should see, as a result, is a decrease in average assets under management with a nearly-offsetting increase in the effective fee rate. 
Sales and distribution fees decreased 7% consistent with the decrease in average assets under management and sales. The asset-based revenue component, which comprises most of this line declined 2% due to decreased average assets under management and, the sales component decreased by 6.8% because of a decrease in U.S. sales, which was partially offset by an increase in the international sales. Shareholder servicing fees were $75.5 million, a decrease of 3%, which is less than the decrease in billable accounts due to the July purge of 2.2 million U.S. accounts that we mentioned last quarter. The remaining decrease was attributable to a decline in networking fees due to the conversion of network accounts into omnibus accounts.  Other net revenue was essentially flat for the quarter. 
Now turning to expenses on Slide 16, we can see that they decreased 2% compared with the previous quarter. The decrease of 7% in sales, distribution and marketing expense was consistent with the 7% decrease in revenue. Compensation and benefits was $309 million, a slight decrease from the prior quarter as increased salaries and incentive compensation were more than offset by lower sick and vacation pay, retirement and commission expenses. 
Information systems and technology expenses were up 21% this quarter as projects were expensed and is completed in the final quarter of the fiscal year. Occupancy expense was up 10% due to the increases in building maintenance, utility costs and equipment depreciation. 
General, administrative and other expense was up 32% this quarter largely due to $11.1 million of fees related to the Darby carried interest payment and a seasonal increase in advertising and promotional expenses. 
Now because the relationship between noncontrolling interest and consolidated sponsored investment products and variable interest entities was causing some confusion, since they impact different parts of the income statement, we've updated Slide 17 to make their relationship clearer. 
Other income net of noncontrolling interests swung to a loss of $68.5 million compared to a gain of almost $30 million last quarter. The primary reason for that change was marked-to-market losses in investment securities. And although we had income from dividends, interest capital gains, gains on available-for-sale investments and positive foreign exchange revaluations, we experienced approximately $160 million of marked-to-market unrealized losses in our equity method and trading investments, consolidated sponsored investment products and consolidated variable interest entities.  And of course, we've seen those marks turn favorable as the market environment has improved recently. Interest expense was a little higher this month due to an increase in our tax reserve. 
Turning to Slide 18. The year-to-date effective tax rate increased 1.5% this quarter. Although this rate is higher than we expected, the increase is primarily due to a shift in the net earnings mix towards higher tax jurisdictions, as a significant portion of our unrealized losses on investments were in lower tax jurisdictions, and that reduced earnings in those jurisdictions as a percentage of taxable income. The annual rate has been fairly consistent over the past 4 years, but we do experience quarterly volatility, particularly, as foreign-source earnings fluctuate. 
The operating margin for the quarter was 37.5%, and that's roughly flat with the last 4 quarters. Cash and investments was $9.4 billion at September 30, including about $1 billion from variable interest entities. And we repurchased 3.1 million shares this quarter, decreasing shares outstanding to 217.7 million. Note that our 36% year-over-year growth in earnings per share exceeded the growth in net income attributable to the company by approximately 3% due to the benefits of EPS accretion, resulting from this program. 
The payout ratio for the quarter was 94% due to the acceleration of repurchase activity as our stock price decreased. We remain committed to returning a substantial portion of free cash flow to shareholders over time. However, a substantial portion of cash and investments is held offshore or used to see new products and may not be available for repurchases or dividends. 
And that concludes our commentary on the fourth quarter results. As always, if you have any questions, please contact Investor Relations or Corporate Communications. Their contact information is located in the presentation and the press release. Thank you.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Conference Call for the quarter ended September 30, 2011. My name is John, and I'll be your operator for today.Please note that the financial results to be discussed in this conference call are
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to Franklin Resources Earnings Conference Call for the quarter ended September 30, 2011. My name is John, and I'll be your operator for today.
Please note that the financial results to be discussed in this conference call are preliminary. Statements made in this conference call regarding Franklin Resources, Inc., which are not historical facts, are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from the future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the Risk Factors and MD&A sections of Franklin's most recent Form 10-Q filing. [Operator Instructions] 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. Greg Johnson. Mr. Johnson, you may begin.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome. Thanks for taking time out to join Ken Lewis and I today for our call. I think, first of all, considering the volatility during the quarter, we are pleased to report positive net flows of just over $3 bill
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome. Thanks for taking time out to join Ken Lewis and I today for our call. I think, first of all, considering the volatility during the quarter, we are pleased to report positive net flows of just over $3 billion. We are also pleased to report record operating earnings of $688 million. 
And now, we'd like to open it up for your questions. Thank you.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Cynthia Mayer from Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Cynthia Mayer from Bank of America.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

componenttext: Just maybe a question on the institutional global international flows you guys mentioned in the recorded commentary. It seems like given how good the 1- and 3-year performances for Templeton equity, I'm wondering what's behind the institutional redemptions you mentioned. And also I think you mentioned some inflows, so I'm wondering what the net is of institutional flows to international global equity overall?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that's a good question. And there were, I think, 5 different lumpy -- and each of them was for a different reason within global equities. There were 2 kind of long-standing state relationships that -- one in emerging markets and one in [Audio Ga
componenttext:
I think that's a good question. And there were, I think, 5 different lumpy -- and each of them was for a different reason within global equities. There were 2 kind of long-standing state relationships that -- one in emerging markets and one in 
[Audio Gap]
and some of that is performance, and some of it's moving to passive, but it did result in, I think, about $1.6 billion or $1.7 billion, between the 2 of those. And then we had another significant account in the variable annuity side on the Mutual Series Discovery side that moved to an in-house manager within one of the large insurance companies that wasn't as much performance-related. And sometimes there's just timing differences. When these redemptions were made, it could have been lagging at that time and then taken a while. And more of the recent rebound in performance may not have been considered.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just as a follow-up, I think you mentioned Italy was your top-selling area. Was that sales of Global Bond? And what if any impact, do you think, the European agreement on recapitalizing the banks would have on European's appetite for Global Bond
componenttext: Okay. And just as a follow-up, I think you mentioned Italy was your top-selling area. Was that sales of Global Bond? And what if any impact, do you think, the European agreement on recapitalizing the banks would have on European's appetite for Global Bond Fund?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's probably a little early to assess that. I still think it's viewed as an alternative category, and obviously, a positive overall for how that fund is positioned and how well it's done. And some of the weakness, which we felt was more sho
componenttext: Well, I think it's probably a little early to assess that. I still think it's viewed as an alternative category, and obviously, a positive overall for how that fund is positioned and how well it's done. And some of the weakness, which we felt was more short term certainly turned around here in the last few weeks. So as far as what happens in terms of flows, I think, just overall, as you would expect the last week we had negative outflows within the Global Bond category and that pressure continued early into the New Year. We don't really like to comment a whole lot on where fund flows are going, but I think in this case, just due to some of the misinformation that's been out there, we'll say that we have been pleased to see how it has been very steady despite that one short period of underperformance. And net-net, year-to-date, probably around breakeven overall with an improving trend and U.S. doing better than Europe as far as looking at the flows within the 2 regions.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up with the Global Bond Fund. I understand the performance has snapped back pretty sharply in the last month other so. But just given the performance hiccup, if you will, are you concerned at all that you might be at risk of somewhat of a ki
componenttext: Just a follow-up with the Global Bond Fund. I understand the performance has snapped back pretty sharply in the last month other so. But just given the performance hiccup, if you will, are you concerned at all that you might be at risk of somewhat of a kind of a reverse halo effect where maybe some of your other global fixed income funds might be susceptible to a slowdown in flows, either across kind of retailer institutional channels?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. I think any time you have that kind of volatility, yes, it'll be a speed bump and slow things down. And certain people will have a new appreciation for the kind of volatility that you can see in that kind of a fund. And we've always said
componenttext: I don't think so. I think any time you have that kind of volatility, yes, it'll be a speed bump and slow things down. And certain people will have a new appreciation for the kind of volatility that you can see in that kind of a fund. And we've always said that this is a fund that's not really benchmark-oriented. And as far as how it's run and how its performance has been so outstanding over time that you will have short-term periods of underperformance. And if we look back in the history of this fund, it's had a couple of periods where it's been down 7% or 8%. So it's not unusual to have that. And it's the kind of style that I think a lot of people are looking for as far as trying to get that outflow from active management in there. So we've already been encouraged by the snapback in flows and positive flows with the U.S. -- certainly on the U.S. side with Global Bond. I think if you look at the absolute numbers and for the year, nobody's lost money in that. Our relative performance is down a little bit, but that's been coming back. But as far as the -- it has a positive return for the year, close to a positive return today. So that -- I think that, that's very important in the psychology of money and new money coming in. And we're still encouraged by the tremendous overall record that it has. And short-term things can move very quickly especially with currencies.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just given kind of the decline in AUM and the slowdown in net flows more recently, are you at the stage where you may be starting to kind of tap the brakes on some projects or reinvestment spending? And then just more broadly, how much flex
componenttext: Okay. And then just given kind of the decline in AUM and the slowdown in net flows more recently, are you at the stage where you may be starting to kind of tap the brakes on some projects or reinvestment spending? And then just more broadly, how much flexibility do you have on the expense side to kind of defend margins looking forward, assuming the markets remain volatile?

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right. This is Ken, I'll take that one. As you probably expect in the answer, we are definitely closely monitoring the expenses. I'd say in the short term, our objective is to keep expenses relatively flat for the next quarter, and some lines will be more
componenttext: Right. This is Ken, I'll take that one. As you probably expect in the answer, we are definitely closely monitoring the expenses. I'd say in the short term, our objective is to keep expenses relatively flat for the next quarter, and some lines will be more successful than others for that. But certainly, that's the message for the troops, that we're watching expenses, though we haven't decided to take any formal programs of cost reductions or any of that. But certainly, we're delaying and deferring projects. So I think there is a fair amount of flexibility, but it takes a little bit of time. And so just as we were back in the global financial crisis in 2008 -- 2007, 2008, we're pretty thoughtful about it seeing if the markets come back, if it's a protracted decline or what have you, and then we kind of make decisions real time.

headline: Franklin Resources Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
